TALK.START.PARA: —By letter dated 1 March 1994 under the signature of the deputy chair of the committee, Senator Vanstone, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, pursuant to standing order 81, has raised with me a matter of privilege. The matter raised by the joint committee is the unauthorised disclosure of an unpublished submission made to the committee. The letter from the committee sets out the facts of the matter, which, briefly, are that a submission made to the joint committee in 1991, and not published by the committee or by either house of the parliament, was quoted and tabled in the houses of the South Australian parliament on 4 March 1993. The committee's letter indicates that the committee has sought to investigate the unauthorised disclosure of this document, as recommended by the Committee of Privileges in its 20th report.

PARA.TAB: I am required to determine whether a motion to refer this matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence, having regard to the following criteria:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b)the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

My predecessor, President Sibraa, has explained the interpretation and application of these criteria in a number of previous cases. The principle has been followed that precedence is given to a matter if it is capable of being regarded by the Senate as conforming with criterion (a), and if there is no other readily available remedy.

PARA.TAB: In relation to criterion (a), the matter is clearly capable of being held by the Senate to meet that criterion, and in past cases the Senate Committee of Privileges and the Senate have made this clear. The unauthorised disclosure of an unpublished submission to a committee is declared by the Senate's privilege resolution No. 6 to be a matter which may be held by the Senate to be a contempt, and is also made a criminal offence by section 13 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987.

In relation to another remedy, the only other remedy for the alleged unauthorised disclosure of the submission would be a prosecution under the act, but that has not been regarded as a readily available remedy in past cases and is certainly not available in this case because the unauthorised disclosure is alleged to have taken place in a state parliament. That may also mean that the Senate is unable to apply any remedy if the facts are as stated by the joint committee, but that is a matter which the Committee of Privileges will no doubt consider.

I therefore determine that a motion to refer this matter to the Committee of Privileges may have precedence over other business in accordance with standing order 81. I table the letter from the joint committee. Senator Vanstone may now give notice of a motion in accordance with standing order 81.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law: Perjury
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned asks: that he be recognised as representing those many ex-marital partners and witnesses that were excluded from the Parliamentary Committee system during the entire life of the now defunct Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation because Perjury was committed in the course of their marital litigation. That exclusion from the Parliament is detailed in the November 1992 Report of the Joint Select Committee—No Honourable Member of Parliament could represent their constituents before that Committee or as a Member upon that Committee. The exclusion was total and is being repeated in the current Committee in relation to the effectiveness of the operation of the Child Support Agencies in all States.
The subject of Perjury in family law is confined to four paragraphs in Chapter 7 of the Report, 7.155 to 7.158 and the Committee's Recommendations are given at paragraph 7.159—it is recommended that:
No. 68 "the Commonwealth Attorney General examine the operation of existing mechanisms for the investigation and prosecution of perjury cases;
No. 69 "the Family Court examine means of raising client awareness of the penalties for perjury, and of the opinions available to parties who believe that an offence has been committed."

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The purpose of the bill is to facilitate the appointment of a new President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments relate to the proposed appointment as President of Justice Deirdre O'Connor of the Federal Court of Australia. Justice O'Connor has agreed to be recommended to the Governor-General for that appointment.
The Judge wishes to continue to hold her office as a Federal Court Judge, and has also requested a fixed term appointment of 5 years.
The Government has agreed to both requests.

Accordingly, section 10 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 is to be amended to provide that a Judge of a court created by the Parliament may concurrently hold the office of President. This is supported by new sections 15A and amendments to section 21. Those provisions make it clear that the tenure and entitlements, including judicial salary, of a Judge who is appointed and serves as President are not affected by that appointment or service. Any difference between the judicial salary and the Presidential salary will be made up by a special allowance.

New subsection 16(1A) of the Act provides that the next person appointed as President may have a fixed term of office. This will allow Justice O'Connor to be given the 5 year term which she has requested.

I wish to emphasise that this provision will apply only to the forthcoming appointment. Succeeding Presidents will have the normal tenure to the age of 65 years. All other appointments will also have that tenure.

Justice O'Connor is the first woman to be recommended for appointment as President of the Commission. The recommendation will be considered by the Governor-General after the Parliament has dealt with this bill.

Finally, Mr President, the Government wishes to record its appreciation of the work of the late Justice Maddern, who held the office of President of the Commission, and its predecessor, from 1985 until January of this year.
There will be no net effect on Commonwealth outlays.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, I present the report of the committee entitled Asylum, border control and detention, together with submissions, transcript of evidence, minutes of proceedings and a supporting research paper, and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my formal tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: ASYLUM, BORDER CONTROL AND DETENTION

Over the past nine months, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration has been inquiring into the law and practice relevant to immigration detention in Australia. The Committee's findings and recommendations on this complex and controversial issue are detailed in the report which I have tabled today, entitled Asylum, Border Control and Detention.

Australia's system of immigration detention has attracted much public comment in the past year. Concerns have been expressed about persons who have arrived at Australia's border without authorisation and subsequent to arrival have sought asylum in Australia. Some of those persons, currently three in number, have been held in detention for over four years.

During the inquiry, there was general agreement that the long term detention of asylum seekers is unacceptable. In this regard, the Committee has noted that various factors have contributed to the length of detention which has been endured by many of those currently in detention. These factors are discussed in detail in the report.

In examining the issue of immigration detention, it was not the Committee's role to apportion blame for past mistakes, nor to seek to justify past practice. Rather, the Committee was charged with the responsibility of assessing the appropriateness of detention within the context of Australia's orderly migration program. While past experience was relevant to the Committee's deliberations, the Committee was of the view that such experience should not be the sole determinant of future immigration policy.

The principal issue for the Committee was whether those who arrive unauthorised at Australia's borders should be allowed to enter and reside in the community while their status is being determined. In this regard, the Committee deliberated extensively on Australia's options and obligations relevant to asylum seekers.

One option for the Committee was to agree with many of the advocacy groups which made submissions to the inquiry and recommend that claiming refugee status upon arrival should guarantee direct entry to Australia. At the opposite end of the scale, the Committee could have decided to support a system whereby those who seek to enter Australia without proper authorisation are turned around at the border, as is occurring in some countries which are faced with a refugee problem of crisis proportions.

The Committee has not supported either of these extremes. Rather, the Committee has sought to ensure that Australia continues to provide an appropriate response to those assessed as being refugees, while at the same time maintaining the integrity of Australia's migration program.

In the report, the Committee emphasises that Australia must retain its sovereign right to determine who may enter, the conditions under which a non-citizen's entry may be permitted, and the circumstances under which a non-citizen may be permitted to stay or may be removed from Australia. Australia's system of immigration control, which supports Australia's important migration program, must be upheld.

Accordingly, the Committee's principal recommendation is that persons who arrive unauthorised at Australia's borders should be held in detention while their claims to enter Australia are determined, but that there should be a capacity to consider release from detention where the period of detention exceeds six months and certain requirements are met. In the Committee's view, this recommendation strikes an appropriate balance between the need to treat asylum seekers fairly, and the need to ensure that mere arrival in Australia does not become the key to unauthorised long term stay.

The Committee has recommended that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs should have the capacity to consider release from detention where the detention has exceeded six months, and the continued detention has been brought about because of inaction or administrative error by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Committee considers that the decision should be one for the Minister personally, which should not be delegated. The benefit of this is that the Minister would be accountable to the Parliament whenever the discretion is exercised.

In considering whether any unauthorised border arrival should become eligible for release, the Minister should take into consideration a range of factors which are listed in the report. These include, among others:
whether the applicant has a special need on the basis of age, health or previous experiences of torture and trauma;
whether the applicant is likely to abscond;
whether there is a reasonable basis to the applicant's claim to refugee status;
whether appropriate support arrangements can be established;
the extent to which the applicant co-operated with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; and
Australia's international obligations.
In the Committee's view, particular consideration for release should be given to those who have a special need on the basis of age, health, or previous experiences of torture and trauma.

Under the Committee's proposals, persons who satisfy the relevant criteria in the appropriate circumstances would be made eligible by the Minister for the grant of a bridging visa, which would secure release from detention.

However, the Committee has emphasised that the Minister should not be compelled to exercise the discretion to issue a bridging visa. In addition, the mechanism should be structured to ensure that the Minister's failure to exercise this discretion in any individual case does not invite judicial review.

The Committee accepts that its proposals do not go as far as some community groups may have wished. The Committee framed its recommendations after taking into account the totality of evidence provided during the inquiry. In particular, the Committee took account of:

the evidence that among those persons who are able to reside in the community while their refugee claims are determined, a significant percentage disappear into the community when they are refused permission to remain in Australia;
the reluctance of community groups to become involved in any policing arrangements for ensuring that persons released into the community would not abscond; and
the difficulties associated with providing adequate support arrangements if unauthorised border arrivals were released into the community.

On this last point, at public hearings, many community support groups suggested that there would be sufficient support within the community to sustain border asylum seekers in the community. However, when 37 asylum seekers in fact were released into the community during the course of the Committee's inquiry, as a result of an agreement reached between parties in a Federal Court action, it was evident that the reality of the situation did not match the confidence of the community groups. Committee enquiries revealed that those who had agreed to care for those released into the community were experiencing difficulty in providing care and support in the early months following release, and doubts were expressed about their ability to sustain that support in the longer term.

The Committee emphasises that a fair and efficient refugee processing system remains the key to minimising the time spent in detention by unauthorised arrivals. As a result, the Committee has recommended that, as an absolute priority, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Refugee Review Tribunal ensure that the processing of refugee claims by unauthorised border arrivals and persons held in detention be given precedence.

The Committee's recommendations are based on the evidence that previous time delays in processing of refugee applications largely have been overcome. The latest statistics provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on refugee processing times gave the Committee confidence that the changes to the refugee processing system over the past few years are providing decisions within a reasonable time frame.

On the issue of time delays, the Committee has noted that various factors have contributed to the duration of detention endured by certain unauthorised border arrivals. One such factor has been the decision by those refused refugee status at the primary and review stages to pursue litigation to the State Supreme Courts, the Federal Court and the High Court. In the Committee's view, the Government cannot be held responsible for prolonged detention where persons seek to utilise all avenues of the legal process on top of the administrative process.

Indeed, the issue of access to judicial review was the focus of much attention by the Committee. In recent years, there has been an increasing propensity to litigate migration matters in Australia's higher courts. While the Committee acknowledges that appeal systems are important to rectify errors which can be made in such matters as refugee determinations, legal challenges in the migration field, as it currently stands, can be and are used to buy time in Australia, as applicants seek to exploit every avenue and loophole open to them in their bid to remain in Australia.
The Committee considers that the increased trend to litigate migration matters must be addressed, and accordingly has recommended:
amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Judiciary Act 1903 in order to limit the opportunity for challenging refugee determinations in the Federal Court; and
the introduction of a leave requirement for applicants appealing or seeking the review of a Migration Act decision in the Federal Court.

The procedures for granting or refusing leave applications should ensure that the applications are dealt with expeditiously, and that unmeritorious claims are disposed of by screening as soon as they are filed. While a leave provision may cause some delays in the hearing of cases which have merit, ultimately it should lead to faster decision making overall, by ensuring that unmeritorious cases are not pursued through the court system. This would also ensure earlier departure from Australia of failed asylum seekers.
The Committee also considered the role of legal advisers within the refugee determination process.

While the Committee had some concerns about legal representatives providing asylum seekers with unrealistic expectations of their chances in litigation, the Committee considers that the practice of providing legal assistance to unauthorised border arrivals at the primary and review stages should be continued. Beyond the administrative review stage, any legal assistance should be subject to a merits test. A recommendation to this effect is in the report.

The Committee's recommendations relevant to immigration detention relate specifically to the new legislative provisions contained in the Migration Reform Act 1992, which is set to come into force on 1 September 1994. The report contains a detailed examination of those provisions.

During the inquiry, the Committee was hampered in its examination of the impact of the new legislation by the lack of information which was available on the regulations which will govern the operation of the Migration Reform Act. Nevertheless, the Committee has identified certain anomalies in the text of the Migration Reform Act which need to be addressed before the commencement of the Act. These are detailed in the report and relate to a number of technical matters on the new procedures for immigration clearance, bridging visas, and judicial review. The Committee has recommended that these anomalies be rectified by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

The Committee will continue to monitor developments in relation to the Migration Reform Act, in accordance with the Committee's terms of reference, by which it is charged with the responsibility of inquiring into and reporting on any changes and proposed changes to the Migration Act and Regulations, and any related Acts. To this end, the Committee has recommended that, as soon as possible, the Government make available for the scrutiny of the Committee the legislative drafting instructions and operational procedures relevant to the Migration Reform Act.

The Minister introduced the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 into the Senate on Thursday, 24 February 1994, after this report went to the printer. The Bill amends the Migration Act 1958 as amended by the Migration Reform Act 1992.

While the main focus of the inquiry was the system for immigration detention, the Committee also gave consideration to the facilities in which immigration detainees are held. The Committee examined the operation of, and conditions and services provided within Australia's immigration detention centres.

For many in the community, Australia's immigration detention facilities have become a focal point for the concerns and criticisms regarding Australia's detention policy. During the inquiry, the Committee listened to various complaints and criticisms about the immigration detention centres and sought responses from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Australian Protective Service in relation to those complaints and concerns.

The evidence provided by the Department and APS indicated to the Committee that they are sensitive to the various criticisms which have been made. Both would acknowledge that there have been past difficulties at the detention centres. At the same time, both pointed to a range of improvements which have been made.

Apart from raising relevant matters, the Committee was not in a position, nor was it the Committee's role, to address each and every allegation made. In any case, it is unlikely that the allegations or problems will cease at the end of the inquiry. For this reason, the Committee has supported a suggestion made to it by the Society of St Vincent de Paul that there should be greater opportunity for detainees, their families and community groups to raise concerns about the detention centres and have these concerns addressed. The Committee has recommended the establishment of an Immigration Detention Centres Advisory Committee, comprising representatives of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, APS, detention centre residents, community service providers, and local community representatives.
The advisory committee should consider and make recommendations in relation to the conditions and services within the detention centres.
The Committee also addressed some specific concerns about the education and health services provided at the detention centres. It has recommended that:
consideration be given to allowing detainee children to attend local schools, in the appropriate circumstances;
consideration be given to teaching detainee children in their native language; and

where a large group of unauthorised border arrivals from the same nationality are held in a detention centre, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs make every effort to engage the services of medical personnel who can provide regular consultations in the native language of that group of detainees.

Finally, the Committee gave consideration to the location of an immigration reception and processing centre at Port Hedland. Committee members acknowledged the disadvantages of placing detainees in a location away from capital cities, including the problems with accessing appropriate services, the additional costs of transport for departmental staff and legal representatives who are required to travel to Port Hedland as part of the refugee determination process, and the difficulties for detainees in accessing community support. At the same time, Committee members recognised the benefits of placing detainees in a centre which is in reasonable proximity to where most of the boat arrivals first land, and where the remoteness of the location provides a disincentive to abscond from the centre.

On balance, the Committee was of the view that it would be premature to close the Port Hedland facility at this stage. The original reasons for establishing the centre at Port Hedland do not appear to have diminished to any great extent. In the Committee's view, should the number of detainees at the Port Hedland Centre decrease to the extent that operation of the Centre would not be viable, then the Port Hedland Centre should be decommissioned, but with the capacity to recommission the Centre should it be required in the future. Recommendations in this regard are contained in the report.

The Committee's report addresses the major issues of immigration detention raised during the course of this complex and controversial inquiry. The Committee wishes to express its appreciation to all those who contributed to the inquiry and to the preparation of the report. As Chairman, I wish to express my appreciation to my fellow Committee members for the time and effort they devoted to this inquiry. Special thanks are due to Dr Kathryn Cronin, the Committee's legal adviser, for her valuable advice and support, and to the Committee Secretariat, including the Committee Secretary, Mr Andres Lomp, staff members Ms Dianne Fraser and Ms Elizabeth Copp, and the Committee's parliamentary intern, Ms Saraswathi Karthigasu.
By presenting all the facts on immigration detention, this report will contribute to a better understanding of the issue.
Adoption of the Committee's recommendations will ensure that an appropriate immigration system operates in the best interests of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Asylum, border control and detention supports the broad thrust of Australia's existing immigration detention policy. The committee has sought to ensure that Australia continues to provide an appropriate response to those in need of refuge whilst, at the same time, maintaining the integrity of Australia's migration program and border protection.

PARA.TAB: The committee's principal recommendation is that persons who arrive unauthorised at Australia's borders should be held in detention while their claims to enter Australia are determined but that there should be a capacity to consider release from detention where the period of detention exceeds six months and where that continued detention has been brought about by inaction or administrative error by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and certain requirements are met. This recommendation strikes an appropriate balance between the need to treat asylum seekers fairly and the need to ensure that mere arrival in Australia does not become the key to unauthorised long-term stay.

Implementation of the recommendations contained in the report will not put Australia out of line with other nations which have unauthorised arrival problems. As the report identifies, most countries have policies of detention, some have even harsher measures, such as turning boats around at sea. The committee rejected the proposal that boats carrying unauthorised arrivals to Australia be turned around at sea. The committee also rejected the proposal that unauthorised arrivals be detained for a short period and then released into the community on a system of bonding or bail.

The committee also rejected the suggestion which has been implicit in many submissions that, because people have embarked upon a long and hazardous sea journey and succeeded in reaching Australia, they must be refugees and therefore should be allowed to stay here permanently. The committee did not address the circumstances which prevail in countries from which people had fled, nor was it required to examine conditions in countries to which failed asylum seekers may have to return.

It is worth noting that, during the course of the inquiry, the deputy chair of the committee, Senator Short, and I visited Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia on parliamentary business not directly related to the inquiry. However, whilst we were in these countries, we made high-level inquiries about returnees—people who had returned to their homelands from which they had originally fled. It is pleasing to record in the tabling of this report that over 60,000 people have returned to Vietnam and over 362,000 people have returned to Cambodia. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees recently convened a meeting of its steering committee of the international conference on Indochinese refugees, which reviewed the situation of 60,000 Vietnamese boat people and 26,000 Lao in camps in South-East Asia.

The meeting recorded that 2,844 people had voluntarily returned to Vietnam in January of this year. The meeting decided to complete work in the first asylum countries under the comprehensive plan of action by the end of next year. This would mean that all camps will be closed at that time. Australia is playing its part in taking those refugees who have been screened from those camps into the process.

Senator Short and I visited some of the camps before and at the conclusion of the aforementioned visit to Indochina. We separately visited the Sikhui camp in Thailand and the Galang Island camp in Indonesia. Additionally, in January of this year I visited the Sungei Besi camp in Malaysia, the Whitehead camp and the Tai A Chau camp in Hong Kong. We are now in a better position to judge conditions in Australia's detention centres.

This was not an inquiry into the detention of Cambodian boat people in Australia, although one could have been led to believe it was because of the emphasis placed on the detained Cambodians in some of the submissions and public evidence taken by the committee. Many submissions, at best, overlooked or, at worse, were not concerned about the fact that people from Bangladesh, Indonesia, Poland, Romania, Vietnam, Somalia, People's Republic of China, Turkey, Nigeria and Macau had all arrived in Australia by boat and had been detained upon arrival.

This was but one of a number of disturbing features of the inquiry. The very important peace process that Cambodia has been engaged in was judged by some to be unimportant. One could have been led to believe that Pol Pot was still in power in that country and that last May's democratic elections had never happened. The fact that 362,000 people had returned to Cambodia was not thought to be relevant. Forgotten also was the fact that the last boat carrying Cambodian people to arrive on our shores occurred three years ago—in April 1991.

A quote by an 11-year-old Phnom Penh boy, Chin Ratanak, in the book A Dream for Peace—human rights drawings by Cambodian children produced by the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia—is enlightening:

SPEECH.PARA: The light of peace is rising in Cambodia, and I have the right to go to school without worrying.

PARA.TAB: The initial poor response from the public for submissions caused the committee to extend the closing date. My provocative statement at that time encouraged additional submissions. However, a number of outspoken critics of the government's policy of detaining unauthorised arrivals on our shores, and high profile advocates of boat people currently in Australia, chose not to provide their views to the committee during the course of its public inquiry.

Ms Marion Le, President of the Indo-China Refugee Association of the ACT, responded in writing to a specific committee request for information after the conclusion of the final public hearing. The committee and the report benefited from this evidence, but I record regret that she, and her organisation, had previously ignored the inquiry. Despite a public challenge and invitation to Mr Nick Poynder, a lawyer immediately and directly involved in the detention issue, he did not provide a submission to the committee and therefore did not appear before the committee to substantiate or elaborate upon his much publicised views.

Another high profile lawyer and public advocate, Mr John Griffiths, from the legal firm Blake Dawson Waldron, found time to write personally to me, but did not put his criticisms in submission form. Ms Margo Kingston, a reporter and columnist from the Canberra Times newspaper, continued throughout the inquiry to make public comment but did not see fit to formally put her views and suggestions to the committee. A number of other journalists also hold strong personal views on the detention issue. These views are expressed on radio, television and in print, but were not offered for challenge or elaboration to the committee.

His Honour Mr Justice Marcus Einfeld of the Federal Court of Australia provided the committee with a detailed submission, but chose not to appear before the committee to be questioned or challenged or to elaborate upon his views. Mr Justice Murray Wilcox was invited to make a submission to the committee after he opened and spoke at a public seminar in Sydney crudely entitled `Punishment without Crime—the Detention of Asylum Seekers in Australia'. The day before, His Honour had issued judgment in the Federal Court of Australia in a case where 48 Cambodian boat people had challenged a decision of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Justice Wilcox declined my invitation to formalise his views by way of submission or to appear before the committee. His Honour did provide a foreword to a book which arose out of this seminar.

I said it was disappointing that the aforementioned did not see fit to give the committee the benefit of their views. It is possible—even probable—that their expertise and strong views would have assisted the committee. Their appearance before the committee would certainly have aided the public debate.

I commend the report to the parliament and to the people of Australia. The report presents the facts on the immigration detention debate, and it will contribute to a better understanding of the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak briefly to the report Asylum, border control and detention of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, of which I was the deputy chairman. I support many of the remarks and, in particular, the tabling statement of the chairman of the committee, Senator McKiernan. From the outset, I welcomed the establishment of the inquiry. I note in the dissenting report by Senator Chamarette that she circulated the terms of reference in draft form to the committee at the start, which is correct. But with not undue pride, I would point out to the Senate that some of the statements I made shortly after becoming shadow minister were also a catalyst. There was general support for the inquiry because it was a very important issue. I commend the report to the Senate and to the Australian public. It has been a very interesting, very difficult and sensitive inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The report has come out with a very detailed and careful analysis. It has produced, with all the sensitivities involved, a very balanced outcome and presentation of the issues, and the recommendations reflect that. I thank all those witnesses who appeared before the committee. We received a very large number of submissions from a very wide range of people and organisations. Those submissions were critical to the committee's work.

I would also publicly congratulate Senator McKiernan on his chairmanship of the committee. It was not an easy task, and he did it very well and with grace. I would also like to thank the secretariat; in particular, the secretary of the committee, Andres Lomp, and staff members Dianne Fraser and Elizabeth Copp, and especially the committee's legal adviser, Kathryn Cronin, for the tremendous support and advice that they gave.

Let me stress what I see as one of the fundamental underpinnings of any consideration of these matters: the quite fundamental importance of maintaining the integrity of Australia's migration program, which is the envy of most other countries around the world. That is due, importantly, to a range of issues. It is certainly due, quite critically, to our universal visa system. We are also extremely fortunate in having no land borders, and we have an off-shore migration program that few other countries have. The committee agreed, I think unanimously, with the view of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which is outlined on pages 108 to 111 of the report, that the concept of detention is a control mechanism to ensure that every non-citizen entering or staying on in Australia is authorised to do so, and to ensure that the integrity of the migration program is upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority, not unanimous.

—I think there is virtually no dispute on the need for Australia to maintain its policy of detention. The fundamental question that arises is the length of the detention process. Senator Chamarette will have her turn in a moment. There are two extremely important issues that flow from this, as I have just alluded to. There is the length of the detention—I will come back to that—but also, and very importantly, the extent, if any, to which the detention regime should differentiate between what to date have been called unauthorised arrivals—in particular, the so-called boat people—and, on the other hand, the different category of illegal entrants.

PARA.TAB: These latter are mainly people who arrive in Australia legally, quite frequently on visitor visas or the like, and then overstay at the expiry of their visas. Illegal entrants in that description total well over 80,000, whereas the total unauthorised arrivals in Australia at the moment is well less than 1,000. So it is important not to get the unauthorised arrivals out of proportion in the debate. I repeat: it is the illegal entrants that, at least in volume, are far the more important problem.

In the past, unauthorised arrivals have been subject to mandatory detention; most other illegals have not. I believe that that is an unjustified discrimination. I am pleased to see that the Migration Reform Act, which comes into effect on 1 September this year—its entry deferred from 1 November last year because of sloppy departmental and ministerial actions—will remove this discrimination. That is good: all illegals will be classified as illegal non-citizens, subject to detention. However, that leaves still the second question of whether the terms of release should be the same in both cases.

The Migration Reform Act provides for a bridging visa system for all those other than what we have to date called the unauthorised arrivals. The committee felt that there should be provision for the release of unauthorised arrivals, under certain conditions, after a six-month detention period because there was a unanimous view within the committee that prolonged periods of detention of boat people or other similar unauthorised arrivals is simply unacceptable in a civilised nation like Australia. So the committee has recommended that there be scope for release of detainees after six months, under certain conditions, and those are spelt out on page 156 of the report.

I know that some people and some organisations will understandably feel that this recommendation is not sufficiently liberal. But I do ask them to have in mind when they are making their judgment that maintaining the integrity of our migration system is of paramount importance for many reasons, not the least of which is the need to maintain public confidence in that system, because if public confidence is lost then the whole of our migration program, including the refugee and humanitarian elements, is placed at grave risk. I accept and indeed subscribe to the committee's recommendations in this respect but I do draw attention, in particular, to paragraph 4.175 of the report on page 155, which states:

The Committee is mindful that the RRT is an independent body charged with making deliberative decisions in its own right and, accordingly, is not subject to Government direction in the management of its case load. For this reason, the Committee has not included reference to the RRT in the above conclusion—

SPEECH.PARA: that is the release conditions—

The Committee emphasises that its conclusion is based on the expectation that an efficient RRT review process will provide fair and expeditious decision making. If the RRT review process fails to meet this expectation, this would need to be addressed by the Government.
I stress that as an important recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The second issue that arises is the extent to which unauthorised arrivals or any other illegal immigrants should have access to Australia's judicial system to appeal their claims to stay in Australia. I believe, for reasons that are spelt out in the report, that access is far too liberal at the moment. The Migration Reform Act does make certain provisions to restrict access to the courts. The report makes further recommendations to further do that. We have also drawn attention to the fact—and it is a specific recommendation, No. 6, in the report—that if those things do not result in a very significant reduction in appeals through the judicial system, the matter needs to be looked at again.
We have a very efficient administrative appeals system in Australia that ought to be taking precedence. I commend the report to the Senate and to the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in paying tribute to the chairmanship of Senator McKiernan and the deputy chairmanship of Senator Short, and to congratulate the committee on the great work it has done. I have added an addendum to the committee's report, and that deals with the capacity of judges to release people from custody in the appropriate circumstances.

PARA.TAB: In my view the courts are absolutely fundamental to the sort of society in which we live. We are a great democracy, a very great and tolerant country, and one that can justifiably pride itself on the way it treats everybody within its borders. Much of that character comes from the capacity of the courts to deliver people from imprisonment in appropriate circumstances. That is a long and a traditional role played by the courts over many generations in Australia, and prior to that, over many centuries in the United Kingdom, from which we draw our legal traditions.

That was so in the great cases that dealt with slavery. There was the case of James Somerset, a black person from Africa. He had been taken as a slave to Virginia and then to England, and he remained there for two or three years. When his master wanted to take him back to Virginia, a writ of habeas corpus was taken out on his behalf, and the courts held that that writ was available to a person, no matter how low his social status.

It seems to me that Somerset's case typifies what we should be about in this country, and that is giving the courts a capacity to deliver people from an imprisonment or from a custody that is not, in the circumstances, correct. As I said in my addendum, it is quite right and proper that the executive itself should have rules according to which people might be released from custody. But it troubles me that the power to deliver a person from executive custody should be confined to the executive. The very statement of that indicates the problem—that the person who holds somebody else in custody should not be the only one who delivers that person from custody.

In Australia we have a great legal system. We have great judges; we have judges who do have the capacity to take into account the public interest at the same time as taking into account the particular circumstances of a person. In my view, judges have the capacity to measure the public interest in preserving, as Senator Short has so ably put it, the integrity of the system of immigration into Australia. At the same time, the courts can balance against that the public interest that nobody should be confined unjustly.
In paragraph 4.181 the committee deals with tests that could be applied in deciding whether or not a person should be released from detention after six months. One test is:

SPEECH.PARA: .whether the applicant has a special need based on age, health, or previous experiences of torture and trauma.

If a person has that experience, that is an appropriate matter to take into account. If a person has suffered trauma overseas it may well be that that person should be released as a matter of urgency much earlier than six months, and it is proper that the judges should have the power to do so. The addendum really is an expression of my absolute faith in the judicial system, my absolute trust in the division of powers, and my absolute faith that if we do give the courts the power they traditionally have had, then that process will not threaten the overall integrity of the immigration system but will ensure that those people who are in need of release are properly released.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express my thanks for the hard work and dedication of the secretariat of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration—the secretary, Mr Andres Lomp; staff members, Ms Dianne Fraser and Ms Elizabeth Copp; and the legal adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin. I also acknowledge the many hours of discussion put in by the deputy chairman and the committee members.

PARA.TAB: I must express my extreme disappointment at the majority report presented here. As I explained in my dissenting report, there is no need for the continuation of mandatory detention that is at the basis of this majority report. This is the most inhumane and unjust of policies, not to mention being extremely costly and ineffective in terms of its purported aims. I looked in vain for evidence to support the continuation of mandatory detention—for perpetuating the disgraceful situation where most of the boat people currently in gaol have been held for more than a year. Some have been held for four years for the so-called crime of coming to Australia without a valid visa. We do not even treat major criminals this harshly.

The majority report blithely notes the length of detention that some boat people have had to undergo but seems to imply that much of the blame for this lies with the legal appeals that have been lodged by detainees. This smacks of a `blame the victim' mentality. If the law is being applied in such a slipshod or discriminatory manner by the departments that a legal case is recognised by the courts, why should not detainees utilise the courts? This is the course available to Australians who perceive themselves to be wronged. When the alternative may be the return to a country where people may face punishment or discrimination, then of course such people are going to make all possible efforts to make sure their cases have been properly considered, and if we regard ourselves as a free country that is right and proper.

This `blame the victim' feeling of many of the report's conclusions perhaps explains why the majority report gives so little attention to the psychological impacts of prolonged detention. There is no shortage of evidence as to the effect of prolonged detention on individuals and families, and these effects can occur no matter how good the detention facility or how robust the individual. Long-term detention is deleterious to everybody, with detainees suffering from boredom, frustration and anxiety, and feeling depressed and tense. There have been suicide attempts and the effects on children are particularly worrying, as the Red Cross and the New South Wales Child Protection Council testified before the committee.

The majority report is also somewhat vague concerning the cost of Australia's detention system. As an overview, detention costs for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs totalled $18.43 million in 1992-93 alone, and this figure does not include the costs of legal assistance. The per person, per day costs are similarly of concern, especially when it appears that there are less expensive alternatives available, as I will discuss shortly.

The majority report justifies its recommendation to continue mandatory detention by noting how processing and review times for refugee applications have fallen considerably since 1990 and 1991. I find this illogical. One does not tolerate poor policy in the hope that its injustice and impracticalities will never become apparent. Moreover, the arbitrariness of the detention means that Australia will still be in breach of its international conventions. If the rest of the committee was so sure of the speed and fairness of administrative procedures for asylum seekers, why was it so adamant as to mandatory detention? Furthermore, why was it so mean-spirited in terms of the restrictions on when and who could be considered for release?

The mean-spiritedness is clearly evident in a number of respects.First, the minister is requested to consider release only where the period of detention exceeds six months and the delay is due to lack of action on the part of the department. Six months is a long time.

Second, the class of detainees to be considered for release if this stage is reached appears to be additionally restricted by the majority report to those who fall into specified categories, such as age or health related need. One can easily argue that the psychological effects of detention for this length of time can be debilitating for anyone, not just the aged, infirm or children. The impact on children of six months detention is incalculable. The third act of mean-spiritedness—this is also reflected in several majority report recommendations—is that it seeks to restrict the legal bases on which immigration decisions can be appealed.

This last point brings me to the political double-speak in the majority report, also referred to by Senator Short, parroting that of the government in describing the Migration Reform Act as eliminating the distinction between the asylum seekers who arrive without documentation and those who apply for asylum after having entered Australia. Why is this a sleight of hand? While it is technically true and stated in the act that all illegal entrants will be subject to mandatory detention, in practice only boat people will be detained. The thousands of illegal entrants already in the community will continue to be allowed to remain in the community while their claims for refugee status are reviewed.

The government cannot have it both ways. If the federal government has decided that documented arrivals who overstay their visas do not pose any threat to the maintenance of Australia's immigration system by being conditionally released into the community, it is extremely difficult to see why it is not the same with unauthorised border arrivals.

The majority report appears to ignore this state of affairs and gloss over it, and regards almost any litigation by asylum seekers as unjustified. More seriously, the majority report recommends a substantial reduction in access to the judicial system. This situation is much more dangerous than the political double-speak occurring with the supposed elimination of the visa-no visa distinction.

Indeed, the limiting of grounds for judicial review of the Migration Act decisions is such as to be possibly against international conventions. Australians would be horrified if they could not challenge administrative decisions on the basis of breach of the rules of natural justice, lack of evidence, unreasonableness or bad faith. Many of these grounds are part of our legal heritage and the exclusion of non-citizens from similar access to judicial review of administrative decisions on these grounds is extremely discriminatory and unjust.

The Human Rights Commissioner has submitted that Australia is currently in breach of several international conventions because of our system of detention. As there is currently no provision which allows the individual circumstances of detention of border claimants to be taken into account, Australia is in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Australia's long-term detention of children also means that we are clearly violating the Declaration on the Rights of the Child and the conventions on the rights of the child. I would submit that the recommendations of the majority report, if implemented, would only increase the likelihood that Australia is breaching international conventions.

All this injustice, this expense and this breach of international conventions is totally unnecessary. There are alternatives available which actually achieve the objectives that are claimed for the practice of detention. The basis of the alternative is a conditional release to be made available to all unauthorised border arrivals claiming refugee status once preliminary identity, security and health checks have been completed. The basic thrust of a conditional release scheme would be to release relevant detainees into the community under specific conditions.

Community groups and their resources would be utilised in a cooperative approach to provide such releasees with accommodation, material goods, transport, education, health and counselling that are adequate for their basic needs. The federal government would provide funds for most of these services, although community organisations may be able to provide some from their own resources.

Particular emphasis on early release should be given to vulnerable individuals such as children, the elderly, the infirm and those who have been victims of trauma or torture, since they are likely to be particularly affected by detention. To say that their detention is mandatory for the first six months prior to these conditions allowing their release on a bridging visa is outrageous.

As well as being more appropriate for the level of the offence that has been committed—that is, entering without a visa—a community based scheme also has considerable potential for savings compared with mandatory detention. I emphasise the fact that if the sleight of hand or the double-speak that says all illegal entrants will be detained is actually true, the enormous blow-out in the budget will defy our imagination.

The remainder of the speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue that arises is the extent to which unauthorised arrivals—or any other illegal immigrants—should have access to Australia's judicial system to appeal their claims to stay in Australia.

It should be recognised that, since 1992, the fundamental reason for continued detention of the unauthorised arrivals is that they have chosen to appeal through our judicial system against the double rejection by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and by an appellate review body, of their applications to stay.
Australia is almost alone in allowing such unrestricted access to our courts in addition to the two tier administrative review system we have.

This increasing resort to judicial review in recent years is in my view undesirable. It cannot be totally eliminated, whether we like it or not, because our Federal Constitution guarantees right of access to the High Court. However, I believe, as did the majority of the Committee, that steps should be taken to severely curtail the access to our Judicial system to appeal against decisions which have been given after the most careful and objective consideration and review at the administrative level. No less than 60-65 percent of all the ADJR Act cases before the Federal Court relate to the Migration Act.
The Migration Reform Act has introduced changes which should go some way to meeting this objective.
The Committee's report makes recommendations to further restrict appeal access.
We are not certain that this will be sufficient. So the Committee made a further recommendation, recommendation 6 on page 104, namely:

". . . if the amendments in the Migration Reform Act 1992 and the proposals in this report aimed at curtailing the recent trend to litigate migration decisions in the higher courts are not successful, consideration be given to implementing a new refugee determination process which would provide refugee claimants with access only to the two tier administrative process, and which would close off access to review and appeal in the higher courts, save for the right of access to the High Court which is guaranteed in the Australian Constitution. . . "
The report deals with a very difficult and sensitive subject.
The importance of maintaining the integrity of our migration system surely cannot be questioned.

It should also be recognised—with pride—that Australia has an unparalleled record for its granting of refugee status to people fleeing from persecution in other countries. We have given refuge to half a million people since 1945. That makes Australia the third largest recipient of refugees in absolute terms, and the first on a per capita basis.
I believe the Report encompasses all these many considerations in a balanced way, and I commend it to the Senate and to the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, I point out that if there is an adjournment the matter can go over to Thursday.

—by leave—I thank the Senate. I will read the minority report because alternative views have been expressed. I was talking about the costs of the program and of the savings of an alternative. I now want to talk about the success rate of that. The evidence from existing release schemes indicates that there is likely to be quite a good success rate in terms of adherence to release conditions. Safeguards for release would build upon the experience gained from the system that currently operates for illegal immigrants. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would still retain some responsibility for those released. The department would also coordinate the program and provide the necessary resources to appropriate community groups to ensure that an adequate scheme is established.

PARA.TAB: Replacing mandatory detention with a conditional release scheme is basically the application of a risk benefit approach. Of course, some unauthorised border arrivals may abscond on a conditional release scheme, just as do some illegal entrants and some citizens on bail. However, these numbers can be minimised by the use of safeguards and incentives. It should not be forgotten that what is being offered is no more than what is offered to Australian citizens, who are invariably able to apply for release when the type of offence involves a relatively minor level of criminality.

Meanwhile, the government could save considerable amounts in terms of costs spent on unauthorised border arrivals. More discussion and analysis on the details of the conditional release scheme that I propose would be necessary before implementation by the federal government. However, I believe that the evidence supports the view that such a scheme would not only deal with unauthorised border arrivals in a more humane manner, it would also be more effective in a risk management and a cost sense than the process currently in existence or proposed in the majority report.

Finally, to the extent that one of the reasons for the federal government's mandatory detention is deterrence, it should be noted that the number of unauthorised border arrivals is likely to vary more with events in overseas countries than with the harshness of Australia's detention policies. In addition, small sums spent in helping refugees at overseas locations may be considerably more effective than the large sums spent on detention in Australia. There appears to be an assumption, but no evidence, in the majority report that the conditional release of border claimants would see the control mechanism unravel. Consequently, an increase in expenditure on support of refugees overseas would be more useful than the continuation of mandatory detention if the government believed that additional measures to dissuade refugees from coming to Australia were necessary. Given the apparent cost of detention, providing resources to help refugees overseas would undoubtedly be considerably more cost effective.

In conclusion, the practices of other countries, cost effectiveness, common justice and our obligations with respect to international conventions all point to the elimination of mandatory detention as a government policy and to maintaining current processes of judicial review. The majority report fulfils none of these criteria, which is why I disagree with most of its recommendations—almost all—and have provided a dissenting report.

One of the recommendations with which I can wholeheartedly concur, however, is that the processing of applications for refugee status from unauthorised border arrivals and persons held in detention must be given absolute precedence. This is particularly the case, given the existing situation of mandatory detention and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) refusing to exercise his discretion and release all long-term detainees. It is also necessary because of the extremely unsympathetic and restrictive nature of the majority report recommendations. I would like to express my heartfelt appreciation to those individuals and organisations who put time and effort into making submissions and appearing before the committee. Their appeals were overwhelmingly to end our detention regime. I am deeply sorry that their views received so little recognition.

I would like to make some final comments concerning the overall inquiry process as played out in this report on detention practices. I believe that the conclusions in the report do not reflect independent analysis of the evidence presented to the committee, but rather reflect existing prejudices of both the government and opposition parties with respect to boat people. These prejudices are evident in all discussions that occur in this place on migration, including those last year on the Migration Amendment Act and Migration Reform Act. I only wish that the changes that are recommended by the majority report did more than just seek to justify an inhumane and unjust policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continuing my remarks from yesterday on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1993. To recap, this is an important debate, although the legislation which is the catalyst for the debate disguises that matter. It is a very simple piece of legislation which proposes a series of amendments to make the operation of the training guarantee administration simpler and to provide more flexibility in its implementation. However, when one looks at the range of speakers proposed by the opposition on this matter, it is quite apparent there are much bigger issues at stake than would be contained in this measure which has budgetary implications of about $2 million this year. What is at stake is essentially an ideological debate about the role of the state and the role of government in the provision of assistance to employers for training. It goes to the heart of basic philosophical attitudes about the way in which these measures should be provided.

PARA.TAB: The list of speakers provided by the opposition clearly indicates it takes this matter very seriously. The remarks we have already heard by Senator Teague indicate that there is not much at stake in terms of the amendments themselves; it is the principle at the very heart of the bill that is causing concern to the opposition.

Essentially, I have been arguing that reliance on the market to provide such basic measures as training of the Australian work force is a totally inadequate measure to provide the necessary skills for the development of a fully-rounded work force and to provide for a mature, developing economy. No clearer example of that can be provided than the fact that a report by the National Safety Council of Australia produced earlier this year indicated that Australian employers are endangering the lives of workers by failing to provide adequate training in the workplace. Up to 600 deaths and 500,000 injuries a year can be directly attributed to the failure of Australian employers and a failure of the market to provide adequate training. That clearly indicates the need for measures to ensure there is adequate provision by this country for workers and for the way in which employers provide training.

What has been indicated is that the Australian economy is growing. As I said yesterday, there is an opportunity now for a better trained work force to participate in that economic recovery and prosperity. In my view, what the training guarantee levy has successfully done is to encourage a much greater compliance rate and a much greater responsibility by employers to meet their responsibilities to this country as a whole. The compliance rate of over 95 per cent is particularly significant. In 1989, a training expenditure survey by the government indicated that 58 per cent of businesses were spending nothing on training and 74 per cent were spending less than one per cent on training.

Many critics of the scheme indicated to the Senate committee hearings that a majority of businesses report that their training has been more effective since the training guarantee levy has been in operation. This legislation and these amendments are only part of a total package, however. This government is keen to ensure there is an ongoing commitment by industry to a more competitive approach to industry development.

Training of one's workers is a very important part of that. From the workers' point of view there is an essential responsibility to ensure that work satisfaction is improved by being able to participate more effectively in the work force and able to move more flexibly between employers to improve the employability of workers.

Those employers who bludge on other employers by not providing training are committing a great disservice, not just to this country, but to the industry in which they participate. It is not appropriate for employers to say, however, whenever there is a shortfall in skills, that the government has a responsibility to fill the gaps. That has been the tradition in this country. Whenever there is a shortfall in skills there are calls by employer groups to provide more immigrants. The old idea of planeloads of people arriving to fill gaps in the economy is totally inappropriate and inadequate for an advanced industrial country.

This government says it is important for all groups in the community to participate in economic development. The government provides all sorts of incentives to employers. Some $2.5 billion a year is provided in direct assistance to employers by governments in this country. It is up to employers to meet their share of the burden. It is not good enough for conservative employer groups, represented in this place by the Liberal Party, to say that the government should get out of encouraging employers to meet their obligations.

The critics of this scheme who suggest the scheme is too bureaucratic and administratively too costly, in my judgment, will be demonstrated by the review process that is currently under way to be incorrect. To date, we have not seen the evidence to support those sorts of ideological claims by the dry-as-dust groups within politics in this country who suggest this scheme is somehow or other not working properly.

We need to clearly examine the evidence which suggests rorts are occurring and to understand precisely what is the political motivation of people who make such claims. What we heard during the Senate committee inquiry into this matter was that businessmen for some years have used the taxation system to their advantage. Nothing is likely to change quickly in that regard. Notwithstanding the fact that the evidence of the Tax Office is that there is very little abuse of the scheme, it is quite apparent some people will misuse any taxation schemes, just as it is quite apparent some employers will resist any attempt by the government to encourage a more socially responsible attitude in terms of the provision of training for workers, no matter what direct benefits they enjoy by participating in such schemes.

It is not good enough for some employers to bludge on this country and to suggest it is the state's responsibility to meet their shortfalls and their inadequacies. This is an important provision. The substantive issues concerning this debate need to be defended.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me say that the Democrats support the amendments contained in the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1993. We agree with their purpose, which is to make the scheme slightly more flexible. Senator Carr provided an accurate description of the effect of the amendments. I referred this bill to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. During that inquiry we were told in further detail what the effect of the amendments would be. As such, the Democrats support the amendments.

PARA.TAB: We were also told during that inquiry that the Department of Employment, Education and Training was conducting a review of the training guarantee scheme. Some aspects of that review were revealed to the committee, but I am still unclear about what the review can achieve in the long term while the government maintains the philosophy of compulsion rather than encouragement. No matter which way one looks at this scheme, it is a scheme which emphasises compliance and compulsion rather than looking at ways of encouragement.

The basis of the scheme is that if an employer is obliged, by qualifying under the scheme by crossing the threshold of payroll level, to spend a certain amount of money on training, but does not do so, a penalty will be imposed—a levy will be applied compulsorily. I support the concept of using training to increase productivity, but I believe we ought to be looking at many more ways of encouraging that to happen rather than by the application of this compulsory levy.

The notion of outstanding trainers is contained within the concept of this legislation, but we have heard little about it. There has been very little publicity regarding outstanding trainers and the practices they follow. We have seen very little attempt to establish such enterprises as models for other businesses to follow. That, to me, would emphasise the encouragement aspect rather than the penalty aspect. There is quite a deal of confusion about what legitimate training is. Senator Carr mentioned the myth of rorts. I agree with him. In some ways we have a tradition whereby there are certain taxpayers who will always find a way to avoid it, and a way of using loopholes.

There should be much more emphasis on what is legitimate training so we can establish that as a model to be followed. Those who are in business to make a dollar are not there for the prime purpose of discovering loopholes but to conduct a successful enterprise. One would hope that that is the case. If those who want to encourage legitimate training emphasise what qualifies for it, we would have more success. Such an approach has the potential to positively affect all enterprises in Australia.

I would like to remind the Senate of what we were told at the committee of inquiry by Senator Schacht, who was the minister presenting evidence at the time. He reminded the committee that there are approximately 800,000 small businesses in Australia. We were also told that only some 70,000 of those businesses were required to meet the training guarantee levy; that is, only some 70,000 qualified by dint of being within the threshold of the payroll level.

In fact, only approximately 500 small businesses did not meet that requirement for training—only 500 out of 800,000—and therefore had to pay. It is fairly strange that any business at all should be in that category because the present legislation provides that an enterprise can remove its obligation to pay a levy by making an equal donation to certain educational institutions, and such a donation is a taxable deduction whereas the levy is not. I am amazed that anybody would be so ignorant as to leave himself liable for that levy when the simple way out would be to make a deductible donation to an educational institution. I am amazed that any enterprise would allow itself to be saddled with the levy at all.

Over the past three years that relatively small number of small businesses—some 500 out of 800,000—have paid approximately $6 million. That amount is much lower than the government has spent promoting and administering the scheme. I understand that the purpose of the scheme is not to raise sufficient administrative funds through levies to pay for itself. That is not the point of the scheme, and I understand that.

The point I am making is that it is an unwieldy scheme; it is not an easily administered scheme. Admittedly—and those who speak on its behalf admit to this—it is a broad brush scheme that is not targeted. It is even difficult to determine whether it achieves its own goal of increasing spending on useful training. Contained within the act at the

SPEECH.PARA: moment there are not the tools to make that determination easily.

PARA.TAB: I contend that enlightened managers were already spending on the training that this scheme requires anyway, and that they were already reaping the consequent benefits of increased productivity. We all know that there were unenlightened managers who may have been compelled by this scheme to spend on training. But the clumsiness of this scheme does not easily allow for determination of whether that spending has been on worthwhile training.

Senator Carr rightly expressed his concern that several hundred workers had died through lack of proper induction and training in correct workplace safety procedures. I share his concern, as I hope all honourable senators would. I refer to the speech given by Mrs Silvia Smith, the honourable member for Bass in the other place, on 3 February when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU's national occupational health and safety coordinator, Ms Renata Musolino, said employers needed to ensure that workplaces were as safe as possible and that workers are properly trained to manage potential danger.
Mrs Smith said that Ms Musolino said:
Clearly there are going to be industries where you can't eliminate hazards and where you have to work with hazardous chemicals or to work with electricity or you have to work suspended in the air.

You make sure that you've done everything you can to make the actual work environment as safe as possible and you train your workers. Where employers are falling down, I believe, is in both these areas.
Most employers provided adequate training but many companies, particularly small businesses, neglected their responsibilities.
That was Mrs Smith quoting the ACTU's national occupational health and safety coordinator. But this scheme does nothing to ensure that those obligations are met. This scheme does not target them.

PARA.TAB: As I have already said, there are some 730,000 small businesses which are not obliged to do anything under this scheme. The scheme is not targeted; it does not even affect a huge majority of small businesses in Australia. In an associated vein, again quoting from Mrs Smith's speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The training guarantee slots straight in with the concept of the level playing field. It also means that the good corporate citizens who train their employees do not have their staff poached by corporate parasites who do not train. This is achieved by the blanket requirements of the training guarantee. All organisations with a payroll over the threshold must train their staff.

That is very noble, but 730,000 small businesses are not caught and are therefore not prevented from poaching from enlightened enterprises that provide well directed training for their employees. Senator Carr is absolutely right: adequate training is not being provided in safety and workplace practices. This scheme does not deliver it. The free market cannot be relied upon to deliver it either; in fact, I would suggest that the free market would do almost the opposite.

PARA.TAB: This scheme needs considerable alteration before it can be declared successful in its own stated goals and achievements. I agree with previous speakers who commented about the fact that this scheme introduces a penalty of record keeping and extra administrative mumbo jumbo to be gone through just to employ people. The refinements required are considerable. In fact, when really considered carefully, this is a scheme that encourages quantity, not quality; the capacity to improve productivity is not correctly addressed; and there is no easy method of determining whether this scheme is actually delivering that which it purports to deliver. The best we can do at the moment is to agree with the amendments that we have in front of us. In fact, the first two amendments proposed by Senator Teague achieve an extension of that flexibility and, because of what they do, will be supported by the Democrats.

We are going a fraction of the way but, as far as we are concerned, the key emphasis in the future should be on encouragement rather than compulsion. When Senator Carr talks about the opposing philosophies in this debate, I would like to add a third aspect: there is not only a need for recognition that training is necessary and must be provided; we should also look at the means of compelling that event to take place. As I have said before, in this scheme there has been too much stick and not enough carrot. In the review that DEET will conduct I will be looking for alternatives such as the emphasis on outstanding trainers and establishing models of good practice and enterprise leading to increased productivity and increased safety in the workplace. I will be looking for those emphases in the DEET review.

At the moment, rather than throwing the baby out with the bathwater, we need to look at improving this scheme. Therefore, the Democrats will be supporting the first two amendments proposed by Senator Teague and will be carefully monitoring the evaluation process which DEET itself is now conducting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it this morning the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1993, which will amend the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. The principal act put into place the training guarantee scheme which, at the present time, requires employers with an annual payroll greater than $226,000 to spend at least 1.5 per cent of their payroll on eligible training. Employers who do not spend the specified amount must pay a training levy. In a sense, because it is not tax deductible, the levy is a fine or penalty imposed on employers. The defaulting employer who fails to meet the training requirement and spend the required amount of money is thereby penalised.

PARA.TAB: Two of the amendments will implement two of the government's promises that were made in the 1993 election lead-up: the carrying forward of excess expenditure and the treatment of training subsidies. Those honourable senators who were here at the time may recall that, when debating the original legislation in 1990, I alerted the Senate to the insufficiency of it in relation to the carry forward element.
