I repeat today what I said then: the inability was inequitable and contrary to normal taxation principles and taxation law and practice. What is surprising though is that it has taken this government nearly four years to act and to correct this anomaly. That is a shame.

Other amendments to the legislation include: the carrying forward of the training guarantee shortfall; the doubling of the minimum allowable apprentice or trainee amount; removal of the age restriction on student work experience; changes to grouping arrangements; and the definition of eligible training expenditure. Other provisions deal with liquidators. I have no problem with the general thrust of the amendments because they increase, although in a very limited way, the flexibility of the scheme. Commendable as the objectives of the training guarantee scheme are—the raising of the national training effort and increasing business awareness of the importance of training—the scheme is an administrative nightmare and a great disincentive to employment. From its very beginning the whole scheme was flawed, and it continues to be flawed.

When the scheme was introduced in 1990, I raised these existing problems before the scheme actually began. Those problems continue to this very day. Undoubtedly much to the government's own embarrassment, its own ministers have condemned and criticised the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—For example, what did Kim Beazley, the then employment minister, say in August 1993? I will quote him for Senator Sherry's benefit because he has expressed some surprise. Government senators really are out of touch with what Minister Beazley, who had responsibility for the scheme, said on this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that government senators are out of touch, considering that Senator Carr, for example, does not belong to the same faction. We all know that Labor Party people do not talk to each other. Here they are, out of kilter with what Kim Beazley, their leader in this particular area, has said. Let us listen to Kim Beazley's sensible words. I quote them to the shame and embarrassment of those opposite. Mr Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: The training levy was contributing to the employment costs of business and should be scrapped as soon as it had achieved these objectives.

I ask Senator Carr and Senator Sherry to note that that was said back in August 1993. The task force set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on regional development found that the scheme was not providing the training for which it was designed. Here is statement No. 2 that those opposite have not read. We have heard statements to the effect that: the scheme was flawed from the beginning; it is hopeless; it should be scrapped; it is contributing to employment costs and thus making it a disincentive to employ people.

PARA.TAB: We have heard what some government people and their advisers say but what do the industry groups say? Industry groups, such as the Australian Council of Commerce and Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the New South Wales Employers Federation, also believe that the scheme should be removed immediately. Others have suggested that it has outlived its usefulness. I suggest that it had very little usefulness in the first place. The scheme has been in operation now for some 3 1/2 years. A number of reviews have been conducted, including EPAC's report on education and training in the 1990s, the working paper of the Australian Council of Commerce and Industry and the Prime Minister's task force on regional development.

Not surprisingly, the coalition has fundamental objections to the training guarantee because it is yet another impost on company business. It is another impost on doing business, another impost on employment and another impost on the competitiveness of Australia, particularly for our firms that are trying to compete out there with the Asian tigers. What are some of the other imposts that the countries to our north do not have? They include the payroll tax and the superannuation guarantee charge. The scheme is not effective in coercing companies to increase their investment in training. That has been proved, despite all the rhetoric, despite all the shouts from the government benches.
Government senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! I would like to hear Senator Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, it has been brought to the attention of some companies that their actual level of expenditure exceeds the minimum required. Companies have therefore reduced expenditure as a form of cost cutting.

PARA.TAB: The scheme applies recklessly to all employers, ignoring their structure and their business activities. For example, the Australian National Audit Office report indicated that the scheme does not suit the management style of many companies and industries, nor does it lend itself easily to program evaluation or the development of performance indicators. In addition to the coalition's criticisms of the mechanics of the scheme, we believe the scheme is dominated by problems such as high costs of administration. Let us look at those.

The ACCI believes that the training guarantee levy has failed in its purpose, has increased administrative overhead costs for business, has been a disincentive to employment and should be abandoned or substantially overhauled. It also argues that the scheme is designed to suit the needs of the Australian Taxation Office rather than the requirements of business. That is an interesting point. The administrative problems go further than just the extra cost; they extend the extra time required to meet and to administer the scheme's onerous requirements.

And what about the scheme's impact on small business? Small businesses have problems complying with the scheme. They find it difficult to construct appropriate training programs for all their employees so they quite frequently select only a group of people to train. One of the other problems is that, because of the difficulties that small business face, the training levy is often spent by the principals in going to assorted conventions. There is a bias in that there is a tendency under the scheme for senior staff to be trained at the expense of the unskilled ranks. Small businesses rarely have the in-house resources to comply with the scheme and must seek external assistance, naturally at an extra cost.

In order to avoid paying the levy, such employers may use the exemption available to payments made to certain organisations, such as universities. Whilst the resulting free funding for such institutions is naturally good, it should not operate as a backdoor method of funding universities as businesses avoid paying the levy.

I suppose one positive aspect of the training guarantee scheme is that it has created some flourishing new businesses. Training consultancies have certainly grown. Unfortunately, this has been at the expense of other employers who will not employ, owing to the high costs of employing staff and owing to, in no small part, charges such as those imposed by the training guarantee scheme.

Firstly, we have looked at the high administrative costs. Secondly, I have just outlined the problems for small businesses. What about the abuse of the scheme? Some employers have been abusing the program by spending on executive training weekends in luxury resorts, and even some government departments have been doing that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's good for tourism.
—They have been going to luxury resorts when they should be doing some in-house training.
—What's your evidence?
—Auditor-General's reports—
—Come on, what's your evidence?

—I also mention Senate estimates. Has Senator Carr not read the evidence that has been presented about the way that some government agencies have been rorting the scheme? It is out there. One is going on at present down at Batemans Bay where people in one department are doing abseiling because they believe that it will encourage teamwork. These are the sorts of things that are going on. So, it is not only the private sector, Senator Carr and Senator Sherry, that are rorting this scheme; it is your own government agencies and departments that are rorting it at the same time.

PARA.TAB: I ask: what is happening in these so-called luxury resorts and weekends off where there is a claim for a training guarantee eligible expenditure? A high level of recreation can be included in eligible training programs—what a rort. Up to 50 per cent can be included if it is for employment related training. Industry is concerned that between 10 per cent and 30 per cent of the $941 million eligible expenditure is fraudulently claimed because of the looseness of the system—that is what it is.
I quote the rorts which the scheme is open to because Senator Carr does not believe me:

SPEECH.PARA: Overseas trips to conferences for executives of an organisation.
That is an obvious abuse of the scheme, and flies directly in the face of the objective of the scheme.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, valid training schemes such as `on the job training' cannot be recognised as eligible expenditure. This is appalling. If this is not a central problem which justifies the government seriously considering abolishing the scheme immediately, one wonders what will stimulate the government to what should be logically sound. It is inertia—four years to get the first real change to this scheme going.

I turn specifically to the amendments. While the amendment permitting a shortfall to be carried forward is a step in the right direction and one that I signalled in 1990-91, I query why a shortfall cannot be carried forward for more than one year. Why is it not three years? An extension greater than just the one year would allow business to adequately plan its training program to take into account new staffing requirements as and when they may emerge. It is prescriptively too short a period in terms of what is allowed. Again, there is not enough flexibility, even in this particular amendment.

I am concerned also that the carry forward provisions relating to the excess expenditure are not available to employers that have elected to form a group. The explanatory memorandum for this is that for technical reasons it is too vague. Perhaps Senator Sherry should direct his mind to answering the question as to the technical reasons. I would be interested in his response. The amendment to the definition of `eligible training program' is marginally better than the original provision, as it inserts the words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has, or by 2 or more persons who together have, a working knowledge of the subject area. . .
in substitution for `is' in terms of:
is appropriately qualified or experienced to design a training program of the relevant type. . .

I indicated to the Senate during the 1990 debate of this bill that problems would be associated with the trainer being appropriately qualified. I am now concerned that the term `working knowledge' is also too vague. A competency standard of some kind would be more appropriate.

PARA.TAB: With all those deficiencies, it is time that the government really took the hard and necessary decision to scrap this training guarantee levy because it is an impediment to business and our competitiveness and is unnecessary. It should be scrapped at the first available opportunity. As I stand here, I give a commitment on behalf of the coalition that, in government at the first available opportunity, we will scrap the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting this legislation, but not because we think it is perfect and incapable of improvement. A number of points mentioned in today's debate are quite true. It is possible for companies, and especially small business, to avoid their actual training contribution by the executives attending expensive conferences and seminars. I have seen a $2,000 for two days conference, especially at the time when there was one year for that money to be spent without there having to be some kind of penalty. The back of this particular conference or seminar leaflet stated, `This seminar is classified as suitable under the training guarantee levy.'

PARA.TAB: I think it was a very good way for a number of people who were putting together expensive conferences to make a lot of money. I am pleased to see that there is some extension over two years so that it is less likely that there will be the need at the end of the financial year for companies to send their executives on expensive, nondescript seminars, which are basically of benefit to people eating lunches and dinners at those seminars rather than creating any real training outcome.

By the same token, extending the scheme a further year, as the coalition is suggesting, may create problems in the other direction. I am not suggesting that the majority of companies were involved in avoiding paying their contribution, but I am concerned if the scheme can be averaged over three years then some, especially young workers in a particular industry whose payroll exceeds the minimum payroll requirement for the training guarantee to be required to be spent, may fall through the gaps. Two years may be the means by which people who are working in a particular business may not receive any reasonable training outcome because their employer has managed to avoid any particular expenditure on useful training for over two years.

I would be concerned that this would be extended too far too soon. The system needs review. Most government expenditure programs which have an outcome which is required to improve training and employment prospects or the efficiency of industry ought to be reviewed. There are a number that I would like to see the opposition have a suitable interest in, such as the removal of tariffs and other micro-economic reform, that is supposedly built to improve efficiency and have an employment outcome.

I would like to see the opposition as interested in the government reviewing those kind of schemes to see if the outcomes were what the government originally said they were going to be. Employers, especially in medium and larger businesses, should look carefully at their training regime. It is obvious many small businesses need assistance. I am pleased to see that this legislation recognises that there has been a problem in relation to apprenticeships, and there is some move to not penalise employers who are actually putting on apprentices by not deducting that from their training guarantee amount that is required to be paid.

I do not know that this is enough. There are problems which have not been recognised in relation to apprentices. I do not think it happens so much in the larger industries. It is known that the government provides assistance—generally $3,000—for new apprentices, but the problem is a greater problem in small businesses than it is in larger ones. It is especially so in those kind of service industries where there is a one-to-one client and craftsperson worker relationship such as electricians and plumbers. This is something that must be addressed, but at this stage cannot be through such a scheme. There needs to be a review of the way we provide useful and acceptable training incentives.

There needs to be a review of the way we provide useful and acceptable training incentives. The stick and carrot approach must be looked at carefully. I would like the government to look very carefully at the outcome of the changes mentioned in this legislation to see that they do improve the situation for the number of apprentices being trained—not just the average number. I would like the government to look at the sectors in which apprentices are being trained to see whether there are certain sectors where we are losing the ability to keep up properly trained apprentices and whether there are other sectors where it is easier to place apprentices at this stage. The Greens will be supporting this legislation and we will not be supporting the opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1993. Very soon after I entered parliament the original training guarantee bill was passed, and I spoke on it at that time. Having come from the field of education, this seemed to me to be a highly inappropriate way to go about training in the nation. The fundamental problem with it is that it sets one rate right across the whole system regardless of the type of training required or the type of business concerned. We pointed out at that time a number of the shortcomings in the bill. The bill did not take into account whether the business was small or large. Fairly obviously, the needs of small and large businesses are different. It also did not take into account the type of business. Obviously, 1 1/2 per cent for a computer business is way under the training requirements, and this applies to any highly technical business.

PARA.TAB: We looked at a business called Tweed Valley Fruit Processors which has a high tech operation for preserving and canning fruit. It spent eight per cent on training. On the other hand, in businesses such as carpet laying and removalists training does not take very long at all. Under this scheme those two types of businesses have to provide 1 1/2 per cent for training or pay the tax levy. This creates all sorts of funny training programs, which I will return to later.

Another thing that the very broad brush approach of this legislation does not take into account—this is probably its most serious flaw—is the profitability of a business. Highly profitable businesses can obviously roll with a charge like this, but very marginal businesses—particularly since this legislation came in, and with the depths of the great recession—increasingly have been forced to the wall by a whole range of inappropriate government charges and procedures. When those very marginal operations have a 1 1/2 per cent impost added—which is really another tax if they cannot spend the money on training in an effective way—they often go under, and I will return to that point later.

There are many arguments for abolishing this bill and, in this amendment before us today, we have a bandaid job. The government realises that this legislation is seriously flawed in many ways, but rather than bite the bullet and do what is required, it is putting to us that it has identified a number of these problems, and that it will take this bandaid approach and change it a bit here and a bit there and hope it will come up with a better scheme that businesses find more acceptable.

But businesses will not find it acceptable for the reasons I outlined at the start of my speech. It puts an additional cost on business. In this modern era of enterprise bargaining, it is totally inappropriate. Training really should be part of a total deal in a true enterprise bargaining package that would look, not at training in isolation, but at all aspects of the way work practices operate in a business. There could be certain trade-offs in a business which would mean that staff in highly technical areas would get a lot more training than staff in less technical areas, but there might be some other benefit in a true enterprise system for those less technical areas. This one rule for all business cuts completely across that and is another reason why it should be abolished.

In the way that some businesses go about increasing their training component there are some very ineffective types of training taking place. One of the greatest criticisms of this scheme is that it often has a high recreational component as businesses struggle to make up this 1 1/2 per cent, and this has led to a lot of rorts in the system. It was highlighted in my own city of Newcastle recently when a training group was discovered to be rorting the system considerably—for example, the group was going to Thailand to have conferences to solve some of the problems of the business. When questioned on this by a more honest member of staff, the head of the business said, `We can get away from the phones'. This particular rort was exposed and the people are being dealt with and charged. But it is the tip of the iceberg.

One only has to look at the conference brochures that are around to see the locations, the types of activity and the costs to see how much rorting is going on. I personally resent it. Apart from being a taxpayer, I am a conference attendee. There are many conferences I would like to go to. As senators, brochures come through to us on all sorts of things. Occasionally I look at one and say, `That would be good. I would like to know a bit more about that, and go to that two-day conference'. Then I see that a conference that five years ago cost me $100 to attend now costs $1,800, and many luxury weekend resorts soak up the money in the training guarantee levy. It is a distortion of training money. This country needs much more and much better training. It makes me very angry that the money is wasted in this way.

The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training was so concerned after the training guarantee levy legislation was passed that it set up an inquiry and has been monitoring its development. Indeed, this legislation before us today was referred to the committee for its consideration. A number of witnesses appeared before us, and what they had to say was particularly revealing.

DEET was there putting its usual little blocking pieces for the government and telling us that this was just very necessary finetuning. It is interesting to see that DEET will have a full report out on this legislation in October of this year. It should then come back into the parliament with our report and we should consider where we go from that point. If the government does a fair and honest assessment of this scheme I believe it will come to the conclusion that the scheme should be totally wound up, and that, in our amendment, with a sunset clause, is exactly what we are proposing.

Other people came before the committee, including Professor Noble from Charles Sturt University. He had done some research into training guarantees across Australia. He found that the average firm spends 2 1/2 per cent of its payroll in this area. He said that we should look at better training alternatives to the training guarantee levy. Indeed, returning to Professor Noble's former point, a lot of those firms which found they were spending more than the 1 1/2 per cent actually cut back their training because they thought, `We won't get the best tax benefit out of our training unless we come back to that 1 1/2 per cent'. So, in some instances, it has actually reduced training.

Gaite and Beresford from the University of South Australia have also done some research on the training guarantee levy. They appeared before the committee and said that this scheme really had little effect on business expenditure and that there was very little incentive to engage in further training. However, they pointed out—and I think this is one of the vital reasons this should be scrapped—that the training guarantee levy adds very high administrative costs and a record-keeping burden.

I have asked a number of firms to provide me with the details on that, and not just on the training guarantee levy but on the extent to which government paperwork right across the board adds to their business costs and, more importantly, adds to the time that they have to spend going through government hoops rather than making money out there in the real world. I have made that request over a number of years to quite a number of small businesses. They have all said, `Yes', I will do it.', but no-one has got back to me yet and I suspect the reason is that they are so busy completing government paperwork that they do not have time.

At our hearing we heard from one firm which gave us its experience of the training guarantee levy. That was Coles Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Pty Ltd from Broadmeadow in my own city of Newcastle. That company has been in business for 38 years and employs 30 to 40 staff. The training guarantee levy did not increase in any way that company's amount of training. But, to highlight the point I made earlier, what it did do to Coles Refrigeration was add 100 hours of paperwork per year in documentation, filling in forms and jumping through government hoops. Multiplied across the nation, this means that this particular piece of legislation has a large impact on business costs, and is another reason it should be scrapped.
Apart from our committee, other bodies have had a look at this scheme. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry conducted a survey, which concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The Training Guarantee survives today as a nuisance imposition on the costs of running a business and on the structure of training at the enterprise level.

What a damning indictment. This statement comes after a survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry which covers businesses that are the main subject of this piece of legislation. It just shows how much this government is not listening. It blindly follows ideological principle and it seems it is not capable, even when we have a piece of legislation like this before us, of fine tuning it to the needs of business and industry.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Taxation Office found that 63 per cent of firms spent the same amount or less than before the introduction of the training guarantee levy, and 70 per cent reported more administrative work. This piece of legislation is fundamentally flawed. It is not working. It does not cover the 93 per cent of businesses under the threshold. A few minor amendments, as proposed in this legislation, will not fix up the fundamental flaws of this bill.

As the government is not prepared to listen, I urge the Australian Democrats, the Greens and the independent member, Senator Harradine, to support in particular the opposition amendment which puts a sunset clause on this bill of June this year. Let us get rid of this scheme and let us get serious about training in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my coalition colleagues Senator Teague, Senator Watson and Senator Tierney in condemning the training guarantee levy scheme but supporting the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill, with amendments proposed by Senator Teague which will be brought forward in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: One can lead an animal to water but cannot make it drink. This government believes in the directive. It has shown that in all sorts of policy areas. In the area of training, the government is basically saying that it believes it knows how businesses should be run. The government believes it should tell a business that it should spend 1 1/2 per cent of its payroll on training its people, and the government has put a levy on all businesses above that $220,000 threshold to enforce this.

We know that governments cannot run businesses efficiently. That is why all governments around the world are now getting rid of their businesses. That is what the privatisation thrust is all about, so that government businesses are pushed out into the private sector to let the owners, managers and employees work efficiently in trying to compete. In properly run businesses, the owners, managers and employees all recognise the need for proper training, otherwise the businesses do not survive. They do not need a government directive to do this.

It is arrogant nonsense to suggest that government ministers know what is best for each business. It is again arrogant nonsense to suggest that government can prescribe the level of training needed for each business, even for the 45,000 businesses which are affected by this legislation. What the government can do and should do is encourage firms to be internationally competitive, and then leave it to the businesses to get on with the job.

International competition forces owners, managers and employees to perform to the best of their ability in order to make the enterprise succeed. If they do not do this, they know there is failure. In a competitive environment businesses know that they have to have a cooperative and effective work force, with appropriate education and training, and the training has to be continuous but at the appropriate level. As my colleague Senator Tierney said, it is horses for courses—a lot of training is required in some jobs and very little in others.

Training is best done on the job, and the amount and cost varies enormously. Let us consider the differences between the additional training that can be given to an experienced bulldozer operator and the training that is required almost continuously for the operators of a sophisticated, electronically controlled plant. The differences are enormous.

I am not being critical of the need for training, quite the contrary. I believe very firmly that training is an absolutely essential ingredient for successful business. I have had personal experience of that, having managed businesses and been a director of several businesses. In each of the businesses I have been involved in we have put an enormous amount into training—in fact, training expenditure commonly was of the order of between 3 per cent and 6 per cent of payroll; and that is necessary. But the judgment is made: what do we need to do to make this business efficient and make it compete with the rest of the world? If we are competing against the best people in the world, we have to train and do it well. I agree with Senator Bell's comments that encouragement and not compulsion is required in the training area. So the government is heading in the wrong direction.

The scheme has added significant business costs and, in particular, administrative costs. This is because of the requirement of the scheme for all training expenditures to be recorded separately from those incurred in the normal course of business. As two of my colleagues have mentioned, since its introduction the current scheme has been the subject of significant rorts, which by themselves make the administration and structure of the scheme a laughing stock within the business community.

We have had numerous examples quoted to us over the years about junkets to seminars and overseas travel which are totally unrelated to industry training. The many flaws in the scheme have been highlighted by the recent survey undertaken by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. There is no need to go into the details because they have been mentioned in previous speeches; but virtually all the employer organisations have criticised the scheme—and all have recommended that it be wound down.

The Chamber of Commerce and Industry report pointed to the fact that the scheme involved considerable administrative costs, and that the administration was apparently designed to suit the needs of the Australian Taxation Office rather than the requirements of business. In its first report on the compliance with the levy in 1990-91, the Australian Taxation Office was not able to conclude with any certainty whether the scheme was actually working.

According to private research conducted for the ATO, about 70 per cent of employers were meeting their training obligations under the legislation, `merely by putting together structured documentation for their existing in-house programs'. Again, I reiterate that all the major employer organisations in Australia have recommended the scrapping of the scheme.

Even government bodies as diverse as the Australian National Audit Office and the government's EPAC—the Economic Planning Advisory Council—have expressed doubt as to the practicality of the scheme. The ANAO report expressed concern that the scheme did not lend itself easily to program evaluation or to the development of performance indicators.

The audit office also found a degree of concern amongst employers and industry groups about the administrative costs of compliance with the scheme, and the fact that it has resulted in the imposition of increased structure and documentation in the management of existing programs. The EPAC report criticised the scheme for approving training programs with a high recreational component.The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the long run it would be desirable to move away from the blunt instrument of compulsion and penalties.
What we require is encouragement—not the blunt instrument of compulsion and penalties.

PARA.TAB: As one of my colleagues mentioned earlier, in August last year the then minister for employment, Mr Beazley, referred to the scheme and was reported as saying, `it probably should go'. The government's own recent task force on regional development, chaired by ACTU Secretary Kelty who is, after all, the power behind the emperor's throne, has actually recommended that the scheme be suspended for three years. According to the findings of the task force, the scheme has not been fully understood by industry, and is seen as an administrative burden.

The real need is to encourage businesses to be internationally competitive, and then leave them to get on with the job. Owners, managers and all the employees, if they are facing up to international competition, will recognise the need to do the training. The employees themselves will demand the training so that the businesses will succeed.

The amendments introduced in the bill attempt to increase the degree of flexibility in the scheme by allowing firms to carry forward excess expenditure from one year to the next. The amendments are simply tinkerings around the edge of the system which has outlived its usefulness, and is now simply a bureaucratic burden on Australian business. I support the three groups of amendments that will be moved during the committee stage by my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill. This amendment relates to an act which requires employers with a payroll over a specified level to spend a minimum amount on training. Of all the silly decisions of this government, perhaps the silliest was the training guarantee levy. It would have to have been dreamt up by some ivory tower boffins with no knowledge or understanding of the requirements of business.

PARA.TAB: The training guarantee levy was sold to a Labor government equally bereft of business experience by those people whom ex-Senator Walsh would call the `chattering classes'. Over the years I have worked in manufacturing, mining and service industries. This has meant working with people at all levels, from tradesmen and unskilled labourers to professional engineers and so on. At no stage have I seen a situation where suitable staff could not be obtained, in the main from within Australia, but in odd specialised instances, from overseas.

I did hear Senator Carr talking about employers bludging off other employers by pirating people from other companies. That practice occurred in days of full employment particularly, and still goes on today. I was a bit amazed by Senator Carr taking that view, because often very good employees are taken by other employers—it is a way that people promote themselves through society.

There have been times when companies have pirated staff from academia and the public sector. I have heard complaints over the years where people say, `We have trained these people in academia or the public sector, and someone comes along and pinches them'. That will not be stopped. That is why I said we have this mad, chattering class that convinced this government to go down the track of imposing a penalty and forcing employers to train people when they do not need to do so.

When we talk about employment, we must acknowledge that the problem has always been the availability of people prepared to work in certain sectors of the economy. That happens even today for reasons which predominantly relate to the welfare system. What the training levy has done is to build up a whole new industry of so-called experts who are earning a living at the expense of the wealth creating sector and who spend the money, whether they need to or not, rather than hand it over to the government.

I was unwittingly involved in this a few years ago—and I see Senator McMullan looking with raised eyebrows; he may have even done it too—when I was asked to give talks at these training programs. Professional people who are involved in training and who have developed it into an industry, get you to go along there. They do not care whether 20, 30 or a 100 people turn up, because they charge a fairly hefty fee. In some instances I suspect a lot of people register for those courses and do not turn up, but have fulfilled their obligation under the training guarantee levy.

They have a piece of paper with a receipt attached to it. Senator Bell is nodding; he has seen it; he may well have given a speech, too, and not been paid for it. That is what is going on. When there is bad legislation such as this it is inevitable that this sort of thing will happen. Senator Carr talked earlier about people abusing the system. Of course they will abuse the system. The worse the legislation the more the system will be abused.

There are those who prefer to hand the equivalent of the training levy over to educational institutions rather than engage in silly but acceptable programs which only serve to reduce the productivity of the companies themselves. Senator Bell mentioned that of 70,000 people in the small business sector who are required to participate in the training guarantee levy, 500 pay the fine—which it is—to the government. He was surprised the figure was that high. I am also surprised it is that high because any accountant would normally advise those people on ways to get around it. I say that quite deservedly: ways to get around it. They do not want to do it but here we have this heavy hand of government that says they must spend 1 1/2 per cent or whatever it is of their total payroll on training people whether they need to train them or not. If there is anything more stupid than that, I would like to know what it is.

One of the problems in this place is that people tend to keep myths alive and the great myth is that these things are all very good and they are doing great things for the country. But there are others, and we have all seen them—we should not pretend that we have not—who spend their money and enjoy themselves at the same time. This applies not just to the private sector but to the public sector as well.

This is very good for the tourist industry and the tourist resorts. I know of one group which went to a resort under an acceptable program to be lectured on stress. No-one took it seriously, including the lecturer. They had a hell of a good weekend. They had a few good barbecues, they played a bit of golf and they were lectured on stress. No-one took it seriously except one person. He decided that he had never been stressed before but he was now, having listened to the lecture, and he insisted on taking a 10-minute walk every hour to relieve that stress when he got back to work. This put the company itself under stress because it had to work out ways and means to get rid of that fellow.

I have no doubt that the vocal minority—the chattering classes, according to ex-Senator Walsh—will scream. They will say that this is not the intent and that people are abusing the system. As I pointed out earlier, it is not the system that people are abusing; it is the system that is abusing them. Hence they are going down this track.

It is about time, when people run a program like this and realise it is a very silly program, to have some commonsense and say, `Look, we tried it out. It was some academic who talked us into it. Let's get rid of it.' As an observation about stress, may I say that in the whole of my working life I have never seen a genuinely busy person suffer from stress—never. I have seen a lot of idle people pretending they were busy suffering from great stress. The most stressful thing to do to people to really stress them out is put them in a room with nothing to do. That was the torture used in the past—people were locked up in rooms with nothing to do and eventually they became mental.

What surprises me about this Senate Standing Committee report on Employment, Education and Training is that notwithstanding the evidence given and presented by the majority in the report, it said, `Let us support the amendments'. Senator Bell has said there is no doubt the amendments do improve the bill. However, the point I want to make is that the act itself should be abolished. I will quote some of the information provided by the standing committee because I think it is important. Evidence given by Charles Sturt University, where a survey was carried out, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A large majority of firms in the survey were of the view if the TGA was abolished this would have no impact on the amount of training conducted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you expect them to say? Whatever the truth is, what would you expect them to say? Come on, be serious.

—I am interested in that interjection from Senator McMullan asking what did I expect the report to say. Here is a university conducting a survey which says that the firms surveyed were of the view that the TGA would have no impact. When he makes that interjection he is reflecting on the firms themselves. That is the whole problem with this Labor government, the attitude of the opposition and the difficulties we are having in the economy. A group of business people—the wealth creators in Australia—who employ the people, the 800,000 small business people Senator Bell referred to, have an opinion and Senator McMullan interjects and says, `What would you expect them to say'?

PARA.TAB: Those people are interested in promoting their businesses; those people are interested in creating wealth; and those people are interested in employing people. We have one million people out of work, not helped by these crazy schemes introduced by this government to impose penalties and conditions that detract from the requirement to employ more people. In fact, if we were to talk to these small business people today they would say that what is wrong with this country is that we have a whole series of things that are a disincentive to employ people. It is not just the training guarantee levy. If it were, we would not have the problem. We have a range of these things.

We have incredible redundancy payments that have to be made. The crazy thing about that is that when a company gets itself into bother and needs to lay off people, that is when it has financial difficulties. So there is a disincentive to employ people on a full-time basis. What this country needs today is incentives to employ people on a full-time basis. Yet the whole thrust of all these policies is to say, `Let's not put them on a full-time basis, let's employ as many as we can as casuals'.

Against that—and I see Senator Burns opposite—are the unions trying to push businesses into employing people on a full-time basis. I do not disagree with that but we cannot push against the tide. If all the government policies—and we have got stacks of them—are to have a climate where there is a disincentive to employ people full time, it does not matter what happens on the side of the unions, people are going to get nowhere. Once the government goes down this track, as it has done on its industrial relations bill as well, there is a disincentive for employers to put people on full time.

Another remark struck me in the report put out by the majority committee. As I said, with all the evidence, it should have said, `Let's abandon this silly stuff', but instead it said, `Let's support the amendments.' It said that Professor Jim Gaite and Ms Karen Beresford of the University of South Australia reported to the committee on their research into the training needs of small business. It is important to reflect on this because the general view on all sides is that small business is the creator of employment in this country. Their research indicated that small business expenditure on training had been little affected by the training guarantee; it provides little incentive for small business to engage more fully in training activity; and the administration and record keeping required was disproportionately burdensome.

They indicated their personal view that despite the considerable changes in the attitude of Australian firms towards training, they still require further prodding. I do not know what they mean by that but if we want this country to be able to get off its backside and employ some of those one million out of work that were caused by the recession we had to have, according to Paul Keating, there is only one way to do that and that is to get off the back of business and to get rid of those disincentives.

One of those disincentives, no doubt, for those who are involved in training is this training guarantee levy. It has been tried and found wanting. It is a pain in the neck to business. It does not increase one iota the real training that goes on to increase productivity, wealth or the level of employment, which we so desperately need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was quite interested to hear some of the comments made by Senator Parer. The first question I would ask if I were looking dispassionately at the legislation would be, `Why have the legislation?'. The answer is very simple. The legislation is there because many people fail to accept their responsibility to train people in the community and do their share for the industries in which they have invested.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer said that this legislation is a disincentive for people to employ. I suggest that it is a disincentive for people to exploit. He also made the point that the unions are pushing for full-time employment. Why would they not? Given other factors being reasonable, full-time employment enables people to have a decent standard of living. If people have part-time casual or part-time permanent work, there is a reduction in their earnings and, therefore, a reduction in their living standards.

I do not believe that unions which are practical in their approach—that would be most unions—do not recognise that already there are many areas where there is a sharing of jobs and some part-time work. The job might be shared by two people—and it suits those people. For that reason, if the union is going to conduct itself in a way that does a job for its members, it should accept that that is a reasonable proposition and address itself only to seeing that decent wages and conditions are paid in that regard.

During my 20 years as a trade union official I met many company managers who have a very good management approach. They know, and have known for many years, what the whole of society has now come to accept—that there is a need for a well-trained and highly-trained work force. They have been contributing to that objective for many years and have been carrying out training in accordance with what is a reasonable proposition and in the interests of their companies.

There have been those who have refused to put any money into training on the basis that at a given time if they need someone to fill a position they offer a few extra dollars and attract those who have been well trained by other employers. It is for that reason that the legislation was necessary—to ensure that these people, who really do not accept their responsibility not only to the industry and to the people who work for them but also to society in general—and who do no training at all—do some training.

It is only recently that unions have looked at multiskilling, embraced it and been cooperative in regard to it. Of course, that is a question of horizontal skilling rather than vertical skilling. Vertical skilling is also a consideration.In the metal industry, for instance, the unions have been very supportive of this proposition. The employers have recognised that it is very helpful and gives them a more skilled and flexible work force. But many of the metal unions are saying that when these people are trained, either academically or properly at the workface, they should get recognition for it. They should get a certificate which indicates what their skills level is and the experience that they have had.

Even though one would think that many employers would believe Father Christmas had arrived if they got multiskilling, flexibility and cooperation, they are resisting the idea of giving recognition to people who have those skills levels and experience. This is another twist in the issue of people failing to pick up their responsibility in terms of training and skilling.

Senator Parer and others have talked about the fact that there will always be transfers of staff. I have no problem with that, and neither does the trade union movement. If two companies which are good trainers find that an employee of one or the other is attractive to them and are prepared to offer that person employment, that is a good thing; there is no problem. It is when those who will not train seek to take the benefit of those who have trained that I have an objection.

Senator Parer also said that there is an abuse of the system. He talked about funny systems where some companies have decided that rather than allowing the money to go to the government they will put on special trips and special supposed training exercises which are not training and really are just a waste of money.

We are seeking to make the legislation more flexible and easier to work with. It provides an opportunity and some compulsion for employers to train people properly, which, as I said, and I repeat, is something that is accepted in the community because of the need for a well-trained work force. Some people have always been involved in training and see it as a reasonable, proper approach which is absolutely instrumental in increasing productivity in terms of quality and delivery of goods. All these things are so important in getting contracts and having them continue. They are all the things that we look at in this regard. We provide the opportunity for people to abide by the legislation. As I said, those who provide training do not have a problem. They already spend the money wisely and sensibly, so there is nothing in addition for them to do.

It is not the fault of the legislation that there are those who do not wish to spend the money and who want only to abuse the system and waste money. I would be absolutely amazed if any employer of any significance could say with honesty that his or her work force did not require training. It is true that there may be odd exceptions where people have been in a job for many years and there is no turnover in staff; but even then there are new things coming up all the time—and training is a useful process. There is no fault in the desire of the government to seek proper and well-trained people in the community, as I said, and thus increase productivity and make society a better place to live in. The fault is with the people who create the abuses. I suggest those on the other side of the chamber address that issue and support the proposition put forward by the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are really two issues before us in the second reading debate and they will come up for consideration in detail in the committee stage. One is whether the legislation should continue and the other is the form in which it should continue if the sunset clause proposal is defeated. There is no contention about the desirability of the general thrust of these amendments if the legislation continues, as, of course, the government is advocating.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with those issues in sequence, but not at great length because, as I have said, the committee stage will give us a chance to do that. The worst thing would be to unduly take the time of the Senate to rehearse a debate that properly will be conducted in the committee stage. But I think they are both second reading matters. They have been addressed at length by participants in the second reading debate. I will not deal with them in the same length, but they certainly warrant response.

Firstly, I will address the overall question as to whether Australia should ever have had training guarantee levy legislation and whether the training guarantee has in fact played a socially useful role. First and foremost there has been no doubt that the training guarantee legislation has been part of that body of changes taking place in Australia over recent years which has fundamentally lifted the profile and focus of training. No change takes place in isolation. There are a whole range of changes taking place in our society. There is a fundamental change in the education and training of young Australians, most notably illustrated by the doubling during the last decade of the number of young Australians going on to year 12.

A lot of changes are taking place. At the same time, we cannot isolate one and say how we can study it totally in isolation. But there is no doubt in my mind, as a consequence of the discussions I have had over the years on the operation of this legislation, that all those people, other than the most hidebound ideological critics—we have heard some of them in this debate—believe that this training guarantee has been part of the process of lifting the profile of and focus on training in Australia. At the initiation of this measure it was fundamental that that profile be lifted. It remains important that Australia continue to have an active training program within our enterprises as well as within our training institutions.

It is important to recognise that there is not a debate about whether training is important; I will not rehearse that. We all agree that is critical to enhancing Australian efficiency and competitiveness as the world economy becomes more open, and a crucial element of competitiveness is the skill level of the work force.

Senator Burns was right to make the point that some people were unreasonably taking advantage of the responsible employers by failing to discharge their training obligation. That is a burden on the most efficient employers. What we had, until this training guarantee emphasis, was that the businesses which were most responsible, either nationally or in their own long-term self-interest, were being imposed upon by a sort of privately imposed tax by the businesses that were not training. They were inflating the training cost of the good businesses by poaching the trained staff. This is a measure about training, encouraging and assisting the responsible employers. In my view, that is the reason why we should not be voting for this sunset clause legislation. Other than those senators who adopt a blinkered approach—and there are some in this place—it seems a bit odd to be advocating that in advance of the evaluation of the scheme that is under way.

Then we get to the amendments about which I wish to say two things. They are not about a fundamental clash of principle between government and opposition, because we are all saying that there should be enhancement of the grouping provisions and that there should be some carry forward provisions. It is a question of how wide, how long and whether those two can interrelate. That is putting aside the third amendment, which is the one that goes to the continuing operation of the bill. We have a fundamental disagreement about that amendment, but as to the other two we do not.

We have the ironic situation that people come in here saying that this legislation is too complex and they then propose amendments that seek to make it more complicated. They cannot have it both ways. The fundamental reason that the government does not agree with these amendments should appeal to opposition senators because the problem is they impose more complexity than they add benefit. It is not that they are inherently bad ideas but that on a cost benefit basis they impose more complexity than they add benefit. We think that should not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of choice.

—But it makes the legislation more complex. People come into this place—Senator Watson does it all the time—and say that more and more the government is driving people to require the assistance of consultants, et cetera, because legislation is unduly complex. Opposition senators are now making it more complex and I do not think they should do so.

PARA.TAB: If the Senate insists upon passing these amendments, the government will seek to clean up the drafting defects in them and make them workable through the House of Representatives because we want to get the essence of the reforms passed. I do not want to elevate this, as opposition senators do, to a conflict of principle. They should not seek to do that because, for a small potential benefit, they are adding a substantial extra complexity to the legislation, which entirely cuts across the whole thrust of what we are trying to do in the amendments and what opposition senators have been saying is their concern with the underlying act. There are also those who have profound ideological objections to people having to provide training.

I ask those who feel there might be some merit in the proposal but who insist the bill is too complicated not to make the matter even more complicated. I thank the Senate for supporting the essence of the legislation. I urge the legislation as speedy a passage as we can combine to provide.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 6, page 4, omit paragraph (d).
(7)Clause 8, page 6, omit proposed subsections 15C(6) and (7)."
(8)Clause 16, page 8, proposed subsection 42A(1), line 31, omit "or (6)."

In proposing these amendments our intention is to make this bill even more flexible for business. We wish to make it more possible to allow the training guarantee arrangements to be averaged over a group of businesses, wider than is envisaged by the current bill. That is the outcome if the Senate supports these three amendments.

PARA.TAB: We believe that if there is a group of businesses that are linked together under company law in the same way that they can, in other elements of their companies' operations, link their operations, there may be a choice for that group of businesses to have training schemes in common or to monitor and account for their training programs and their spending on training across a group instead of by individual businesses.

The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) has put up only one objection to this. He has taken up the quite legitimate argument that Senator Watson puts from time to time that we have very wordy tax legislation and often equally wordy amending bills which make life complex for people who have to operate the tax law. In this instance I believe that is an Aunt Sally; it is not an appropriate analogy to be used as relating to this legislation.

I put it to the committee, absolutely manifestly, this bill that is before us comprises 10 pages. With all the amendments that I am proposing on behalf of the opposition, it will still comprise 10 pages. There will be fewer words if these amendments are carried. There is not the kind of complexity that Senator Watson rightly refers to—and which the minister rightly acknowledges and refers to—with regard to some of the tax matters that we consider.

I note that in the second reading speech by the minister in the other place, and in the speech in this place, there was reference to `avoiding complications'. The minister repeated this phrase in his summing up. I reject that argument. I call upon Senator Bell and the Independent senators to see the merit of choice, the merit of allowing Australian business what it wants, and of allowing averaging of the operation of this legislation over a group of businesses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not reiterate the points I made in summing up the second reading stage. I will refer only to those things which add detail to the points which I made by way of general response in summing up the second reading stage.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague has accurately described the purpose of these amendments. It is pointless to reiterate that. They seek to allow access to grouping and carry-forward provisions at the same time. What they do not do is deal with the issues of who owns the excess and who has responsibility for the shortfalls as one allows the interaction between the grouping provisions and the carry-forward provisions.

Each provision has merit and is being supported by everybody here, but they do not go to the issue: if one makes a choice, who owns the excess payment? Which part of the group or who is responsible for the shortfall? I am not saying that it is impossible to draft amendments that do that, but that is where the complication arises. It does not arise from what Senator Teague has done, but from what we will have to do to make his provision work.

If the committee decides to support this, as I say, we are not going to take our bat and ball and go home. We will seek to give effect in the House of Representatives to the Senate's intention by redrafting the amendments, sending them back to the Senate, and having the same purpose with better drafting, but it will make it more complicated.

The reason we did not do this was not because we did not think of it or that it was a heinous principle, but that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel advised that a legislative scheme which provided access to both the grouping and carry-forward provisions and dealt adequately with the ownership and responsibility issues would be excessively complex; that is, the benefit that would flow would not justify the added complication. Therefore, we do not think it should be done. We will come back with that complex option if we are required to do so, but I urge the committee not to require us to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the groups of amendments proposed by the coalition, I think it would expedite matters if I addressed both groups—amendments 1, 7 and 8, and 2 to 6 and 9—proposed by Senator Teague. I indicate the Democrats will support both of those groups but will reject proposed amendments 10 and 11. The reasons for that are that, in seeking to make the best of the legislation that we have here, it is quite evident that what we are really about is making more flexible the provisions that apply to enterprises; to allow the decisions about training to be taken at an enterprise level in a way that is as flexible as possible to accommodate the variety of training needs that exist in industry.

PARA.TAB: Training needs should be emphasised. Training should be allocated, to borrow a phrase from another place, according to need. That is not an expression that was invented just recently. In fact, it is part of the well-established theory of human resource management that good human resource management practices take place after a training needs analysis has been instituted at the enterprise level. The enterprise should then be able to conduct its training according to that training needs analysis rather than other constraints.

Some of the constraints that have been applied to enterprises have been applied by the timetable and the regulations which attach to the training guarantee scheme. In reducing the rigidity of that scheme and allowing greater flexibility, we come closer to the opportunity for human resource management divisions of enterprise to be able to provide training according to the training needs analysis rather than artificial constraints provided by legislation.

That is why we support the first two components of the coalition's proposed amendments. I understand what Senator McMullan is saying about the fact that, with regard to compliance with the legislation, complications will be added to the legislation, but I honestly believe that complying with the training needs analyses of their enterprises will become easier at the enterprise end. So it may be a bit harder for us but a lot easier for industry.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 8, page 5, proposed subsection 15B(1), line 7, omit "until the next year", substitute "for a designated period of years not exceeding a further two years".
(3)Clause 8, page 5, proposed section 15B(4), line 16, add at the end "following the period designated in subsection (1)".
(4)Clause 8, page 5, proposed section 15C(2), line 21, omit "the next year", substitute "a year in a period of years designated in subsection 15B(1)".
(5)Clause 8, page 5, proposed section 15C(3), line 27, omit "the next year" substitute "a year in a period of years designated in subsection 15B(1)."
(6)Clause 8, page 5, proposed section 15C(4), line lines 37 and 38, omit "the next year" and substitute "a year in a period of years designated in subsection 15B(1)".
(9)Clause 16, page 9, proposed subparagraph 42A(2)(d)(ii), lines 6 and 7, omit "the next year", substitute "a year in a period of years designated in subsection 15B(1)".

I thank Senator Bell for his comments and analysis. He has foreshadowed the argument I now put in favour of these amendments. I certainly thank him for the carefulness with which this has been considered by him and his colleagues. This decision means that the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats are responding to Australian business and industry and ensuring they have the kind of flexibility that will make for better training, for better outcomes for personnel, in our view.

PARA.TAB: I also note Senator McMullan's acknowledgment that this is a matter of judgment. I certainly welcome the cooperation foreshadowed by him in terms of making sure this legislation is in a form which will work according to the principles of this debate. In due course it will be very straightforward for us—probably a matter of minutes—having checked any rewording that might be considered by the government in the House of Representatives, to then conclude the matter. I gave these amendments to the minister's representative with a view to any such suggestion being made during this consideration, but I am quite happy for the matter to be dealt with as the minister foreshadowed.

The reason that the committee should support this second group of amendments is that, in this matter of judgment as to the length of time that is beneficial for averaging, we believe there ought to be a carry over into one more year than that which is envisaged in this bill—that is, an averaging over a three-year period effectively rather than the two that the government has acknowledged. It is our view that in this matter of a judgment being made this is a better outcome. I am very glad to see there is majority support for that in the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I can count; therefore I will not waste the time of the chamber. I do have an obligation to put on the record the details of my concern which will be reflected in the activities that the minister responsible will have to take when this bill goes back to the house and will be reflected in what comes back here, but I will be as brief as I can be.

PARA.TAB: I am told—and I have not dealt with it with sufficient detail myself to be able to go beyond this general comment—that, for example, the proposed change to subsection 15B(4) is seriously deficient and will not achieve Senator Teague's purpose at all. I could go into that in a bit more detail; I simply flag that as an area where we are going to have a problem. There also appears to be a problem where the proposals cover only the carry forward of shortfall. Of course, one would also have to be able to deal with extending the carry forward of excess expenditure.

So there are a few of those problems that we will have to deal with. We are concerned again that the additional complexity required to extend the carry forward provisions by an extra year is way out of proportion to the benefits that come from it, but I have exhausted my persuasive power and Senator Bell has indicated it was not sufficient so I will not try it any further. I think it is important that the committee says that on the record. I will get these amendments out of the way and then we will have what I think will be a slightly more substantial debate on the next ones.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10)After clause 18, page 9, insert the following new clause:
"18A.After section 101A of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Act to cease to have effect from 1 July 1994

SPEECH.PARA: `101B.Unless repealed earlier, this Act ceases to have effect on and from 1 July 1994.'.".
(11)Clause 19, page 9, line 39, omit "The", substitute "Subject to section 18A, the".

This is closest to the concerns of the Liberal and National parties. It appears that unless I can be enormously persuasive in these next two minutes there will not be a majority for these amendments. I will not concede that until we hear the voices, but I will put my arguments to honourable senators again, as I did in my speech on the second reading debate. I am not going to go over my speech on the second reading debate but merely point out that this is a flawed bill. It must be suspended. It needs to cease its operations and we will see better training outcomes as a result.

PARA.TAB: I refer only by listing: to the task force on regional development, chaired by Mr Kelty, which has asked that it be suspended; to the Industry Commission which sees it as a blunt instrument, mostly ineffective; and to the particular study of Professor Charles Noble—and I noted Senator Carr's remarks that he had only had a limited area of study. I do not fully accept that. There will always be limitations when there are surveys but I nevertheless list the arguments that he has put at large and to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I will continue the listing: to Professor Gaite, also referred to by Senator Carr, and Ms Karen Beresford; to the study at Monash University by Tim Henson; to the condemning of this whole measure by the Business Council of Australia; and to the call by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry for the scrapping of this legislation. Other senators have referred to others that have made similar assessments.

It has been our view from the beginning that this is flawed legislation. It is a firm promise of the Liberal and National parties that this would be one of the imposts on business and industry that we in the coalition would remove as soon as we had the opportunity to do so. Accordingly, the amendments that are now before us, Nos 10 and 11, would see this whole piece of legislation ceasing on the first day of July of this year which is the fourth anniversary of the operation of the act.

I finally put it to Senator Bell to get on with this action now where he can take the initiative. I say this through you, Mr Deputy Chairman: be a part of the action that is successful now, before this government does the same thing in the May budget. The honourable senators opposite are aware of the arguments such as those to which I referred in my speech in the second reading debate and which I have listed just now. With the exception of some people, such as Senator Carr and Senator Burns, who do not seem to be convinced yet, it may well be that there is a majority in caucus, certainly a majority in the budget cabinet of this government, who want to see measures that are responsive to the requests of business and industry, and to see the end of this legislation. Then training can be built in with other incentives and be more effective for the kinds of outcomes in training that will make Australia all that much more internationally competitive. I therefore make this final appeal to the Democrats and to other honourable senators that they join with the coalition in voting for these final two amendments in order to get ahead of the government's budget, when it is likely to also abolish this whole scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government senators are opposing this proposition, essentially because it fails to recognise that there is currently a major review under way into the training guarantee proposals and legislation. The review will provide us with information necessary to judge the cost effectiveness of these measures and to evaluate the measures that encourage the growth of training and a training culture. The real issue, however, is not assessment of the cost evaluation; it is a philosophical difference that relates to the way in which we see the world, the way in which we believe the government should be encouraging changes in behaviour by employers, and the employers' obligations to this country and to their work force.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague quotes at length the Noble study and a number of others. Perhaps I should remind the Senate that the Noble study itself is fundamentally flawed. It was limited to 79 companies in the Albury-Wodonga area. It had a response rate of only 55 per cent, so fewer than 45 companies responded. What the honourable senator is regurgitating is essentially prejudice. He is regurgitating a philosophical view that government should get out; he is trying to give aid and comfort, in effect, to people who wish to bludge on other employers who are doing the right thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Survey conclusions are not made invalid by—

—The survey conclusions, I would put to Senator Teague, essentially reflect prejudice. As Professor Gaite also indicated, they will not necessarily reflect his assessment of what was actually happening with his report, but an attitude that is being expressed by some small-minded, narrow-minded, ignorant people about the way in which they should conduct their business affairs. Of course, it is understandable that some people will want to bludge on others. It is understandable that in business people seek to take advantage of their competitors. That is not necessarily a correct approach that should be taken.

PARA.TAB: It has been indicated that lots of rorts are going on in this area. Mr Flood has appeared before the Senate committee. He is the officer from the Australian Taxation Office responsible for compliance management. He indicated that, in his experience, in the experience of the Australian Taxation Office, for some 20 years businessmen have been taking trips to various things and a prime aim was to get a tax deduction. In relation to the training guarantee, our experience has been that not a lot of that sort of thing has been claimed for the training guarantee. Certainly, newspapers tend to think that everybody who goes on an overseas trip or somewhere is doing it for the purposes of the training guarantee with training funds.

However, this is not what we have found with our audit program. We have been asked for a full substantiation of nearly 1,000 cases. In only about 60 of those cases have attempts been made to claim what we might call `junket conferences'—only 60. Now we are talking here about measures that apply to companies with payrolls of more than $220,000. We are talking about perhaps 70,000 companies that are actually able to be covered by this particular measure. Under the Taxation Office's own estimates, its audit programs, we find 60 that are ripping off the scheme. So it is totally inappropriate to suggest that this scheme is invalid, and an attempt to de-legitimise it on the basis of rorts is a pretty cheap shot. To try to illegitimise the scheme, based on the actions of a few people, is not an appropriate political strategy, I suggest, if people really do have the interests of this country at heart, and if they really do have an interest in making sure we have a flexible and highly trained work force.

For working people the question of training is vital: workers have a right to proper training. They have a right to ensure that they have the capacity to move from one industry to another, from one employer to another. The whole issue of occupational health and safety clearly demonstrates that, if people have to rely on the market, they will fail.

I am looking forward to this review. I believe it is an opportunity to assess the progress of this particular training guarantee proposal. I hope that employers do pay greater attention to occupational health and safety. If employers will not do it, then the government has a responsibility to make sure that they do it in the future. The future of our country and the future of workers is at stake with this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not think the legislation is perfect. Indeed, we have introduced some changes that we recognise will make it better; even the opposition recognises that the legislation will continue. The opposition has offered up amendments which have been carried. I am not surprised that that list of objectors to the legislation was quoted and, of course, those objectors have not changed over the years.
—Including Mr Kelty; listen to Mr Kelty.

—I would suggest that Mr Kelty is not the only person who has wisdom in the trade union movement. He is not always right. A lot of the reports from the Industry Commission are pretty blunt instruments too. There are employers who say, `We do not need this legislation. This is not good legislation'. I can recall a meeting with BHP representatives some four or five years ago where they openly admitted that the company used to tell workers to leave their brains at the gate. Now BHP says that the workers are an asset, not a liability, and that training is an important part of sharpening them up and making them an even greater asset.

PARA.TAB: Employers are talking about self-regulation: they want to take care of the training themselves. I can tell the chamber that they have not taken care of it very well for the last 100 years. I do not think we can trust them now anymore than we could a few years ago. I believe the legislation needs to continue in the interests of this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague provided us with the temptation to join him in supporting these amendments. I think it was the wrong temptation. The Australian Democrats will not be motivated just to get ahead of the government. If the government is planning to scrap this scheme in the budget, so be it. Let us see its reasons for doing that. I do not think it is appropriate to be rushed into a decision here today, just on that basis of scoring first. It is not our motivation and I will deal with what our motivation is with this legislation shortly.

PARA.TAB: Before I do that, Senator Carr rightly pointed out that this scheme is in the middle of a review, and I referred to that in the debate on the second reading. The Democrats are concerned that the scheme be turned into one that works properly. It may require a complete transmogrification of the scheme and I think that is fairly likely.
