It seems to me that the scheme is rightly criticised for a number of failings.

I share with Senator Carr the concern that all enterprises be made safe. This scheme does not guarantee that. It does not guarantee that 1c is spent on occupational health and safety training measures. Whether the scheme should guarantee that is another question. I do not think it should be supported just because it might. We should be looking for a scheme that does guarantee, to the best of its ability, that enterprises engage in proper training in the health and safety of workers. Also, a proper scheme would reduce the incidence of poaching.

Just a few minutes ago, Senator Carr referred to the bludgers of industry, who do not do any training themselves but pick up well-trained workers from other places. This scheme does not stop that. It should. We hope that a review of this scheme will organise things so that it tends to stop that. We can never stop it entirely. If that was ever its aim, this scheme has failed. The Democrats would be looking for a scheme which would reduce the administrative burden of employing people rather than add to it. This scheme has failed to do that. I hope that the Department of Employment, Education and Training, in its review, manages to find a way of reducing the administrative burden. It is not impossible. The review is looking at a darned sight more than 45 enterprises in one particular area. I understand that several thousand interviews are being conducted.

TAB.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak today on a matter of great importance to me and to all Western Australians, and that is the matter of fire safety in Western Australia. There is a growing concern in the community about the protection of Western Australian citizens from the ravages of fire and the protection offered to professional and volunteer firefighters in Western Australia as a result of a proposal put by the Western Australian Fire Brigade board to reduce services and to reduce staffing currently provided for fire protection in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have a particular interest in this matter, being a former official of the firefighters union of Western Australia. I am still an honorary member of that union, a position I am very proud of. My concern today arises from the success of that union in achieving appropriate salary levels for professional firefighters in Western Australia in a recent decision of the Western Australian Industrial Commission. In that decision the full bench of the commission awarded significant pay increases to professional firefighters, to be phased in over the next year or so. That was the umpire's verdict after a very long wage contest between the brigade and the union, spanning more than three years. The dispute was eventually brought to arbitration because of the failure to achieve a conciliated result.

Unfortunately, the cause of my concern is that the Western Australian Fire Brigade board's response to that decision of the industrial commission has been to look at the financial impact of that decision on the board and attempt to reduce its fire services to accommodate increased costs to its budget. I am the first to admit that the cost of wages is a large proportion of the Western Australian Fire Brigade board's budget and is the most significant expenditure item. I am happy to concede that the wage decision represents a major impost on the board.

Unfortunately, as often happens in such matters, the board has taken it upon itself to see the answer in reducing fire services and protection to the Western Australian community rather than in attempting to convince government that appropriate funding ought to be made available to continue the established service and protection levels that are required in Western Australia. I think it is very worrying and an indictment of the Western Australian Fire Brigade board that it seems to have adopted a position of reducing services and reducing the community protection level that it established.

The board has recommended a proposal which seeks to reduce crewing on certain appliances, particularly at certain country fire stations—which I am sure is of concern to Senator Panizza—and also to take appliances off line. The phrase `on line' refers to appliances being staffed and available on call to fight fires and other emergencies within the metropolitan area. The proposal would have the impact of reducing the brigade's expenditure by reducing the number of firefighters employed in fire protection at any one time.

Those people in the Western Australian community who understand these issues are greatly concerned about this reduction in fire protection levels. It is always difficult to determine what is the appropriate amount of protection. Obviously services cannot always meet all the demands that are placed upon them. Nevertheless, Western Australia currently has an approved level of service and fire protection to meet the minimum requirements established under professional firefighting guidelines. The proposals that the fire board has put forward seek to reduce that level of protection, and to put at risk the Western Australian community and its firefighters. I think it is of grave concern to the whole Western Australian community.

There are two things that the board is proposing that are most likely to have an immediate effect. The first is the abandonment of safety crewing. The safety crewing concept is internationally recognised as the minimum desirable crew required to attend on a first appliance at an emergency. Safety crewing requires that the first firefighting appliance has to have a crew of four firefighters. This is based on the requirements for wearing breathing apparatus and safe firefighting techniques. The four firefighters are required so that two firefighters can enter the burning premises, search for people trapped inside and deal with the fire. The other two firefighters stay outside to provide assistance and backup for the two inside.

Safety crewing is a very well-established, international safety requirement of firefighting. To its credit, the fire brigade board has argued for and struggled for years to implement safety crewing in Western Australia. Approximately four years ago, we were successful in achieving the establishment of a safety crewing program to ensure that all first-attending appliances in Western Australia were safety crewed. However, this proposal by the board will reduce safety crewing. It will mean that, in a number of centres, fewer than the minimum of four firefighters will be on those first-responding appliances. The regional centres of Geraldton, Bunbury and Albany are of particular concern. These centres are a long way from the metropolitan area and a long way from professional backup.

In the case of Geraldton and Albany, if there were a major fire or a major incident in one of these centres, backup from other professional services would be over four hours away, which is a long time. It would be almost impossible to provide adequate support for the firefighters and for the community. Local volunteer brigades provide enormous service as backup to the professional brigades in those regions, but their equipment is limited. I would be the first to say that they are inadequately serviced, in terms of equipment, training and other needs.

Therefore, the reality is that those centres are extremely isolated in terms of professional backup for first-attending appliances. The board's decision will mean that the lives of firefighters in those regional centres will be put at risk. Make no mistake about that. It is also putting at risk the lives of the volunteer firefighters who back up the professional firefighters. The board's proposal has this fundamental problem. It is a problem that will come back to haunt the government, unless something is done about it.

The second area of concern is the board's suggested decommissioning of second-line appliances at a number of key metropolitan stations. It is a fact that second-line appliances are generally located in the vicinity of Perth's major hospitals. They are located there because of the established higher risk involved in firefighting in those particular places. The station at Fremantle provides backup to the Fremantle Hospital—I do not mention that for any purpose relating to the by-election. The Daglish Fire Station, as Senator Panizza would well understand, provides an important backup service to Perth's major hospitals—the Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital, the King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women and the Hollywood Hospital, which is the old repatriation hospital.

Those stations are there for very good reasons: they are there to help protect lives in the case of a major incident at those hospitals. I think every senator would be aware that an incident at a hospital would be a particularly dangerous situation, given the number of persons who would be unable to get themselves out of the buildings. This proposal is a real threat to the protection offered to the Western Australian community and a real threat to the lives of Western Australian firefighters.

It may well be that this reflects the problem of the composition of fire brigade funding in Western Australia. Essentially, the funding of the fire brigade is made up of a 75 per cent contribution from insurance premiums and 12 1/2 per cent each from local government and state government authorities. The impact of that system of funding is that the Western Australian fire brigade board is dominated by the considerations of where the funds to meet the needs of the brigade are to be raised. A lot of the representatives on the Western Australian fire brigade board have a very keen eye to their own constituencies, be they the insurance companies or the local government authorities.

I do not deny or decry their very real problems in meeting brigade funding but I think it really is a reflection on the adequacy of the system. When it comes to the question of appropriate fire protection, it seems of more concern where the local government authorities or the insurance companies are going to be able to find the funding for the brigade, rather than the primary question of the proper protection to be offered to Western Australian society and the protection to be offered to firefighters. We really have to call upon the state government and call upon the Minister for Emergency Services, Mr Wiese, to put the protection of the community first and ensure that funding is made available to retain the existing fire protection standards established by the fire brigade board.

The level of concern that exists in the fire brigade about these proposals is reflected in the fact that the chief fire officer has written to the Minister for Emergency Services expressing his concern about the proposals. He does not support the proposed reduction in staffing and is fearful of the risks that it poses for the community and for firefighters. I think the views of the chief fire officer in Western Australia have to be given great credence and he has expressed serious concern about these propositions.

Honourable senators would be aware of the deaths that occurred in New South Wales during the recent bushfires and honourable senators from Queensland would be aware of the tragic loss of two professional firefighters in an incident in a fire in Queensland recently. It brings home to us the real dangers involved in firefighting, both for professional and for volunteer firefighters. Because of the extremely good safety record and professional standards set in Australia over the years, it is easy to forget the very real dangers faced by firefighters every day of their lives. It is easy to discount those dangers and the risks at which they put firefighters and the community in the event of fire or other emergencies.

I do not intend to make an outrageous, emotional plea in relation to this matter. I do not want to use the sort of terminology used by my friends opposite in relation to another matter—about people having blood on their hands—because I find that sort of rhetoric totally inappropriate. But—

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one wants to say that.

—If Senator Teague looks at the speeches of members of his party in the last couple of days regarding Carmen Lawrence he will see that sort of speech being made. It is an indictment of the Liberal Party. I think honourable senators opposite should dissociate themselves from those remarks. But I will come to that later today. What I am saying and what I am calling on the Western Australian government to do is to provide leadership to ensure the maintenance of professional fire prevention standards in Western Australia. The minister must act, not try to wash his hands of the issue or appear publicly to be supportive but not act. If the minister is not up to the job he ought to resign. The Western Australian government has an obligation to maintain proper fire protection standards for the community and to maintain the safety crewing standards for the firefighters involved. It will be on its members' conscience if it fails to ensure those standards are met.

PARA.TAB: I urge the Western Australian government to act before it is too late. Already, firefighters in the country centres in Western Australia have been put at risk. It really does require the government to act urgently. If the minister will not act, I call on Premier Richard Court to ensure that the government does ensure that the current protection standards and safety standards for firefighters in Western Australia are maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, in the debate on matters of public interest, I spoke about the dreadful loss of population from rural Australia, which concerns us all, and about the syndrome `get big or get out', which is certainly one of the factors in that loss of population. Today I would like to extend that debate and say that that same syndrome—get big or get out—is also part of the cause of the crippling debt facing many of our farm families.

PARA.TAB: Some years ago I attended a seminar in Roma in central Queensland on the future of the family farm. At that seminar one of the big debates was about this very issue, to get big or get out. The response of one of the farmers on that occasion was that farm families are often people with big hearts and big hats, but they are even bigger—expletive deleted—fools. `Get big or get out' is something that farmers have been hearing for 15 or 20 years; yet, having followed that advice, they find themselves in the same situation.

I have heard story after story of farmers, in response to that demand of them, buying adjoining properties in the early 1980s. At the time they often had little or no debt. By the late 1980s, having bought those properties, the same farmers faced ruin because of the unsustainable interest rates they endured during those years. The capital debt on some properties doubled in three years because of the incredibly high rates of interest.

Let me give just a few examples to underline what I am saying. The Balmoral branch of the Victorian Farmers Federation conducted a survey of woolgrowers in its area. The woolgrowers were asked a number of questions, including one about their perceived viability; in other words, whether they felt that in the long term they would be viable. Only 18 per cent thought they would be; 48.9 per cent thought they were borderline in terms of viability; and 33.1 per cent said that they could not be viable in the long term. In other words, an astounding 82 per cent of respondents considered their viability in 1993-94 as either borderline or not viable. However, they were asked this further question:

SPEECH.PARA: If interest rates on all rural borrowings were reduced to six per cent during the current commodity downturn, would you be viable?
If interest rates were reduced to that level, 79.7 per cent of respondents said that they could be viable, while 20.3 per cent still believed they would not be able to continue.

PARA.TAB: So an astounding 82 per cent of respondents considered their financial viability in 1993-94 as borderline or not viable at all but 79 per cent turned that around, in terms of a reduction in interest rates to six per cent. The Balmoral branch of the Victorian Farmers Federation concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: This provides an excellent case to the Federal Government to trigger the `exceptional circumstances' provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme.

My colleague Senator Lees also gave some figures last week in a speech on debt in South Australia, particularly for clients of the rural counselling service. The figures for January to June 1993 show that the total debt of those clients in South Australia was over $303 million. The average debt of those clients was $242,852.

PARA.TAB: I refer the Senate to the Queensland Country Life of 10 February, where the President of the Queensland Grain Growers Association, Ian Macfarlane, said this:
The rural debt situation is now so critical most farmers will need at least three above-average seasons and profitable crops in a row to restore their viability.
With an average farm debt around $250,000; four to nine crop failures in a row and borderline equity, many of the State's grain producers have to swallow their pride and seek more help.

SPEECH.PARA: I could perhaps give honourable senators an international perspective on this. A recent UNICEF report entitled The State of the World's Children 1992, Summary says this:

PARA.TAB: "But it is, above all, the weight of past debts which threaten future progress . . . the developing world owes approximately $1,300 billion to the governments and banks of the industrialized nations and to international financial institutions. Each year, the repayment of capital and interest amounts to approximately $150 billion—roughly three times as much as the developing world receives in aid. As it is impossible to meet these interest charges in full, the amount unpaid is added to the total debt owed . . . When all transactions are taken into account—the net effect is that the developing world is now transferring $40 to $50 billion a year to the industrialized world.

SPEECH.PARA: It further states, `Debt is the new slavery that has shackled the African continent'. The article goes on to speak about what is happening to people in the Third World. But my concern is that Australian farmers, Australian farm families and Australian farm children are in the same situation—or will be, if something is not done now. What is to be done, of course, is the obvious question.

PARA.TAB: In the first instance, I would like to recommend that the Senate heed the call of the Queensland Grain Growers Association president, Ian Macfarlane. Again, I read from an article in Queensland Country Life:

Mr Macfarlane is keen to clinch Commonwealth support for a Rural Adjustment Unit he hopes to set up jointly with governments, banks, financial advisers and rural organisations to tackle the debt crisis in the bush.

The RAU concept, which has the backing of the Queensland Farmers Federation, would be set up as a co-ordinated body for distributing drought aid and would have the specific brief of dealing with the thorny issue of rural debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Grain Grower, the in-house magazine, says of Mr Macfarlane:
He said such a package may also involve banks being prepared to write off some interest and rescheduled debts.
It further states:

PARA.TAB: Mr Macfarlane is keen to see governments, banks and rural organisations sit down and thrash out a debt reorganisation package that would enable government assistance to be maximised and amplified.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the government to take note of the very many voices which are calling for a tackling of this whole issue of rural debt—and not only for that, but for a tackling of the very thorny issue of debt reorganisation, even of debt write-off. I want to give a theological perspective on this and to point out that, for some 1,500 years, the church would not allow the charging of interest on loans; this was prohibited. It is only in the last couple of hundred years that the prohibition against what was called usury has been relaxed.

PARA.TAB: I underline that by saying that there has been an attempt by numbers of people within the Australian churches, and certainly in campaigns conducted by the World Council of Churches, to tackle the world-wide problem of debt, particularly its effect on Third World nations, especially those involved in growing food. Around the world, that is where debt is hitting the hardest. I refer the Senate to the Hebrew scriptures and to the model there, which is probably 3000 years old, of the jubilee and sabbatical years in which the call was for debts to be written off, slaves to be released and land to be returned to the families who originally owned that land. Those concepts need a lot of translation to be relevant to our situation today but, whatever the starting point, wherever we begin in order to tackle debt and interest rates, whatever analysis we use of the problem we face and whatever solution we propose, the issue of debt slavery must be tackled.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, following my statement on ministerial arrangements yesterday, I now draw the attention of honourable senators to the new ministry list which has been circulated. I inform the Senate that Senator Richardson is unwell and will be absent from question time today. Questions relating to the health portfolio should be addressed to Senator Crowley who also represents the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services. Questions relating to environment, sport and territories should be addressed to Senator Faulkner.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister. Now that the annual return for the year ended June 1993 has revealed that the Prime Minister's piggery holding company, Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, is technically insolvent with accumulated losses of $13 million and liabilities of $25 million exceeding assets by $6.5 million, is the Australian public entitled to know how and by whom their Prime Minister's massively indebted piggeries are being kept afloat? To whom is the Prime Minister indebted for his company's financial survival? Why has the Prime Minister's half-owned holding company Euphron Pty Ltd secretly borrowed $287,000 from a Danish company? What other financial obligations to foreigners do the Prime Minister's financially strapped half-owned companies have?

—Really, this prurient interest on the part of Senator Baume has to stop. It does not bear any resemblance or any relationship to a legitimate inquiry about possible conflicts of public duty and private interest. It is simply an exercise in prurient political interest. It is an exercise in fishing, trawling, poking and fingering here, there and everywhere in the hope that something will turn up. As I have said on innumerable occasions, nothing has turned up in all his fingering, poking, trawling, crawling and barrel-plunging over the last two years or however many months he has been doing it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume has drawn big, fat blanks every time he has embarked upon one of these expeditions. Whether it is in relation to FIRB, AQIS or inquiries about taxation benefits and so on, the honourable senator has been wrong, and I will remind him of his errors every time he asks questions of this particular kind.

The Prime Minister has declared his financial interest in that particular commercial enterprise. It is on the public record; there is no secret about it. Like any other commercial enterprise, it has its ups and its downs. It is well known as a matter of public record that there is quite a high level of indebtedness associated with the particular business and that its viability in the future may well depend upon its capacity to engage in a major expansion exercise of the kind that has been the subject of discussion with the New South Wales government in the context of environmental approvals and so on.

All that is a matter of public record, and all Senator Baume's fiddling, poking and crawling around in whatever gutter he thinks he can find in this particular area will not benefit him or the public interest in any way, shape or form. Beyond that, I am not going to enter into the details of these various transactions because, unless the honourable senator can demonstrate far more effectively and far more cogently than he has so far that there is any legitimate ground for public interest or public inquiry in these matters, he does not deserve an answer and he is not going to get one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I expect, as normal, to get personal abuse whenever I refer to ASC official documents outlining the facts. I repeat my question to the minister: to whom is the Prime Minister indebted for his company's financial survival? If the minister does not recognise that that creates a potential conflict of interest, he is an extraordinary man. What has he got to hide? I also asked about what financial obligations existed to other foreigners, including guarantees. I therefore ask the minister: what has happened to the $3 million guarantee that one of the Prime Minister's companies has from its Danish partners? I repeat the question because it is a matter of major moment in terms of potential conflict: to whom is the Prime Minister under an obligation in order to maintain his ailing piggery companies long before, I might add, there were financial obligations for expansion?

—I do not think I am or the Prime Minister is under any obligation whatsoever to go further in explaining the details of these kinds of issues in the absence of any credible basis for this question to be asked. Senator Michael Baume has personal financial interests all over the place. We do not know what they are because he has never put them on the public record because he and his party filibustered their way through every opportunity they have ever had over the last ten years to put these matters on the public record. Senator Baume thinks he can sit there with his record of failed financial transactions behind him, his record of business failures and his lack of credibility through his whole personal history in Patrick Partners and elsewhere, and divert attention from that by coming up with this sort of trawling rubbish. Well, he is not going to get an answer.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister clearly attempted to restrain himself but, of course, he could not and he descended to the usual personal abuse and questioning of the personal integrity of Senator Baume. I direct your attention to standing order 193(3), which says that personal reflections and imputations are highly disorderly. Not only should you direct the minister's attention to that, but also you should explain to the minister that there is a very real public interest in understanding whether there are conflicts of interest between the Prime Minister's private position—
—Order! You have made your point of order, Senator Alston.
—Sit down! It is not a point of order at all.

—Order! Senator Faulkner, I will determine whether it is a point of order. If I were to hold up debate or question time disallowing expressions of opinion such as Senator Gareth Evans has given, I would be ruling out of order most of the questions as well. It seems to me that there is nothing out of order in the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer the minister to reports of an explosion that ripped through the NCA offices in Adelaide. I ask the minister: can he advise the Senate of any details regarding this explosion at the office of the National Crime Authority? In particular, can he give us any information regarding the safety of staff members?

—At about 9.15 this morning an explosion occurred at the premises occupied by the NCA in Waymouth Street, Adelaide. At this stage it is understood that the bombing occurred when a parcel received at the authority's office exploded. The South Australian police service has instituted a major investigation into the incident. My most recent advice is that two people have been killed and four others injured as a result of the incident. I am not yet in a position to release the names of the victims of this attack. I am, however, advised that one of the deceased was a Western Australian police officer performing duties with the authority. The government extends its deepest sympathy and condolences to those injured and to the families of those others who lost their lives in the explosion.

PARA.TAB: Australia has been fortunate in the past not to have been the subject of such violence against our national law enforcement agencies. Violence of this kind is un-Australian, alien to our way of life and utterly to be condemned. I am sure members from both sides of the Senate share my horror and sadness at this incident.

This morning the Minister for Justice spoke to the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Tom Sherman, who assured him that security checks were being conducted on all NCA offices. He also spoke to the South Australian Minister for Emergency Services, who also assured him of the fullest cooperation of the South Australian police. Assistant Commissioner John Beck is in command of the investigation. I assure the Senate that the resolve of the NCA and the government to fight organised crime will not be affected by this incident. The government and, I am sure, the parliament will not be intimidated by this sort of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Defence. What studies have been done concerning the relocation of the fleet base from Garden Island to White Bay? What is the justification for this move? Does the minister agree that the magnitude of such a change would be about $3 billion with no increase in capabilities for the Australian Defence Force? Finally, since the correspondence between the minister and the Prime Minister is now a public document, will he formally table that in the Senate together with any other documentation he has on the move?

—It would probably take me more than four minutes to respond to some of the false information that was given in the 7.30 Report, but I will concentrate on Senator MacGibbon's direct question. He asked what plans have been made to move the fleet base from Garden Island to White Bay. The answer is none. I received on 31 July 1993 a letter from the Prime Minister that asked me to look at the feasibility of that. I subsequently met with the Prime Minister on 8 September to discuss that issue with him. We had a general discussion on whether there would be any possibility of this fitting in with the belief that the land around the fleet base—and especially on Garden Island—could be used for the purposes of recreation for the benefit of Sydney people. It was not as suggested in last night's report that we would put a large housing development on it. That discussion, I think I could summarise in relation to the Prime Minister and me, remained fairly inconclusive. I indicated to the Prime Minister after that discussion that I would come back at another time and discuss it with him.

PARA.TAB: At this stage there is no direction, as implied in the program last night. There was only a request from the Prime Minister to look at the feasibility of moving the fleet base. I gave no commitment to do so; I gave a commitment to look at it. Senator MacGibbon mentioned costs, which would be an absolutely critical factor. We would have to look at whether there is any benefit for the defence force. The area we concentrated on and which has had no publicity was ADI's plan to retract from Garden Island itself to the core business. Having probably visited the site, Senator MacGibbon would probably realise a large part of Garden Island is basically small workshops, tennis courts, residences et cetera. It may well be possible, if we want to add to the glamour of Sydney Harbour, for the ADI operations to retract back to their core business area around the dry dock and leave the rest for the Sydney public. Long term that is the feasible area we will be looking to.

To reiterate, in spite of what the program alleged last night, there has been no direction to me to move the fleet base; I was simply asked to look at its feasibility, with no commitment either from the Prime Minister or me that we would eventually do that. Further, I was more interested to look at the plans produced by ADI to retract from Garden Island. It would be a very expensive thing to move the fleet base. Put it this way, senator: if the Prime Minister wanted to move it and I did not want to move it we would see one of the great conundrums of life answered: what happens when an irresistible force hits an immovable object.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and reassurances. I recognise that the ADI commercial operation is one issue of some concern, but the Captain Cook graving dock is the largest in the southern hemisphere. It is a national asset, and the parliament would be very concerned if Australia lost that facility and it became a fish tank or something or other.

—As Senator MacGibbon would realise, the overall future of Garden Island is very much tied up with the two ocean policy, what the future of ADI is in terms of privatisation and whether in fact the naval engineering division would be privatised and, if so, who would buy it and what future it would be put to. I put to rest one thing: the implication in the program last night that there was going to be some enormous Luna Park, Disneyland or residential development that would crush all the heritage aspects is complete nonsense. No one has put that forward other than in one report which looked at many options to government which we have not yet accepted as advice.

PARA.TAB: The future and the value of the dockyard will depend on commercial considerations of what work is available for it to do. Like most Australians interested in industry issues, I would love to see it continue well into the future as a viable dockyard. I do not think anyone is trying to put that at risk although the commercial reality may, in the long term, put it at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Trade. Given the increasing focus on the services sector as a source of strong export growth into Asia, can he advise the Senate what the government is doing to expand and consolidate Australia's involvement in this emerging export market?

—I thank Senator Murphy because his question does raise an issue of some importance. It is too little appreciated that the improving export performance that Australia is showing is not just a product of our traditional markets and the success in increasing export manufactures, but more and more it is in the intangible items that we cannot see—the services that are providing enhancement to our export performance. I do not think this gets enough attention or consideration. I was therefore pleased to see the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald which reinforced this argument. In recognition of the contribution of Senator Cook and other trade ministers during the life of this government, I have to say that they have, for the first time, realised the enormous potential in services exports for Australia in the region and more broadly.

PARA.TAB: While the government has initiated a major study of the services sector, it has the potential on the initial reports, which Senator Cook and I have seen, to be as significant as the McKinsey study on emerging exporters has been for the manufacturing sector. It is too early to say that definitively because the report is not concluded, but the initial reports are very encouraging and very interesting. They have raised a lot of important issues; they encourage one to think that not only are we doing well but that there is enormous potential to do much more. I say this first because I believe we can be more successful and, secondly, because the market, particularly in this region, will grow and expand. That report is due to be released in the middle of the year.

I look forward to that both in itself and as a contribution to a broader debate on this very important issue about where the jobs will come from for Australians in the future, where the wealth will be generated, and where important opportunities for the young Australians who are succeeding in our enhanced education performance as a country will be working and finding their career options in the next century.

It is probably underestimated that services already account directly for 20 per cent of our exports. That fact is not taken into account when people think about the various elements of our trade. Services make an enormous contribution to merchandise exports. It has been assessed that their contribution to exports overall rises to about 40 per cent when we assess their contribution into other exports also.

Increasingly, the service exporters are taking advantage of government programs in the export area. The last figures I saw showed that up to 40 per cent of export market development grant recipients in 1992 were service companies. The successful negotiation of the Uruguay round gives an enhanced opportunity to succeed in this area. A lot of Australians are doing very good business in this area. It is creating wealth and jobs in the country and opportunities for Australians around the world. There is more to do, and I think when this study is released in the middle of the year it should engender a lot of interest for members of parliament in general, and the community more broadly, about where the opportunities are for Australia and Australians into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murphy for asking that question because my question follows from it very naturally. It is directed to Senator Evans. Can the minister confirm that Australia is still exporting hazardous waste for so-called recycling to non-OECD countries, particularly those in South-East Asia? What guarantees, if any, can the minister give that these wastes are recycled? Can he explain why Australia continues to block international efforts to ban the export of hazardous waste from OECD to non-OECD countries and is planning to do so again at the Basel Convention meeting later this month? Can he explain how exporting our waste to non-OECD countries meets our obligation under the Basel Convention for the disposal of hazardous waste in an environmentally sound manner? Given the government's marketing of Australia as clean and green, how does the minister reconcile this with the export of hazardous waste to non-OECD countries? How does this export to South-East Asian nations improve the environment in those countries?

—I am not sure that I have before me sufficient information to answer every one of those questions. Yet to the extent that there is a shortfall, I will rectify that after question time or at the next available opportunity. But let me say generally about all this that the Australian government does view trade in hazardous wastes as a serious matter and will certainly act to ensure that any such trade is environmentally sound. We are a party to the Basel Convention on trans-boundary movements of hazardous waste and their disposal and we believe that this convention provides a good framework to minimise and eliminate its negative aspects. We will not be involved in dumping hazardous waste on our neighbours and trading partners and we will ensure that the Hazardous Wastes (Regulation of Export and Import) Act of 1989 implements our international obligations in this area. To this end, late last year Mrs Kelly announced a comprehensive review of Australia's policy on trade in hazardous wastes for recovery. That review is being conducted in close consultation with industry and environment non-government organisations and is expected to be completed early this month.

PARA.TAB: That review will provide much better information on Australia's trade in recoverables than we have at present. We know that there is substantial trade, much of it in wastes or secondary raw materials which are not really hazardous, such as scrap metal or waste paper. There is also significant trade in wastes which are accepted as hazardous, for example, metal-bearing sludges from refining operations or spent lead acid batteries.

Not all trade is environmentally damaging, however, for many countries of our region. It is only through trade that we can find the economies of scale that are needed to make recycling viable. Without trade many wastes would go straight to landfill or be stockpiled. So Australia will work with its trading partners in the region to ensure that any trade in these products or wastes that does occur is, in fact, environmentally beneficial.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and it relates to the progress made on reform of the electricity supply industry at last Friday's heads of government meeting in Hobart. I ask: can the Minister inform the Senate whether the government's focus on reforming the supply side of the industry is consistent with good environmental practice?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for her question and acknowledge her close interest in the environmental issues that are at the heart of the question. I can assure Senator Zakharov that the answer to her question is yes. The government's objective in electricity reform is to gain benefits for consumers and industry through lower and more competitive electricity prices. Interstate and intrastate competition and institutional change in the industry will drive this.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the big reform moves in transport and telecommunications, the states are responsible primarily for decisions which will determine the type and pace of reform in this area. That is why the COAG forum is particularly critical. I certainly welcome last Friday's agreement, and the significant achievement that the Prime Minister made at that meeting, to push forward with the uniform approach to network pricing and regulation. There is also a strong link between this reform and good environmental management.

I had the opportunity to discuss this very issue this morning with the new President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Professor David Yencken, and a number of his colleagues from the ACF. It has been argued that because reform will lead to cheaper electricity, that will lead to more electricity being used, which in turn will lead to more greenhouse gas emissions being created. That is a highly simplistic analysis; the picture is far more complex.

There is a much more environmentally positive story to tell. There is no doubt that the power generation sector is and will remain a greenhouse gas producing industry. However, the COAG reform agenda is set to increase the amount of power produced per unit of fuel burned. There are a number of reasons why this will be achieved: there will be a more efficient use of existing generating capacity through more grid interconnections; older and less efficient plant will close over time; and new, more environmentally benign capacity will come on stream. The new capacity will have very modern, integrated carbon scrubber technologies built in rather than added on as they currently are in the older power stations. Real opportunities for co-generation using fuels other than coal, for example, natural gas, will be opened up.

Remote area power supplies will become more competitive, with more conventional grid connections, and cost-effective demand side measures will be encouraged when prices more accurately reflect the actual cost of the supply.So there is a coincidence here between industry's desire for more efficient input pricing and the trend towards more environmentally sustainable practices in industry.

I should add that, while the electricity reform agenda does focus on the supply side of the industry, the government has continued to fund a range of energy demand management programs and renewable energy initiatives. Many of these programs predate our commitment to the COAG reform process and will continue as a legitimate part of a broad based energy policy framework.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Is the federal government leaving open the possibility of freezing the tariff on passenger motor vehicles at 25 per cent when it reaches that level on 1 January 1996, because the domestic car manufacturers do not believe the pace of the federal government's micro-economic reform program is fast enough to enable them to be competitive with a 15 per cent tariff?

—I have answered four or five questions from the opposition and from Senator Spindler, who has a particular interest in industry policy for the Australian Democrats, on what might be the content of the industry statement. On all occasions I have indicated to this place that the industry statement is under consideration. We expect to announce the statement at the end of April or the beginning of May. Until such time, there is a healthy industry, both in the media and at large, in speculation about what the statement might contain.

PARA.TAB: It is not my intention to fuel that speculation in any way, other than to say I am in a constant process of consultation. However, the question of what might become of tariffs is central to such an industry statement. I have been at pains to indicate that the fundamentals of our industry setting, which obviously refers in part to tariffs, are the strong and virtually unshakeable pillars upon which the statement will finally be framed.

But on the question of the pace of micro-economic reform and the level of tariff protection in the automobile industry—or more broadly, the automotive industry—I point out that last Friday the Prime Minister, the premiers from the states and the chief ministers from the territories agreed on adopting the report on competition policy in Australia. I regard that as a massive step forward for the nation of Australia in addressing and quickening the pace of micro-economic reform, because I believe fundamentally that the precepts in the competition policy will, by creating genuine competition in our ports and as between ports, and in rail, in road, and in electricity generation and supply, be a means of levering forward the next generation of micro-economic reform.

What has been rightly said of micro-economic reform is that the initial impetus and thrust for major micro-economic reform came from this government. It did so in the form of the major reform on the waterfront, the National Rail Freight Authority, the major reform of coastal shipping and major reform in initiatives taken by us in order to rationalise the generation and distribution of electricity.

While this government does not shirk the task, and will not shirk the task of continuing with the ongoing needs of making sure that we are competitive in those areas, nonetheless the fair observation is that the burden of micro-economic reform that is as yet untackled is at state level. The commitment by the premiers, with the Prime Minister and the chief ministers, is an indication, I think fairly put, of their willingness now to move that matter forward. Obviously that is a big consideration when we consider how the tariffs are cast in terms of industries, and the ability of those industries to adjust to global competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The government's policy is to reduce car tariffs by 2 1/2 per cent per annum until the 15 per cent target is reached in the year 2000. Is the minister now telling the Senate that that policy is in limbo and that the policy may well change as a result of the forthcoming industry statement?

—Of course industry policy is under consideration. I endeavoured to give the broadest possible indication that our tariff reform agenda is a central, consistent and stable part of our industry package. While I obviously will be reserving the right to look at what we might do at the end point of tariff reductions, the broad and simple message is that we are committed to those levels of tariff reductions.

PARA.TAB: That does not mean to say we do not listen to views put by industry. Of course we do. One view relates to micro-economic reform, and those opposite just heard me answer a question in respect of that interest in some detail a moment ago.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Pensions and Incomes Asset Test: Review

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Could the minister outline the terms of reference of the pensions income and assets test review? Could she also inform the Senate of the identity and experience of the consultant appointed to conduct the review; who the members of the review panel are; and the role of the reference panel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for her question because the review of the pensions income and assets test will be of great interest to government and I hope to the opposition senators too. The review is examining the conceptual framework, design principles and the actual operation of the income and assets test. It will also examine the relationship between the social security income and assets test and the taxation system and will identify options for change and improvement to the current tests.

PARA.TAB: The minister has announced the successful tenderer—John Barber and colleagues of Ageing Agendas. The members of Ageing Agendas have a strong understanding and working knowledge of the pension system, taxation and retirement income products. The minister has also announced that the consultants will be advised by a special reference group made up of experts drawn from welfare, pensioners and retiring interest groups as well as from the finance industry. The combined expertise of Ageing Agendas, together

ANSWER.PARA: with the reference group, will mean broad, complex tasks are handled effectively.

PARA.TAB: There seems to be some difference of opinion among members of the opposition about the merit of this inquiry at all and how it will proceed. The honourable member for Berowra had to issue the inevitable press release when the minister made the announcement and he was complaining that there had been such a stalling over the tendering process that there would not be time for a full and comprehensive review. That is not true. The department has followed due and proper process in the tendering selection.

The shadow minister for veterans' affairs, Senator MacGibbon, obviously has a very different opinion of the review team and a very different view from that of the honourable member for Berowra. He did not see any need for a comprehensive review and thought that these people could write the report over a weekend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earth-shattering.
—Speak up.

—Senator Kemp should tell his colleagues to be quiet. I am not mumbling at all. What is clear from the government is that there will be time for consultation. Giving older people a chance to have their say is something that we believe is crucial and a crucial part of this review, something that some members of the opposition clearly do not believe. We want a well-considered, open process and that cannot be done over a weekend, as Senator MacGibbon was suggesting, albeit somewhat flippantly, I think.

PARA.TAB: While the review is going on, the opposition has been adopting ridiculous positions on government amendments, particularly with regard to the Veterans Entitlement Act—amendments that would positively help pensioners. We do not understand—I certainly do not understand—why the opposition would want to say, `Let's not do anything until after the review', when it could pass amendments that would be of direct benefit to pensioners. That is pretty hypocritical in view of the fact that these amendments are related to the treatment of managed investments. Apparently that is an issue for the opposition but it is not prepared to pass those amendments to the veterans entitlement—I have lost it—the veterans—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lost all the time.
—Those opposite are really sharp today. Here they are opposing amendments that would benefit pensioners—
—Hopeless, imcompetent!
—I say to Senator Vanstone that those opposite are opposing amendments—
—Order! Do not debate it. Please get on with the answer.

—Thank you, Mr President; I will be very pleased to do so. Those opposite are not proceeding with amendments that would assist pensioners to get benefits. Opposition senators are obstructing such amendments and this will lead pensioners to worry a great deal.What is the position of those opposite on this? Do they seriously want to participate in this inquiry? If they want to benefit pensioners, they should join us in that inquiry, make it comprehensive and pass the amendments.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the report released today by the Commonwealth Grants Commission where the updated figures cut Queensland's allocation by $148.7 million, or nearly five per cent on the budget distribution, the highest by far of any state. Is the government prepared to reconsider this outrageous recommendation for the reduction in Queensland grants? Is Queensland being punished for being a low tax state and not having fuel and financial transaction taxes, the legacy of financially responsible coalition and National Party governments in Queensland? Is this cut the Commonwealth's way of forcing Queensland into line with the other states and applying a petrol tax?

—The figures published by the Commonwealth Grants Commission are contained in its 1994 update report on general revenue grant relativities. As Senator Boswell said in his question, that report has come out today.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Grants Commission is acknowledged by the Commonwealth, the states and the territories, it should be said, as an impartial umpire on the distribution of general revenues. It annually undertakes a review and publishes that review on best knowledge in the circumstances. It is independent of executive government and its recommendations are a basis for consideration at the upcoming Premiers Conference. This government will make up its mind about what it does about state revenues prior to the Premiers Conference, of course using the publication that is now before us as some sort of indication. But I have to say that it is indicative only.

I was asked whether the government will reconsider the report. That is not an appropriate question because it is not our report; it is a report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission that looks impartially at all the facts and indicators and makes a recommendation to the government. It is a report from the umpire and it is not for us to reconsider.

The other question was whether Queensland was being punished? That is a question that the Brisbane newspapers might want to headline. If they do, they would be mistaken because Queensland is not being punished. We cannot describe under any use of language that the findings of an independent body represent any malevolence against Queensland. It is what the statistics show and what the circumstances that have given rise to those statistics dictate.

The main reasons, I understand, for the large redistribution of general revenue assistance away from Queensland are a correction for errors of input cost factors used for Queensland in calculating the 1993 per capita relativities, which resulted in overpayment to Queensland in 1993-94, and the 1991 census data, which indicated a decrease in the proportion of the Queensland population who are Aboriginal, which results, of course, in lower funding.

We can play the winners and losers game when we look at the reports of such a body as the Commonwealth Grants Commission. If we did play the winners and losers game, it would be found that Queensland and Western Australia would be losers and New South Wales and the Northern Territory would be winners. But that is an idle game to play. The most sensible and serious game to play is to come to grips with what the statistics tell us, and from the Commonwealth point of view listen to the views of the states and, in due course and before the Premiers Conference, make a responsible recommendation about funding. That we will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does Senator Cook concede, by standing by the principle enunciated by the Grants Commission, that Queensland should raise its level of tax revenue to the average of the other states, thus destroying its low tax status? That principle is penalising the efficient. Does that make a complete mockery of the government's new competition policy?

—The Grants Commission finds its own reasons for making its recommendations. We consider those and the views of the states in making our offers to the premiers in terms of funding. The answer to the second part of that question—does it make a mockery of competition policy—is a two letter word: no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I am glad that the minister has acknowledged my interest in industry policy because I am going to ask him about the Kelty recommendations on regional development. I acknowledge the minister's answer to an earlier question of mine that he cannot pre-empt the government's decisions in either the budget or the industry statement, but I ask the minister to advise the Senate in general terms whether the government supports the Kelty recommendations and whether he, personally, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, supports the establishment of regional economic development organisations, as recommended in the Kelty report, to mobilise regional and local initiatives and resources?

—We will be responding to the Kelty report, the Industry Commission report on regional Australia, and the McKinsey report on, as I recall it, business inputs into regional Australia when we bring down our white paper on jobs, industry policy and regional development. We will respond to all of those things in that context.
—When is that coming down?

—We have not fixed the date precisely, but we are working to a timetable of bringing down that statement early in May or late in April—that is the slot we are aiming for—and it will be before the budget. That is the current intention.

PARA.TAB: I am asked whether I personally support the recommendations of the Kelty report and, in particular, the regional economic development organisations. I do not have a personal personality; I only have a ministerial personality. In this place that is true; outside of this place it is a different matter. But in answering questions, I only have a ministerial and government personality.

Speaking to the report, I will make my views known in the white paper process. The Kelty report is the first and most exhaustive study of the needs of regional Australia. It has highlighted a number of the problems of regional development and it has put forward a series of recommendations—137 in all, I recall. They all go to how life in regional Australia can be improved; how job opportunities can be enhanced; how economic development can be improved; what the information flow available to regional industry and regional centres might be; and how we can better deliver those services that we as a Commonwealth government deliver in social security and welfare to regional Australia, and target it in a way that is best suited to the needs of those particular regions. It does all of those things and they are welcome observations and recommendations in the report.

The recommendation on regional economic development organisations is one that I will respond to in due course. However, let me say to the Senate that anything that encourages regions to collectively, and across all interest groups in those regions—from the environmental interest groups, to the union interest groups, to the business interest groups—come together and articulate a vision for development in those regions and articulate to the federal government and state governments, as well as their local authorities, how that should be undertaken, is welcome. It is a sort of citizens' initiative that will be welcome and, of course, it will add greatly to the ability of those regions to develop themselves. Whatever encourages that sort of initiative is something that those opposite will find that this government will smile on. Whether it is in exactly the same form as recommended or in some other form, those opposite will have to wait and see.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given the Prime Minister's feigned indignation on ABC news last Sunday night regarding his own high moral ground in never resorting to personal attacks in 25 years in politics, can the minister explain exactly what the Prime Minister would call the following litany of abuse which has graced his parliamentary career? I quote selectively from the many sources available to me: `A complete political harlot'; `This piece of vermin'; `You stupid foul mouthed grub'; `You are a piece of criminal garbage'; `The brain damaged member on the other side of the House'; `The champion liar of 1983'; `Scumbags on the front bench'; and `The monster from the deep lagoon'. How would the minister describe this language, if not as personal attacks of the worst kind?

—Senator Troeth has shown she can read Liberal Party research, but she has not shown she can read a transcript or read properly a newspaper account of what the Prime Minister actually said. What the Prime Minister said, as I specifically recall it, is that he had never resorted in the past to unprovoked personal attacks on people's personal or financial affairs. I know the Prime Minister is not a person who tells fibs in this respect or any other respect. The Prime Minister is not someone who goes trawling around people's private affairs, be they affairs of the heart or affairs of the purse.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has never got into that business. He has never got into the Tuckey business; he has never got into the John Howard business; he has never got into the Michael Baume business. When it has got to do with personal matters, financial matters or things of this kind, that is what the Prime Minister is referring to when he so often responds as he does—those who embark upon those kinds of assaults on people's integrity or upon their privacy. The Prime Minister is someone who is committed to upholding some decency and some values in public life in this country. In that respect, he is in spectacular contrast to most of the mob opposite who do not even understand what those values are about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I assure Senator Evans that my reading ability is equal to his own. The Prime Minister hopes the changes to question time in the other place will create tranquillity in, and a greater respect for, the chamber. Again, in view of the Prime Minister's own actions in debasing standards of parliamentary behaviour, what guarantee do we have of a genuine commitment to the improvements that he has foreshadowed?

—There is only one mob which has perverted the new question time arrangements—those represented by those sitting opposite. Question time under the new system was working well for a day or so in terms of people asking much more substantive questions of many more ministers on a wider range of issues and getting decent, straightforward and explicit responses. Opposition members went on a political rampage because they thought they could get some squalid political advantage out of it, because they wanted to divert attention from their own miserable, internecine, internal problems, and they set about embarking on a course of action of a highly politicising character which necessarily brings its own reward. They got that reward and they should not be complaining about it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Small Business, in his capacity as minister responsible for Customs. I refer to an article that appeared on the front page of the Canberra Times this morning relating to a crackdown on fuel substitution rorts that are allegedly costing the Commonwealth $100 million a year. I understand that not only is the fuel substitution a fraudulent practice, but also it is regarded as a highly dangerous practice. What action has the government taken to stop this practice and not only protect the Commonwealth revenue but also eliminate the danger associated with the practice?

—Yes, I am aware of the front page story in the Canberra Times today suggesting that this matter would cost the revenue $100 million. I cannot corroborate that figure. That is an estimate from within the industry, though our own belief is that the figure is more likely to be $20 million—that would be a more realistic estimate. Honourable senators would be aware that at the end of last year the parliament carried legislation to outlaw this practice and to draw up regulations for it. It was supported by all parties in the Senate, and I thank them for their support. The legislation is yet to be proclaimed, but regulations are also having to be drawn up to allow for appropriate exemptions.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out that the government took this action because the loss of revenue is significant and would have gone higher. It is also a dangerous practice if not regulated because there is the possibility of these mixtures or blends exploding in engines, not only risking loss of property but also causing danger to people. It was for both the loss of revenue aspect and the danger to the public aspect that the government took this action.

Under the legislation the following provisions will apply: an excise manufacturer's licence will be necessary to blend petroleum products after they have been cleared from Customs control; blended petroleum products containing petrol will be liable to excise duty on the whole volume at the rate applying to leaded petrol; other petroleum blends will be dutiable at the diesel fuel rate on the whole volume; crude oils and condensate used as fuels are also liable to excise duty; records of production and delivery of the above goods will be required to be maintained and duty payments made to Customs on a regular basis; and penalties of up to $50,000 or five times the duty evaded can apply for non-compliance.

I want to stress that this should act as a very clear warning to those in the industry who are indulging in this fraudulent practice. They not only run the risk of paying heavy fines for evaded duty but also leave themselves open to hefty damages through civil proceedings where their fuel substitution practices lead to either property or personal damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. Following the government's failed attempts to protect the copyright of recording artists via the now unconstitutional blank tape levy, will the government accept that to increase the sales tax on blank cassettes will simply disadvantage innocent consumers, and be costly to run and inefficient? What is wrong with the proposal put forward by the Australian Tape Manufacturers Association, and endorsed by the Australian Consumers Association, that a licence fee to make a copy for one's own use be included in the price of any recorded music purchased? Does such a licence fee not operate very effectively for computer software? Does the minister not understand the stupidity of continuing with the situation where Australians can buy products such as this Icehouse Big Wheel CD and be law-breakers if they tape the CD but are given instructions with purchase on how to copy the floppy?
—I think the best I can do with Senator Vanstone's question is pass it on to the relevant minister, and if she would like I could even take the CD as well.
—You just want to copy it.
—Icehouse is not my niche.
—Nor mine either.
—Knowing Senator Vanstone, I would be surprised if it was to her taste. I will leave the floppy with her, and I will pass on the question to the minister.

—My question is directed to Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade. The government's efforts to encourage trading and cultural links with countries in the Asia-Pacific region have been effective and well publicised. I ask the minister whether he can explain to the Senate what the government is doing to encourage Australian firms to look at opportunities within the Indian Ocean region.

—It is a very appropriate question to come from a Western Australian senator because the need to look west as well as north in our trade promotion, trade activities and the activities of Australian business is very important, and I think more appreciated on the west coast than in the rest of Australia. But it is an issue for Australians wherever they are because there are important business and trade opportunities for Australia throughout the Indian Ocean region, and significant possibilities that they will grow rapidly.

PARA.TAB: There has always been a significant and important market in the Middle East. A strong market also exists in India and many Australians companies are doing good business there. It is important to take account of the re-emergence of South Africa into the international economic community and the trade opportunities that provides for Australian business.

There has been a significant amount of activity about this issue of Indian Ocean trade links. In particular, I have had recent discussions with the Indian Minister for Commerce, Mr Ahmed, in what was called the Australia-India Joint Ministerial Commission. Both formally and informally we discussed the potential of developing Indian Ocean trade links. This development will not become one that will or should displace the priority given to the Asia-Pacific region, particularly to the ASEAN and north-east Asian countries. It will not be of that order but it is nevertheless potentially very significant.

In particular, I refer to the interesting new and important opportunities that are emerging in India. The government has commissioned an Indian trade and investment study to identify business opportunities and strategies for pursuing them. I have seen a draft report of that study and it indicates something that would be recalled by those honourable senators who were members of the Senate committee which inquired into Australia's relations with India, which committee made an important contribution to this issue. In the massive economy which already exists in India there is a significant middle-class market, the smallest assessment being $100 million plus. The indications are that, for the remainder of this decade and into the next century, it will be a rapidly growing large market for a wide range of Australian products. We therefore particularly welcome the dramatic and courageous economic transformation which is going on in India. We are very encouraged that the Indian government is strongly committed to continuing the process of economic reform. Some honourable senators will have seen reported today and very briefly yesterday the Indian budget for 1994-95, which was presented to the Indian parliament on 28 February. It has some liberalising and economic growth emphases that are very important to Australia in terms of overall economic growth and the market that will create and, in particular, general and specific tariff reductions.

I am very pleased with the recent announcement of a successful bid by Command Petroleum Holdings to develop the Ravva oilfield off the coast of Madras in India. The project received a lot of support from the Australian government, including ministerial level support from Senator Cook. It is an important opportunity. It is about wealth; it is about jobs. It is one of those positive possibilities that are important for Australia, particularly Western Australia. I am confident that, as an added element to a trade strategy with its principal focus on the Asia-Pacific and recognising our traditional markets in north America and western Europe, an emphasis not only on India but on the other countries in the Indian Ocean as well has significant potential for Australians and Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister in his caretaker role as Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to the Prime Minister's admission that he is holding the position of Minister for the Status of Women only until he `got a better person'. Can the women of Australia now expect a fifth minister in the women's portfolio in the space of 12 months? Does the Prime Minister's admission mean there is not one person in the current Labor caucus capable of representing women? Do Australian women deserve better than the current merry-go-round of ministers in the women's portfolio?

—This is a curious question that Senator Patterson dares to put here when we compare this government's record for women with that of the opposition. This government put the Office of the Status of Women into the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet—it has been there since we came to office in 1983—giving standing to women and recognition of the importance of that portfolio's responsibilities. From there we have established the policies and programs that have convinced and continue to convince Australian women of the seriousness with which the Prime Minister and this government regards policies for women.

PARA.TAB: It is the opposition that wants to remove policies for women and to do away with the affirmative action policy, and this government that has got the credibility on these issues. As to what is in the Prime Minister's mind, we will wait and see.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is a simple question. Does the Prime Minister's admission mean there is not one person in the current Labor caucus capable of representing women? That needs a yes or no answer. Does the government have no one better to take responsibility for the status of women portfolio than a man who yesterday raised the prospect of dressing up in drag to do the job.

—The view of the opposition on this is very selective. There was a committee of inquiry into the Office of the Status of Women which, as Senator Patterson would know, I set up and chaired. The recommendation was that the OSW should go into the cabinet, and that is where it is. That is where the Prime Minister is looking after it. What is more, Senator Patterson is selectively quoting about the Prime Minister. She did not tell senators that today the Prime Minister opened and addressed the first meeting of the Australian Council of Women. It was a round table meeting representing all the women of Australia. It was a very significant first, and where was the Prime Minister? He was there. He was meeting and speaking to those Australian women. The credibility of the Prime Minister with women still stands.

—I ask Senator Gareth Evans, representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, about the agreement signed last week by Mr Bilney and Dr Haryono Suyono, his counterpart in Indonesia, for Australia to help fund a program of assistance, managed through UNFPA, to enable Indonesia to provide family planning, training and technical assistance to Pacific islands. Is it a fact that this statement, signed by both ministers, says that Indonesia's program of family planning is voluntary and non-coercive? How does that tie in with the well-established evidence of the exercise of power by the army to enforce the target driven family planning program in Indonesia? Why did the minister at the press conference not pull Dr Haryono Suyono up when the latter supported the promotion of Norplant, the contraceptive/abortifacient, as a beauty aid? That is how it is promoted in Indonesia. Can the minister advise honourable senators as to how these statements can be made?

—I am not aware of the background to that exchange or series of statements Senator Harradine refers to. I will seek a detailed response from my colleague Mr Bilney and give the honourable senator an early reply.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time Senator Coulter asked me a question about the export of hazardous wastes. The only thing I need to add to the answer given previously for the sake of completeness is this: the question of a ban on the export of hazardous wastes from OECD to non-OECD countries will be considered at the Basel Convention conference of parties meeting in Geneva on 21 to 25 March. While Australia presently has in place a de facto ban in relation to exports to non-OECD countries for disposal, the issue of extending this ban to cover recoverables is complex. The government is presently considering its position on this issue, recognising that the need to ensure that the trade in recoverables is conducted in an environmentally sound manner while not unnecessarily regulating trade in material which is both commercially and environmentally valuable.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, might I say that I see Senator Coulter has put out a press release embargoed until 3 p.m. which says that we appear at the top of the list of a `sinister seven' exporters of hazardous wastes. That appearance at the top of the list is purely a result of alphabetical considerations, and Senator Coulter's arithmetic is obviously shonky to the extent that we are not the largest exporter in per capita terms. That honour goes to Germany and the United States.

Senator Coulter also alleges in his press release that we are in breach of the Basel Convention. That is not so. The convention itself, article 4(9)(B), allows for exports of wastes which are required as raw material for recycling or recovery industries in the importing states, and where the trade is regulated. I have already acknowledged that there are deficiencies in the act so far as the regulations on recoverable waste are concerned, but they are being addressed in the review of the whole trade in waste. I hope that Senator Coulter reflects some of these points in his press release before it finally goes out.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time, in answer to a question from Senator Jones in respect of the bombing of the NCA in Waymouth Street, Adelaide, I gave the answer that the most recent advice to me was that two people had been killed and four others injured as a result of the incident. I have now received further clarification from the Minister for Justice concerning the NCA bombing. It appears that one member of the NCA staff was killed. However, another staff member is currently in a critical condition and undergoing surgery. A further four people were injured, as I stated earlier.
