—Senator Brownhill asked me a question on 24 February, and I sought to get more information for him. I am aware that both importers and local manufacturers are concerned by the AAT decision to which Senator Brownhill referred, which effectively granted duty free status to imports of chrome leather splits which previously attracted duty in accordance with assistance arrangements for that industry. Following the AAT decision, a sector of the tanning industry, the Federated Tanners Association of Australia, expressed concern over the sudden reduction in assistance levels resulting from that decision. I understand that these concerns have been referred to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, which has asked Customs for advice on the legislative changes which would be necessary to restore the intended assistance levels that existed prior to the AAT decision.

PARA.TAB: I can assure Senator Brownhill that the government remains committed to full discussion on this issue. I have asked officers within Customs and the TCF to explore all the issues with both importers and local manufacturers and to provide me with a report. A decision will be made on the appropriate assistance arrangements once the consultation process is finalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to hazardous wastes.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that 98 per cent of the world's hazardous waste comes from the 24 OECD countries. Contrary to what the minister said in answer to a question last week about the rich countries being able to afford to clean up their environment, the shipment of these toxic wastes to Third World countries indicates the fallacy of this idea.

PARA.TAB: The minister's stupidity—or is it wilful neglect of the facts?—is also indicated by Australia's action in resisting the tightening of the Basel Convention to the extent that it would ban the movement of these wastes across trans-national boundaries. The fact is that the rich nations are running out of space and, rather than cleaning up their production methods, Australia, along with six other countries, has chosen to export its environmental and health problems to the Third World in our region.

In New South Wales, the minister for the environment has said that Sydney will run out of landfill sites within seven years. In the US, the creation of the super fund to clean up contaminated sites—those sites contaminated with toxic waste—has resulted in the discovery of so many sites that it is expected the cost of that clean-up will exceed $400 billion. The cost of landfill in the US rose from $15 per tonne in 1980 to $250 per tonne in 1989. It is no wonder that the rich countries are looking for a cheap alternative such as dumping this dangerous material in Third World countries—countries which do not have the technology or the financial and economic ability to deal with these wastes safely. In an economic rationalist world it makes a great deal of sense to dump waste in the lowest wage country. As Lawrence Summers, the chief economist with the World Bank, said, the economic logic is impeccable.

The Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the Australian mining industry have also strongly supported this practice of dumping hazardous wastes in Third World countries, and why should they not? It brings economic benefits, at least in the short term, to Australia and, more particularly, to the companies that these organisations represent.

Australia is exporting its hazardous wastes mainly to India and the Philippines. Australia is the world's worst polluter and, contrary to what the minister just said, in absolute terms between 1990 and 1993 exported three times as much as the US on a per capita basis. Our wastes include such things as cadmium, copper, lead and nickel, all of which are hazardous to human health.

Recycling, of course, is the excuse which is often used and was the excuse which the minister used today. But, in fact, when one looks in these Third World countries one finds that, particularly in the case of lead acid batteries, much of this so-called recycling is going on in backyard establishments in which young children are actually remelting lead dross to get small amounts of lead to turn into recycled metal.

The Basel Convention places an obligation on states to transfer to states of import no hazardous wastes which are not to be managed in an environmentally sound manner. Yet there is abundant evidence that Australia's wastes are not being handled in an environmentally sound manner in these Third World countries. It also says that first world countries shall only export if the state of export does not have the technical ability and the necessary facilities to dispose of these wastes in an environmentally sound manner. So, clearly, the fact that Australia continues to export these things indicates that Australia has neither the technology nor the facilities, which is simply untrue.

The ASEAN nations meeting in September 1993 moved that their governments should prohibit the import and trans-boundary movement of all hazardous waste for any reason into ASEAN countries, and passed a number of other resolutions in this connection. Australia, Canada, Finland, Japan, Germany, US and UK are the world's worst polluters in this trans-boundary shipment of hazardous waste. It is a disgrace to Australia and I would urge the minister very strongly, in going into that Basel meeting later this month, to move that Australia totally ban the export of this material from Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pensions and Incomes Assets Test: Review

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Denman this day, relating to a review of the pensions and incomes assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a degree of misinformation in the rather confused answer that Senator Crowley gave. She tried to imply that there was a difference between me and Mr Ruddock. I understood her to say that I said the inquiry could be held in a weekend. I have had the Hansards sent to me of all my recent speeches and I cannot find a reference to that, and I just do not think there is any basis for that assertion at all.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that Mr Ruddock in a speech in the other place said he thought the inquiry would take a bit longer. But in a subsequent speech, on 24 February, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that, while I personally have doubts about the ambitious nature of the program for the review that the consultant has set having regard to the nature of the very considerable task that has to be undertaken, the consultant seems to believe that he will be able to expedite the process. He is talking about bringing forward the date for the preliminary report, which will be made public, from July to June. He is hopeful that he may be able to speed up the process.

So the long answer that we had from Senator Crowley about how it would take ages for the inquiry into the retirement income policies to take place has certainly been undercut by the chairman of the committee looking at that matter.

PARA.TAB: I also take exception to Senator Crowley's attack on the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia and, by implication, the Australian Democrats too, because they supported us on this motion, that we would not amend any retirement income policies until the committee inquiring into retirement income policies set up by the government had made its report.

We did that for very good reasons, as we made clear in this place. We are tired of the goal posts being moved for the elderly and the infirm—the people who cannot look after themselves. We are tired of a system that imposes notional gains on shareholdings and assets that pensioners might have when, as has occurred in many cases, they may well have paid a higher price for them than is realisable on the markets today, but because the share prices are rising in the papers, they are credited with a notional income from the increased value of the holdings they have.

I have dozens of letters in my office from pensioners and veterans who have gone through a great deal of financial loss. They have been forced to sell stock they held to qualify for and maintain their pensions. That is quite wrong. We on this side of the chamber have made it clear on a number of occasions that we will not put up with that.

There is also the enormous mental distress that comes to the elderly—people in the final years of their lives—faced with complex bureaucratic rules and regulations that they do not understand, and which this government capriciously changes week in, week out; month in and month out. That is why we will not go along with Senator Crowley's scheme until there has been an inquiry into it—until it has been thought through, and the honourable senator has come up with some coherent and fair system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), to a question asked by Senator MacGibbon this day, relating to the relocation of the Sydney fleet base from Garden Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray in his answer referred to the 7.30 Report last night and indicated that, in his opinion, a number of incorrect statements were made. I would like to point out that the information I have is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was given the opportunity to put his point of view on a number of occasions by the 7.30 Report, but declined to do so.

PARA.TAB: However, what is more important in the answer that Senator Ray gave is that last night in the 7.30 Report it was revealed that the Prime Minister had asked the defence minister to consider relocating the Sydney fleet base from Garden Island to White Bay. Despite the minister's indication that he was an immovable object when it came to the irresistible force that the Prime Minister may apply to him, I believe that this is a very important question which deserves another kind of answer.

I believe it is quite possible that, in the end, the Prime Minister will have his way, no matter how immovable Senator Ray might believe himself to be. In that case, my concern is that a large sum of money will be spent on relocating a major naval facility from one site in Sydney to another site, and purely for aesthetic reasons. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to population control policy in Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans's answer was not much of an answer to me, and that surprised me. Last week—on 24 February—the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, Mr Bilney, in this parliament signed an agreement with Haryono Suyono, the state minister of population and head of the BKKBN, Indonesia's national family planning board. It makes a ludicrous assertion that the Indonesian family planning program is voluntary. In fact, it is a target driven, population control program.

PARA.TAB: There is ample evidence of the fact that it is not voluntary. Let me give an example. Inside Indonesia dated March 1992 describes how authoritarian the family planning program is in Indonesia. One aspect is the safari or hunting expedition. The report says that in a subdistrict of West Java people in `difficult' villages were told by field workers that if they refused contraceptives they would have to join the transmigration program to the outer islands. In other cases, unwilling villagers were picked up by military or police personnel and taken to the village head office to have contraceptives inserted. I am using the words of Inside Indonesia. The authors said that during their field trip in 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: IUDs were inserted at gunpoint to those who continued to resist.

`A voluntary program', says minister Bilney—a voluntary program indeed! He then commits the government, extraordinarily, having regard to what the government has said in this matter, to a program of assistance managed through the United Nations population fund to enable Indonesia to provide family planning training and technical assistance to the Pacific countries. Those who are exacting coercion on the Indonesians will be the ones to devise promotion and training for the population programs funded by the Australian taxpayer in those countries.

PARA.TAB: The agreement says that the United Nations population fund, UNFPA, will be involved, as though that gives it some sort of legitimacy. As far back as 1989 I asked AIDAB about UNFPA's state of the world population 1989 report which detailed some of the population control methods used in Indonesia, describing Java as the scene of some of the most innovative and effective family planning programs in the world. Whole groups and whole villages are denied loans unless the women become contraceptive acceptors. In fact, they get higher loans if they accept IUDs.

That is stated in the UNFPA's own document—and we are going to support this program! That to me is a violation of human rights. Minister Suyono confirmed during the press conference that Norplant, which is a contraceptive-abortifacient, is promoted in Indonesia as a beauty aid. Norplant: Under her Skin gives a feminist perspective of what is going on in this area.
Let me just tell honourable senators what Indonesian Minister Haryono said at Mr Bilney's press conference. When he was asked about Norplant, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well the way we inform people is just a variety of ways just like introducing something new, like when you introduce Coca-Cola you introduce it not like a kind of drink but rather to put yourself there, everywhere and things like that. This is the way to inform people and to get them attracted to it.
I ask the Senate whether that is fair. He goes on to say—(Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for the Status of Women

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to the administration of the Status of Women portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley was asked whether there was anybody else in caucus, other than Mr Keating, who could undertake the job of the Minister for the Status of Women. The simple answer was either yes or no. It would seem to be that no would be the answer because Mr Keating has taken it on. He said he is holding the position `until he gets a better person'. This indicates to me, and I think it would indicate to the Australian public, that he does not think there is anybody in the whole of caucus who can do it.

PARA.TAB: This time last year the person holding that position was the Hon. Wendy Fatin. She held the position from 4 April 1990 to 24 March 1993. Then Senator Crowley had it for all of nine months. Then Mrs Kelly had the position for all of three months—or 3 1/2 months, or whatever it was. Now Paul Keating is in a caretaking position. So all in all, by the time he gets the next person in, the women of Australia will have had five ministers in approximately 12 months.

In all good faith, women's groups and people who represent the media—because Minister Kelly saw some of the media about the representation of women in the media—spend time with these ministers. They inform them and outline their concerns about the issues, and spend a lot of their voluntary time and their own money—in many cases—getting to Canberra to speak to people, only to find that they have to start all over again. It was nine months later in the case of Senator Crowley and three months later in the case of Mrs Kelly—and I do not know how many of them are going to get to see Mr Keating.

That is what the women in caucus were asking him about yesterday. They said, `Is there not somebody to whom these women's groups can go, because they are not likely to get to you'. He said, `If I was'—not `if I were'—`a British member, then I would dress up for the occasion', which is inferring, I presume, that he would dress up in drag. It was not a very funny joke and, rightly so, the women in caucus were critical of Mr Keating.

We could not expect much else from him. Yesterday when I gave notice of a motion which outlined his maiden speech, somebody said to me, `Oh, well, you know that was his maiden speech. That was 25 years ago.'—or whatever. It was about the time I was growing up as a young woman trying to establish myself in a career; and I was dealing with people like Mr Keating. He said about the Liberal government:

SPEECH.PARA: In the last couple of years the Government has boasted about the increasing number of women in the work force. Rather than something to be proud of I feel that this is something of which we should be ashamed . . . Is this Government doing anything about child endowment? Is it doing anything to put the working wife back in her home? . . . It engages in a lot of claptrap.
That gives an indication of where he was coming from at the beginning of his career. I do not think he has changed one jot or one skerrick in the time he has been here.

PARA.TAB: The poor women in caucus, and some of the SNAGs over there, have not made a skerrick of difference to Mr Keating. In 1980—we thought he might have learned by then and that the leopard might have changed his spots—he said to a delegate at an ALP conference, `You know the rules, darling'. Then he said to a journalist in 1992—Senator Newman remembers this well—`Well, it is only that colour coordination of yours and that wonderful hairdo that encourage me to give you a very nice reply because you always put the most charming questions'. I hope that when women go to women's groups they have decent hairdos and have the right sort of clothes on and the right colour coordination because then the Prime Minister will feel inclined to give them a decent answer. Obviously, Mr Keating puts some sort of credence on how people look; that is the way he treats them.

Of course, former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, when he was responding to a question from journalists on interest rates, as reported on the ABC Four Corners program, said, `Good try, darling. Good try, darling'. John Dawkins said to Mrs Sullivan, `Sweetheart, you don't need a model to work this out'. And so it goes on. There is a number of other examples. I think even Ros Kelly referred to somebody in her office as `the little girl who answers the telephone'. It shows that they have not come anywhere in this debate. They are all talk and no action. The sooner the Prime Minister gets someone, if he can find someone—for heaven's sake, he does not seem to have anybody there now—to address women's issues—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no women on the frontbench.

—That is right. The government is always going on about all its achievements for women. If we look at this side of the chamber we see that the front bench is loaded with women and that there are women of talent behind us. Yet the Prime Minister cannot find one person—male or female—to take on this role; so he has to do it in a caretaking role. I find it absolutely amazing that the government can talk about all the things that it has done for women.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating what is now known as the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. It is an omnibus bill that will facilitate minor policy changes as well as make technical and minor amendments to the principal act. In a number of cases these amendments directly result from previous legislative deficiencies and oversights. It is of concern to me that we often spend time in this chamber dealing with the correction of legislation when loopholes have been found. We spend an inordinate amount of time doing that.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will not be opposing this bill in total but we will be opposing specific parts of it: the imposition of a harsher assets test for primary producers—a number of my colleagues will speak in more depth about that—and two measures that relate directly to the current review of the pension income and assets tests. We will also be moving amendments to improve the equity and fairness of the new penalty interest charge regime that this bill seeks to set up.

I wish to speak briefly on a number of initiatives in the bill. Firstly, this bill provides for an extension of eligibility for mobility allowance for people with disabilities undertaking jobsearch activities or in a competitive employment and training program who are unable to use public transport. The government informs us that this measure is required to correct an oversight and, as such, obviously will be supported by the coalition. However, I am concerned that extensions to the eligibility for this allowance appear to have been made in such an ad hoc way. It would be appreciated if the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, Senator Crowley, informed the Senate exactly who is now eligible for mobility allowance and, more importantly, who is currently excluded from it.

This bill will reverse the current situation whereby the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is able to order a stay of a decision even though the Social Security Appeals Tribunal has reaffirmed a departmental decision. The coalition considers this to be a proper approach in such cases where there is obvious considerable doubt about whether a benefit has been correctly paid. I note that the good work of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has forced the government to move amendments removing the retrospective element from this part of the bill.

The coalition welcomes the initiative in this bill that will allow the widow B pension to be paid to recent widows in receipt of other benefits without requiring them to go through the process of making a totally new claim. The government should be commended for this initiative, which will reduce stress on these people during a very difficult time in their lives.

We also welcome the fact that, finally, a social security agreement has been signed with Italy. However, I am concerned about the amount of taxpayers' money that has been spent in travel costs for ministers and bureaucrats in relation to this agreement. With phones, faxes and other modern means of communication, and with consulate staff and, I believe, even some social security staff being located in Italy, it is questionable whether as many politicians and departmental officers needed to jet around the world to finalise this agreement.

This bill makes relatively minor changes to confidentiality provisions in the principal act. In effect, these changes will mean that it will be an offence to disclose protected information even if the information is innocently obtained. The definition of protected information will be extended to include information that reveals that a person is not known to the department.

The coalition has been at the forefront of criticising the lack of effective legislation to protect the confidentiality of client information. We were instrumental in setting up a Senate inquiry in 1991, prior to the ICAC report that was so very critical of this department, and long before the corporate conscience of this government was finally pricked and the government was forced into taking action.

It must be recognised that Social Security has taken positive action to strengthen its legislation in relation to the confidentiality of client information. This is more than can said for some Commonwealth agencies handling client information—confidential client information in particular. However, legislation is not the only weapon that bureaucracies have at their disposal to protect what is often sensitive information on clients held by them. It is just as important—probably more important—that effective administrative practices are put in place to prevent the unauthorised disclosure of confidential information and to detect people who disclose such information, usually for their own financial gain.

It is in the area of adopting appropriate administrative safeguards that the auditor, in his Efficiency audit report No. 23 of 1993-94, revealed that this department was grossly deficient. It would be appreciated if the minister informed the Senate as to what action the department is taking to overcome the deficiencies outlined in that report of the auditor.

While the coalition supports the confidentiality provisions, I wish to comment briefly on the removal of the 15 sitting days requirement for ministerial determinations relating to public interest disclosures. This amendment may be needed to facilitate this process effectively. However, it removes the important double lock on such disclosures resulting in far greater reliance on ministerial and bureaucratic discretion. In relation to such issues, the buck must stop with the minister. I assure the Senate that the coalition will monitor very closely the impact of this amendment.

Having disposed of the initiatives that the coalition will be supporting, I wish to turn my attention to those which we will be either opposing or seeking to amend. This bill sets up a new penalty interest charge regime that will apply to ex-clients who refuse to reach an agreement with the department in relation to repayment of debts. This new penalty interest charge, which will be imposed at an annual rate of 20 per cent, will replace the previous one-off additional administrative charge that was imposed on debts unpaid after three months at a rate of $15 plus 10 per cent with a ceiling of $515.

The coalition does not oppose the concept of a penalty interest charge. We believe that measure will introduce a fairer and more appropriate incentive for ex-clients to take positive action to repay debts to Social Security. However, we are very concerned about a number of matters in relation to the administration of this penalty interest charge. In particular, we are concerned that as yet there are no guidelines for administering this charge. In fact, there is no requirement in the legislation for guidelines to be formulated at all.

Social Security has indicated to a Senate committee that it will administer the charge in a commonsense way. But we are not willing to take that for granted. Hence, we will move amendments to require the formulation and use of guidelines in administering this charge. We will also seek to have these guidelines tabled in both houses of parliament as disallowable instruments. We also support the amendments of the Australian Democrats, reflecting recommendations 3 and 4 of the Welfare Rights organisation's submission in relation to this matter.

This bill also seeks to impose the apportionment rule on a liability that exists in relation to an asset that is in part exempt for the purposes of the assets test. The government is claiming that this provision, which will impose a more rigorous test on assets used for primary production, merely gives effect to its stated intention when the original legislation was passed by parliament. The coalition is flabbergasted—it is very difficult to find a word, but I suppose that is an adequate one—that this government claims that the current assets test treats primary producers far more generously than other clients. On the contrary, we contend that the assets test does not take into account the dire circumstances of many farmers, including the fact that they are totally unable to realise these assets. We will oppose this miserly measure. As I said, some of my colleagues will address this particular issue in more detail.

The coalition will also oppose two measures in this bill that are directly relevant to the current review of the pension income and assets test. First, this bill seeks to provide that certain assets—namely, the value of certain life interests—will not be disregarded in calculating the value of a person's assets. Secondly, the bill seeks to ensure that the assessable period of a non-client partner is taken into account when a client realises a saved non-superannuation investment. As I said, both of these measures directly relate to the current review. The coalition is of the opinion that it is entirely inappropriate for the government to be continually tinkering with the income and assets test while this review is being conducted. For this reason, we will oppose both these initiatives.

In conclusion, I reiterate that this bill is not an overly controversial or significant piece of legislation. However, as I said, the particular issue of rural families is of very great concern to the coalition. As a result of the close scrutiny that we have given to the bill, we will be moving the amendments that I have foreshadowed in the committee stage. I will address some of the issues in more detail at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 contains 13 parts. As with most of these broad-ranging social security bills, some amendments contained within the bills the Democrats support and others we believe should be amended or opposed. We welcome the extension of the mobility allowance to those people participating in a competitive employment placement and training program who are funded outside the disability reform package. We also welcome the clarification over AAT stay orders contained in part 3, and the extension of the confidentiality provisions in part 6.

PARA.TAB: We are pleased to see that widows who are eligible for a widow B pension will, under certain circumstances, be paid that pension without the need to submit an application form. Those circumstances include when women are on a wife's or carer's pension immediately before their partner dies. It should be noted, however, that in line with the government's phasing out of the widow B pension many people currently on the carers pension will find that they do not qualify for this pension.

I have tried to understand the philosophy behind the phasing out of the widow B pension, but I think we need to recognise the unique circumstances many of these women are in and make provisions for that. In particular, I refer to the position of women who may have been on a carers pension for many years and find that, when their spouse dies, they are put onto a Jobsearch allowance. Not only does this mean they are thrown back into a job market that they may not have been in for over 20 years, but also that they lose the fringe benefits provided under the carer's pension. We need to ensure that some highly specialised labour market programs are available to these women. We may need to look at some limited extension of fringe benefits to them.

A number of representations from constituents have been received by me on this issue, and I intend to spend some time examining it further this year. In fact, I have been asked—and not because I sought but simply because of the concern in the community—to speak on a number of programs where around Australia people are telling stories about the disadvantage which they are suffering.

The most ridiculous situation brought to my attention is that of a number of women in Rockhampton, central Queensland. One of these women in her mid-50s, after caring for her spouse for some years, on his death discovered she was put on a Jobsearch allowance and had to engage in various training programs, one of which was to restore her self-confidence, and so spent two days learning karate. She was then supposed to spend another week in front of a computer, despite the fact that she had no keyboard skills and no idea what computers were about. Before the end of that week she dissolved in tears and had to absent herself from the program.

Another woman told me that she was given $70 to outfit herself so that she could be more presentable to employers. She, of course, pointed out that she would be competing with many young people who would certainly benefit from the outfitting. Her very clear complaint was that `there are no jobs for me'.

The measures that I have mentioned—that is, the extension of the mobility allowance, the clarification of AAT stay orders, the tightening of the confidentiality provisions and the automatic granting of the widow B pension in certain circumstances—are all beneficial measures for clients, and as such will be supported.

I turn to some of the measures contained in the bill which the Democrats are not so keen to support. Part 5 seeks to establish a new penalty regime for those with outstanding debts to the Department of Social Security. I am certainly glad to see the repeal of the existing mandatory charge, as it most unfairly discriminated against those with a low capacity to repay loans—particularly those who are still on a social security pension or benefit.

Under the proposed system, a penalty interest charge will be applied to those non-client debtors who do not enter into an agreement to repay their debt or breach an existing agreement. However, it seems to me that the new system places no clearly defined requirement on the department to make an effort to enter into negotiation with the client. Although I am sure that this is unlikely, it would be possible under the proposed legislation for the department to simply phone the person's home and, if it fails to contact him or her, send out a notice the next day stating its intention to impose a penalty interest charge on the person for failing to enter into an agreement to repay the debt.

We need to ensure that the department issues these notices to impose the penalty only after it has made a reasonable attempt to enter negotiation with the client and has determined that the person is either refusing to enter negotiation or will not accept a reasonable repayment schedule.

Again, I need to say that I have had representation from people who have said that in their experience with the department it is not simply that they have not been contacted but, rather, when they have tried to contact the department and point out their situation they have entered into the most amazing comedy of errors on the part of the department, which almost boggles the imagination.

I also think the time period in which the penalty interest charge for those who breach their existing agreements needs to be more clearly set out in the legislation, and I foreshadow that I will be moving some amendments to part 5 at the committee stage. Part 4 of the bill will create a debt to the Department of Social Security where a person has been paid a pension or benefit during an AAT stay order, but the appeal is ultimately unsuccessful. In other words, the department will be allowed to recover money it paid to the person in the period between an SSAT ruling and an AAT decision which goes in the department's favour.

It is my understanding that, to date, it has been recognised that payments made while a stay order is in force are not recoverable as debts as they are deemed to have been legally granted. Indeed, payments under a stay order of the SSAT—that is, while the hearing is in progress—are not recoverable, even when the SSAT's decision is to affirm the original departmental decision. In the case of sole parent pensioners, the department is required to continue to make payments while the appeal is being determined. Again, these payments do not become debts.

This bill seeks to change this practice at the final level of appeal—that is, the stage between the SSAT and the AAT. Thus, an inconsistency will be introduced by this legislation which the Democrats fear the government may seek to rectify in the future by also making those payments under the SSAT stay order recoverable debts. The estimated savings on this measure are minimal, and will have no budgetary effect. The effect on the few people to come under this provision will be significant, and the Democrats will be opposing this part.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—You will like the next bit even better, Senator Boswell. Part 7 of the bill deals with the assets test as it relates to primary producers. The view of the Democrats in this area is well known to all in the Senate. The Democrats have always believed that the assets test unfairly discriminates against primary producers and on numerous occasions we have sought to rectify this problem by exempting the family farm from the test. When we realise that the average value of a sheep farm in Australia is around $850,000, the average dairy farm around $880,000, a broadacre farm around $900,000 and a beef farm over $1 million, one can see how farmers are shut out of the social security system purely by virtue of working an asset which this government chooses to include in the assets test. We have to remember that the farm is a working asset.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have always been opposed by the government in our attempts to exempt the family farm from the assets test—and opposed, on occasions, by the opposition. Given that, I was somewhat surprised to read the comments of the shadow minister for social security in the House of Representatives debate on this bill. He said that members of the opposition `think the imposition of the assets test generally on primary productive properties is harsh'.

That is a surprise to us because those opposite have not supported some of the amendments which we have suggested and which have been designed to ease some of that harshness. In line with our belief that the assets test unfairly discriminates against our primary producers we will support any move which grants a concession to farmers under the assets test. As I have said, we have tried on numerous times to address this problem constructively. We hope the government will note our concern and will give a commitment to look into this further and address the problem. We will be opposing part 7 of the legislation. Finally, the explanatory memorandum states that part 9 of this bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: where a non-client partner realises a `saved' non-superannuation investment, the growth (or loss) on the investment that is attributable to the client is the longer of the assessable period for the client or the assessable period for the client's partner.

I have no idea what that means. If that is in the explanatory memorandum, God help those trying to understand it. However, my staff were able to explain it to me. Apparently the government claims that this amendment simply reflects the practice of the Department of Social Security since 1987 to calculate growth over the longer of these two periods, and that it was an omission in the amendments made in December 1992 that inadvertently removed the legislative basis for doing so.

PARA.TAB: In simple terms, however, the effect of part 9 will be to reduce the entitlement to DSS payments of those holding investments such as managed investments. As there is a major review to be undertaken of the income and assets testing regime, any tightening in this area, no matter how small, seems unwarranted at this time. Given also that apparently so few people will be affected and there are no financial implications from the measure, there seems little risk in delaying it until that review is completed, particularly as managed investments will be closely examined at that inquiry. So the Democrats will be opposing part 9 of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, which imposes new debt apportionment measures. These measures will make it even harder for rural families to qualify for benefits such as the jobsearch allowance and the age pension. A couple of nights ago on Four Corners we were treated to an expose of Labor's neglect of poor rural electorates in its divvying up of sports grants. Today the government is asking the Senate to entrench Labor's anti-rural syndrome in legislation. The decision to allocate social security benefits to urban Labor electorates while denying the same rights to families in National Party seats is being written on a page of Hansard as opposed to a whiteboard, but the principle is still the same.

PARA.TAB: Let us consider the lot of two families, the Smiths from the city and the Joneses from the country. The city Smiths live in a leafy suburb with nearby parks, sporting facilities, cinemas, shops, schools, hospitals, dentists, sewerage, water and public transport. The country Joneses live on a property 150 kilometres from the nearest town. If it is a Queensland town it has probably recently lost its courthouse, railway workers, doctor, policeman and DPI station. One bank has already shut its doors, the postal service is threatened, and the school has just lost another teacher. The Jones beef and sheep property has shown a substantial loss for three years running and is coming up for a fourth, due to the drought. They have been feeding dwindling stock for three years.

Mrs Jones is at her wits end trying to teach the younger children through School of the Air and keeping up with on-farm work commitments because they cannot afford hired help. The eldest boy has been pulled out of boarding school to help run the place. His older sister is in the city and has gone on the dole because she cannot get Austudy due to her parents' assets. Over the years the Joneses and their parents and grandparents have contributed millions of dollars of export income to Australia—which has helped finance the expansion of city services. The banks are on their back for interest payments. Mr Jones manages to get some cash income from shooting feral goats. Eighteen months ago they liquidated their remaining non-essential asset—Mr Jones's insurance policy.

It is March 1994. Mr Smith in the city is retrenched from his job. Having little assets apart from the family home he quickly qualifies for JSA and starts a retraining program. His wife is hopeful of finding part-time work. It is not easy to meet repayments and they have to cut down their weekly expenditure. The Joneses, meanwhile, are facing some difficult decisions. The rural adjustment scheme which last year considered them viable in the long-term has just notified them that they will not be receiving an interest subsidy any longer; they cannot prove that they have been operating profitability for two of the last five years.

In light of this downturn, the bank—which in Queensland also administers the RAS scheme on behalf of the federal government—has rung them to say it is thinking of foreclosing and it has received an offer of $5 an acre—well below the current valuation of the property. The lender advises them to sell. The RAS administrator, sometimes also a lender, advises them to apply for farm household support to keep food on the table while they sell up, and then apply for a re-establishment grant to help purchase a house when they move out to an unknown place with unknown job prospects, or they can apply for JSA or, if old enough, the pension.

The Joneses have known that this decision was coming and it has caused them a great deal of distress. Mrs Jones is very worried about her husband who is very depressed. She hopes he does not turn violent as some of their neighbours have done. She hopes her son does not become too affected by their problems and suicides, like her young cousin. She is not looking forward to contacting the drought community centre the next day and being put on their charity list for food credit. She knows the woman who runs that centre and that makes it worse, but at least she will get a trip to town, thanks to the donated petrol voucher from the Red Cross. She misses not ringing her sister, but the phone bill would be too high. She is worried that the younger children are behind in their school work and that she does not spend enough time with them.

With the assistance of the rural counsellor whom they have waited six months to see, they pore over the paperwork. They decide that since $5 an acre would still leave them with money owing, they will try to hang on and get something out of their investment. It would take only a couple of good seasons and they would be back on top again. They look at the conditions of taking farm household support; it is like JSA for nine months but then it becomes a loan until they have sold up, and it is available for only two years.

The Joneses do not like their chances of selling up within nine months at a fair price, so they would be taking another loan if they took farm household support. This is anathema to them. They feel like a gun is being held to their heads: `Sell up or pay back your living allowance'. When the government first introduced the farm household support it announced that it expected 1,400 farmers to go on it in the first year. Eleven months later, in August 1993, there were 380 families receiving farm household support. These were also the toughest times in rural Australia.

In the first six months of 1993, there were 136 approvals for re-establishment grants at a cost of $5.7 million. At the same time, there were 519 approvals for interest subsidies under normal RAS which cost $6.3 million. It cost nearly as much to throw 136 people off the land as it did to keep 519 going.

So the Joneses turn to the JSA conditions. There will be great difficulty meeting the assets test they are told, but if they are prepared to go through the appeal process, which takes up to six months to get valuations and so forth, they might just make it. Mrs Jones decides to apply, although the idea of being on the dole is very foreign. Nevertheless, food on the table is the top priority. Because she lives so far from town, she will have to approach neighbours who are worse off than she is for work in order to fulfil the JSA conditions of seeking employment.

The Joneses are warned, however, that if they stay on JSA for longer than nine months they forfeit their access to any re-establishment grant if they are forced to leave after all. They are given another piece of advice by an ex-neighbour who now squats in the old shearer's shed on their property. If they do have to leave, they must go quietly and not put up any fuss about the purchase price or they could endanger receiving their re-establishment benefit. The RAS administrator—also a lender in Queensland, the QIDC—has the power to knock back applications if the farmer does not leave the property in a so-called orderly fashion. The Joneses' newly acquired sundowner explains that he kicked up a fuss, was sold up for a song and he still owed money, but was refused a re-establishment grant because of his so-called disorderly behaviour.

The Joneses decide that their only alternative is to try for JSA and hope that the seasons turn around in time for them to show some improvement before nine months are up. In May 1993 the government's best estimate of the number of farmers or their spouses on JSA was between 4,000 and 4,500. When Mrs Jones rings up the next day to further inquire about the JSA, she uses the freephone service which eventually connects her to a social security officer in Perth who has no knowledge of rural conditions. Mrs Jones goes to town to find out more from the local community centre where a rural access grant pays a part-time salary to a drought relief coordinator who works 60 hours a week, but, unfortunately, the grant will end in June.

Mrs Jones has to wait a while until the community worker is free. The worker's logbook shows a daily personal workload of over 30 face-to-face calls and interviews for assistance and Mrs Jones notices that the phone never stops ringing. The community worker has bad news for Mrs Jones, and this news is what brings me to the section of the social security legislation that we are concentrating on at the moment.

Mrs Jones is told that the government has tightened the assets test by a process called debt apportionment which means that some debt will be apportioned to the family home, even though their loan was to purchase additional land as a drought minimising strategy, following advice from their lender in the 1980s. The new arrangement sounds the death knell for Mrs Jones's hopes of accessing any benefits that would help her put food on the table that was not another loan. The community worker is sympathetic but harassed at the thought of telling so many that they will not be able to access JSA if this legislation goes through. The phone rings and it is the QIDC with an unclear answer on whether a client who has been receiving JSA for longer than nine months might still access a re-establishment grant. She asks: what if the client was only on JSA for nine months one year and wants to go back on JSA the following year for nine months? Would the client still qualify for a re-establishment grant? Someone will get back to her.

The phone rings again—this time it is a woman on JSA wanting to know why she can go on a pension at 60 but her husband cannot automatically get one, when a man who has been on JSA for 12 months and turns 60 will get a mature age pension and his wife will automatically get the pension. She feels discriminated against and wishes that her husband had gone onto JSA instead of her. The community worker sighs, remembering how the woman on the phone used to be the district's most efficient producer and Landcare advocate. Now her property is one of the worst degraded areas and is overrun with feral animals and woody weeds.

Mrs Jones looks at her watch. The community worker turns back to her and writes out a fuel voucher so that Mrs Jones can afford the petrol for the trip home. The worker hands Mrs Jones another slip of paper which is good for credit at the local food store to the amount of $85. `That's all this month', she says, `and next month, we just don't know'.

Late last year there were 1,000 families depending on food parcels to survive in south-west Queensland. There are now 160 in the Miles district alone using the new credit system which replaced the system of distributing 18 tonnes of food a month. The CWA and Rotary which have been largely funding the credit—which is supplemented by bread, fruit and vegetable subsidies or donations—fear that there will be very little left for the next month. Poverty is spreading in central Queensland and their dwindling resources are spread too thinly.

Mrs Jones gets her groceries. She looks longingly at some talcum powder but resists and buys powdered milk instead. She fills up the car and begins the two-hour drive home. She is not beaten yet. Perhaps she could move to town and find some work there while her husband still works the property. But what about the children and their day care? What work could she do? What work is left to do? Mrs Jones drives home.

In September 1992, there were 15,000 primary producers on RAS, mostly receiving interest subsidies. The government expected two things to happen: firstly, that there would be 3,000 to 4,000 new entrants. In the first six months of the new RAS, there were 519 approvals for interest subsidies under normal circumstances. Temporary exceptional circumstances funding was introduced and took up a lot of the slack. But that finishes soon and the eligibility guidelines have been tightened anyway. The second thing the government expected was that between 6,000 and 7,000 farmers would finish their RAS contracts that year—1992-93. In November 1993, I asked what had happened to those 6,000 to 7,000 families no longer receiving RAS. I was told that the government does not monitor the affairs of farmers who are no longer in receipt of RAS support. I was told that for those who are not eligible for RAS, farm household support and other welfare programs are available.

In the wool industry, exceptional circumstances RAS has been aimed at 30 per cent of the nation's specialist woolgrowers. The rest are left to manage as best they can. Only one quarter of the industry has no debt. It was impossible with the wool prices of the last four years to have made a profit on wool. Graingrowers in Queensland have made heavy losses every year of the drought currently in its third devastating year. Thank God, as I make this speech, it is raining in Queensland. Over 50 per cent of Queensland was drought declared. So there are literally thousands in similar situations to the Joneses. Senator Lees told us the other day that a third of South Australia's farmers are living on or below the poverty line. The government insists that there are welfare programs available.

Farm household support has been a miserable failure. It has been shunned by a community already up to its neck in debt without needing the government to offer it more debt. JSA is a highly sought after prize in the rural survival stakes. First, the government phased out the modified JSA provisions. Now, today, it is removing the last vestiges of hope for many rural families by tightening eligibility still further.

If these rural families were crucial to Labor's chances in marginal Labor electorates, would this be happening to them? Do people on the dole in Bankstown have to pay back their equivalent to household support after nine months? They do if they are family farmers in Gwydir. Are benefit recipients in Swan restricted to a two-year limit? They are if they are family farmers in O'Connor. Do people in Bowman have to sell up their houses before their living allowance becomes a grant? They do if they are on household support in Maranoa. Are the recipients of income support in Hotham working 12 hours a day, seven days a week, to keep export producing properties alive? They are in Mallee—that is, if they can get some income support.

Under a Labor government this bias towards Labor electoral interests has become institutionalised. The sports rorts are just the tip of a gigantic iceberg. Labor is doing a gilooley on family farmers—kneecapping them to stop them competing. As the Queensland government submission to the RAS advisory council in November 1993 said:

SPEECH.PARA: Social security Jobsearch allowance is not available to most families due to complex eligibility criteria and extended assessment processes, whilst other income support measures are seen widely as additional debt.

In response, the federal government is tightening JSA eligibility still further, knowing full well that the only alternative is the farm household support, and it is useful only as a living allowance while selling up and leaving the land.

PARA.TAB: What it boils down to in the end is, if you cannot get RAS, then you have to get out. How do the country Joneses keep up with the city Smiths?

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator Patterson and Senator Boswell in foreshadowing our opposition to clause 27 of this legislation, which will effectively lessen the likelihood of members of farm families getting social security benefits such as unemployment benefits and the pension.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, in these recent years of rural recession, it has become necessary for many farmers and their families to apply for government assistance in the form of social security. In the period 1990-91, the average broadacre farm net equity was $734,886. For the same period the farm business profit for all broadacre farms was negative $24,838.

For the following period we see the same pattern. In 1991-92 average broadacre farm net equity was $784,760, yet farm business profit was once again in the red at negative $23,810. The 1993 farm survey states that, on average, broadacre farms are expected to record a third consecutive year with business loss. All industries are expected to record lower average farm business profit in 1993-94.

While farms with high equity positions have, for the most part, been able to maintain their financial positions, farms with lower equity have seen a sharp reduction in their position over the past three years. Where farmers and their families are in the income and assets test levels placing them in the possible range for social security, as we have seen from the graphic illustration provided by Senator Boswell, this amendment could come into force.

There is a necessity for a level of debt in order that farmers maintain productivity. If farmers are to improve their income potential, even in bad times, as much money as possible needs to go back into the farm for fertiliser, fencing, the purchase of stud stock and machinery and the improvement of water resources. Most farmers are asset rich in terms of the land they hold, and yet they are income poor, as the average figures I quoted earlier will substantiate.

In fact, as the earlier figures indicate, on average farmers are in debt. There is very little left over for personal use. Farmers' capacity for personal expenditure is very much reduced, and many must borrow in order to maintain the productivity of the farm.

This amending bill requires the Department of Social Security to apportion debt on the basis of what the borrowings are secured against. So if a farmer had taken out a loan for farm land, the Department of Social Security must now allocate a portion of this debt against the farmhouse. Therefore the government's method of debt apportionment would unfairly make a farm family's assets levels appear higher than they really are. Clearly all the farm debt should instead be offset against the farm assets in calculating eligibility.

The government's bill would mean that many farm families, and particularly farm women, would be ruled out for social security entitlements that they should be eligible for. Rural women, as part of farming families, have always worked in some capacity on the farm as wives, mothers, and as partners in the many and varied day-to-day tasks of farm life. But in recent years we have seen the movement of farm women into employment off the farm, and often at some geographical distance from it. They have embarked on this in order to supplement the farm income which, as I indicated earlier, has fallen dramatically in recent times. Many of these women are trained teachers, nurses or other professionals, and are able to return to their former careers. Others are not so fortunate. They must search for work, and often only find it after some time. They are just as deserving as urban women of the jobsearch allowance and yet, under this proposed legislation, they will be denied it because the asset level of the property has been artificially inflated.

Farm women are the silent sufferers on farms when times are tough and income is scarce. It is appalling that the Department of Social Security could attempt to worsen this situation with this amendment, which would deny farm women their fair and legitimate entitlement to social security assistance.

The coalition view is that the assets test in relation to rural property owners should be revised in any case. The impact of this proposal is to impose a rigorous assets test on primary producer property owners who are already in necessitous circumstances. For this reason, the coalition opposes this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the second reading debate. For the purpose of saving time and ensuring the speedy passage of this legislation, I will not make an extensive comment now, but will respond during the debate at the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: However, there is one matter that I believe I should address at this stage and that is in response to Senator Patterson, who asked, `Who is eligible for mobility allowance, and who is not?'. Section 103(5) of the Social Security Act 1991 sets out who is qualified for a mobility allowance. Rather than read out that section, as it is quite lengthy, I draw the honourable senator's attention to it. I would certainly be able to offer to honourable senators any assistance they may require with further questions on mobility allowance, if they would like to put those on notice.

Senator Patterson also sought information on the action being taken in regard to Efficiency Audit Report No. 23. I do not have that information to hand, but I will ensure that it is provided to Senator Patterson. As I said, I think the Senate would be assisted if I made more specific comments during the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other day Senator Lees was quite critical of us for not moving amendments to the previous social security bill, and for suggesting in an amendment I moved in the second reading debate that the government draw up a series of quite complex amendments to address an issue. Senator Lees said, `Well, I don't know what is the matter with the opposition. We get our amendments done and we can manage it with our limited resources'. Here is an example of the very thing I was talking about. When we do not have the resources and the legal expertise—with all due respect to the tremendous work that the clerks and deputy clerks do in assisting us in drafting—it is not always possible for us at short notice to ask all the appropriate `what if' questions and to work through all the unintended consequences. This is a very good example of that, where the government is now having to amend an Australian Democrat amendment.

PARA.TAB: I hope Senator Lees takes note that she criticised me the other day for not moving amendments when I knew that they were very complex, and when I called on the government because of its additional resources to address them. Here is a perfect example of the Democrats having moved an amendment which now has to be amended by the government. The government's amendment will be supported, but I hope the Senate will take note of that and that Senator Lees will be less critical in future because the Democrats are not perfect.
