TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing these clauses in their entirety. These clauses will create a debt to the Department of Social Security where payments are made under an AAT stay order and the AAT ultimately decides in the department's favour. As I pointed out during the second reading debate, payments made under a stay order of the SSAT do not become recoverable even when the SSAT decision is to affirm the original departmental decision. In the case of sole parent pensioners, payments up to the SSAT stage must continue to be paid while the appeal is being determined. These payments do not become debts either. So these clauses seek to implement different arrangements for payments made under an AAT stay order from those that will apply for payments under an SSAT order. Thus there will be an inconsistency introduced into the legislation.

PARA.TAB: One of the concerns I have is that some time in the future the government will seek to remove that inconsistency by making payments made under an SSAT stay order recoverable as debts as well. It has to be remembered that for a stay to be granted people need to convince a member of the AAT of the merits of their case: that is, in the view of an AAT member there has to be at least some chance of the appeal being successful. Thus, when a stay is granted, the client is given the impression that the application is a valid one and proceeds on that basis, including the detailed preparation for the AAT hearing.

The explanatory memorandum indicates that this measure is to have no budgetary effect. I suspect the reason for that is the very small number of people to be affected. I think the department estimated that there would be about 10 people subject to these provisions. While the overall budgetary effect is to be minimal, the effect on those 10 people could be quite significant, particularly in view of the fact that AAT hearings can often take several months to be concluded.

Some people may argue that if these clauses are defeated then we will be providing an incentive to people to pursue their appeals right through to the AAT stage in the knowledge that it will extend their payment period with no need to repay if the appeal is unsuccessful. I do not believe that this is a valid argument, however, as the decision as to whether a stay is granted is made by an AAT member, and this specifically excludes those making frivolous claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting the Democrats because the coalition is of the opinion that it is inappropriate that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal grant a stay in proceedings resulting in a benefit to be continued if the Social Security Appeals Tribunal has reaffirmed a decision by the department. For this reason we will not be supporting the Democrats.

—The government does not accept that permitting recovery of debts arising from AAT stay orders will act as a disincentive to anybody thinking of appealing to the AAT. It should be understood that the issue of whether it is appropriate for the AAT then to grant a stay order is quite separate. The stay order option should not be an avenue for a client to simply continue to receive payments for as long as possible regardless of the strength of his or her case. In making decisions on stay orders, the AAT is required to take into account the interests of any person who may be affected by the review of the decision being appealed. It is more likely that the AAT would refuse a stay order if money wrongly paid cannot be recovered.

PARA.TAB: I think it should be possible to recover wrongly expended money where a person has the capacity to repay it. But I am assured that the department has no intention of enforcing recovery from those clients not in a position to repay that debt. If there is a question about a person's capacity to pay, it is possible for payments to be made by instalments or for the debt to be written off. Decisions taken under the act about these matters may be appealed.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —As those of us who have been working behind the scenes on this bill know, we had drafted some amendments on this issue and, with advice from the department and the minister's office, those amendments were not going to achieve what we hoped to achieve. In fact, it was claimed in discussions that the issue that we were concerned about was not a problem and that it was dealt with in the bill. Just to be doubly sure, so we have it on the record, I seek an assurance from the minister that there no possibility of the application of a double jeopardy. I would like an assurance that people who have had a three-month additional administration charge applied to them but who have negotiated a repayment agreement with the department will not now be forced to reach a new agreement under the new system under the threat of a new penalty interest charge.

PARA.TAB: We do not consider it inappropriate that people who have had the old administration charge applied to them but are still refusing to negotiate an agreement be required to negotiate under the threat of a new penalty interest charge. However, if a prior repayment agreement has been reached, we do not consider it right for the department to use a new regime to get a new agreement under threat of a penalty interest charge. We would like that to be clarified on the record because we have been told off the record that that is not the case. Could the minister place her interpretation of this bill on the record so that it is clear and our concerns are addressed?

TALK.START.PARA: —A penalty interest charge will be applied only when a debtor no longer receiving a social security payment refuses to make repayments when they have the capacity to do so. Accordingly, it is not appropriate to exempt people from the potential application of the charge. The former charge had a different purpose from the charge that we are debating. This proposal is an incentive to repay a debt; it is not a charge for administering a debt.

PARA.TAB: Saving those who have had the old charge applied would be contrary to the rationale for this proposal. It would create inequities, and there would be no incentive to repay the debt. The department will be forced to resort to other provisions, such as the garnishee provisions, if it cannot use the penalty interest charge on those people whose debts are over three months old. Otherwise these people will be able to continue to ignore the department or just stop the payments they are now making.

The government believes that the proposed penalty interest charge provides a regime which is fair to the client and the Commonwealth. Other provisions, such as the garnishee provisions, are clearly harsher on clients. I wonder whether that assists Senator Patterson?

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator Crowley give me an assurance that, under the current amendments, where someone has already negotiated an agreement under the old system, and is doing the right thing by making repayments, he or she will not be required to renegotiate that agreement and make repayments at a faster rate? If a person gets angry or concerned about this, and he or she appears not to be cooperating, I want to know whether the old agreement stands. I want to make sure that that person is not in double jeopardy if he or she is repaying in good faith.
—Senator Patterson can be assured that, if people are repaying under an agreement in good faith, they are not in any jeopardy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 8, page 4, at the end of proposed paragraph 1229(1)(b), add the following word and paragraphs:
"and (c) the Secretary makes reasonable attempts to negotiate an agreement with the person; and
"(d) the person:

TAB.TAB: (i)is unwilling to enter into negotiation for such an agreement; or
(ii)following such negotiation, does not agree to repayment of the debt by reasonable instalments, being instalments reasonably within the person's capacity to pay the debt;"

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been said under this clause, if a person does not enter into an agreement within 14 days of receiving a notice requesting them to do so, a penalty interest charge can be imposed on them. However, there is no legislative requirement on the department to make any effort to enter into negotiation with the client before sending that notice. The only prerequisites set out in the legislation are, one, that the person is not receiving a social security payment and, two, that the person owes a debt to the Commonwealth. So the department could—I stress could—send out these notices to people without any real effort beforehand to come to some agreement with them.

PARA.TAB: Our amendment seeks to provide that the department can send out a notice stating its intention to apply a penalty interest charge only after it has made a reasonable attempt to enter negotiation with the client and has determined that the person is either refusing to enter into negotiation or will not accept a reasonable repayment schedule. This at least places some obligation on the department to make an effort to enter into negotiation with the client. The department may claim that this provision is covered in its guidelines, but I believe it is preferable to have such provisions in the legislation as it gives more direction to senior officers and to appeals tribunals and more consistency throughout the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would have been clear from my speech in the second reading debate that, although there should be guidelines, we agree with the Democrats that this provision should be put into the legislation. Often we leave things to the discretion of the minister or senior bureaucrats that should be in the legislation, and this is an example of that. Even though the department says it will be covered in the guidelines, on this occasion the coalition agrees with the Democrats that it should be in the legislation.

—Penalty interest will not be applied to debtors who are still negotiating an agreement unless they are deliberately stalling recovery action. The legislation specifically provides a discretion for this in sections 1229(3) and 1229A(3). The department will determine agreements based on what debtors can afford to pay after all reasonable expenses have been allowed. The imposition of the charge will not be automatic; it will be applied on a case by case basis by experienced officers. The government does not strongly object to a welfare rights proposal, except for the proposed early use of garnishee provisions; it simple believes that this point is more appropriately incorporated in guidelines. So we oppose the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 8, page 4, line 35, proposed paragraph 1229(1)(d), omit "interest may become payable on the debt", substitute "a garnishee notice may be given to another person or interest may become payable on the debt;"
4.Clause 8, page 5, at the end of proposed subsection 1229(6), add the following subsection:
"(6A) A person is to be taken to have entered into an agreement under section 1229A if the Secretary has:

TAB.TAB: (a)issued a notice under section 1229(1); and
(b)subsequently issued a notice under section 1233.".

SPEECH.PARA: The department is currently able to recover debts by garnisheeing from others who hold money for, or owe money to, a debtor. We believe that this is yet another step that the department should be required to explore before issuing a notice for a penalty interest charge. Where the department can recover its money via this means, there will be no need for a penalty interest charge. We believe it is appropriate that the department follow this course.

TALK.START.PARA: —For very similar reasons that I gave for supporting the previous amendment of the Democrats, the coalition also supports these two amendments.
—As I have said already, the government remains of the view that these points are more appropriately incorporated in the guidelines. Therefore, we do not support this amendment of the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 8, page 6, line 25, after "subsection (3)", add "and (3A)".
6.Clause 8, page 6, at the end of proposed subsection 1229A(3), add the following subsection:
"(3A) Interest payable under subsection (2) ceases to accrue on and from the day the person:

PARA.TAB: (a)next pays the instalment due under an agreement; or
(b)enters into a new agreement;

SPEECH.PARA: whichever first occurs.".

The purpose of these amendments is to more clearly define in the legislation the period for which a penalty interest charge will be applied to those who breach an existing agreement. The period is set down for those who fail to enter into an agreement to apply from the 14th day after a notice is issued until a person enters an agreement. While the start date for someone who defaults on an agreement is once again 14 days after a notice is issued, there is no definitive time at which the penalty interest charge is to cease to apply. Instead, there is just a general discretion to the secretary under section 1237.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the department's policy will be to apply the period from 14 days after the notice is issued until a person either enters into a new agreement or commences repayments at the previous rate, but this does not appear in the legislation. Our amendment seeks to place these provisions into the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —For similar reasons to those I put in the debate on the previous amendments moved by the Democrats, the coalition will support the amendments.

—For very similar reasons to those I have already given, the government will not be accepting the amendments. I remind Senator Woodley I have been advised that there has not been a great deal of time to look at some of these amendments. On the best advice to this point, some of these amendments will not be possible to put into what I am advised is called black-letter law. They will be much better dealt with under the flexibility of guidelines. For these reasons, the government will be opposing these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 8, page 7, after proposed section 1229B, add the following new section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Guidelines on the penalty interest charge scheme

SPEECH.PARA: "1229C.(1) The Minister must, not later than 1 July 1994, and thereafter from time to time, by notice in writing determine Guidelines for the operation of the provisions of this Act dealing with Penalty Interest Charge.
(2) A notice under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.".

The coalition moves this amendment to ensure that there are guidelines formulated by the department—I referred to these guidelines in my speech on the second reading—for the purposes of administering the penalty interest charge. The department said that it would be using guidelines. However, often the guidelines are neither available to the parliament nor to the people affected by them. In this instance, it will make the guidelines a very public document, which means that people will be very clear about the circumstances surrounding the requirements to comply with this legislation. The amendments also have the effect that these guidelines be tabled in both houses of parliament and that they be a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting opposition amendment No.1. We are happy to support any move which increases the level of scrutiny that this parliament has over the operation of such schemes as the penalty interest charge. I apologise to the minister for the lateness of circulation of our amendments.

—I appreciate that. It does not make it easier, but it is helped by the apology and I thank Senator Woodley for it. The government does not accept opposition amendment No. 1; we believe it is unnecessary. The department already consults with welfare rights on guidelines. It has agreed to provide the guidelines to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. If the guidelines are subject to tabling and disallowance—and don't I know!—it will result in delay and uncertainty. The government believes that the existing consultation and scrutiny mechanisms are adequate and therefore opposes this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 26—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 27.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes clause 27 which seeks to impose a harsh assets test on primary producers. The amendment seeks to impose an apportionment test on assets that are, in part, exempt from the assets test. The government contends that this was its original intention when it made amendments at an earlier date in relation to the treatment of assets used in primary production, and the coalition does not dispute this point. However, we contend that the current assets test in relation to rural property is too harsh. I mentioned that in my speech on the second reading and my colleagues have expanded on that. The current assets test should be reviewed. Also, farmers organisations have expressed their concerns about this provision. Therefore, we will be opposing this clause.

—The Democrats also oppose clause 27 for reasons given in my speech on second reading. We see the farm as a working asset and as such believe it should be exempt from the assets test. The government amendments contained in clause 27 of this bill seek to introduce a new formula to implement the apportionment rule for primary producers. We are not convinced by the government's argument. We are worried that, in fact, the overwhelming majority of farmers have been on the land for many years and will have paid off that part of their original loans that related to their houses—particularly in light of the fact that most farms have very modest houses on them, and that is only if the farmers have had a loan in the first place. Many, of course, will have inherited the farms and may have no debts against them.

PARA.TAB: It is also highly unlikely that any new debt incurred by a farmer will relate to the family farm home. Banks are hardly of an inclination at the moment to lend farmers tens of thousands of dollars to do up their dining rooms. Indeed, figures from the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics indicate that virtually all new debt incurred by farmers is for farm business purposes only—that is, for the purchase of land or working capital for debt reconstruction or for the purchase of plant and livestock. I believe it is unfair for the department to assume that a certain portion of a primary producer's loan will be used to improve the farmer's house. For those reasons, we will vote against this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government certainly opposes removal of this clause from the bill. Both the Democrats and the opposition have failed to recognise that there are already special provisions under the assets test to take account of the particular circumstances of farmers. There are special hardship provisions in the assets test, directed mainly at assisting farmers. Farmers are also able to aggregate their farm assets and liabilities for the purposes of calculating assessable assets. The latter provision, confined only to farmers, enables an excess debt on a particular farm asset—for example, on a harvester—to be offset against the value of other farm producing assets. That is how the concession was first announced in 1991, and no other group gets this special concession.

PARA.TAB: The change in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 does not alter this beneficial treatment of farmers. All it does is make more explicit in the legislation the existing policy that has been in place for many years. That policy requires that where some assets are exempt from the assets test—for example, the farmhouse on a farm—any debts relating to that exempt asset should not be allowed as a deduction. It seems to me a perfectly reasonable and equitable approach.

No-one suggested in 1991 that liabilities related to exempt assets could be used to reduce the value of assessable assets. This amendment has actually arisen from an interpretation of the existing act by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, which suggested that the current wording did not allow the apportioning formula that gives effect to this longstanding policy to apply to farm assets. This is where I think the opposition's hypocrisy is revealed. It argues that there should be no changes to the social security income and assets test pending the outcome of the current review. Then it says, `Let's knock off a simple technical amendment and change the policy'. I would like Senator MacGibbon to be listening at this point, and I hope he is. But this is not just simply a policy change because the opposition wants to scrap one of the basic principles of the assets test.

In fact, both the opposition and the Democrats would be scrapping that basic principle for just one group. It is quite clearly a change of policy and, much worse than that, it will cost about $15 million. If we had to consider the most equitable way to spend $15 million on assistance to farmers, this would certainly not be the way to do it. Under this amendment, farmers with the biggest houses would be the biggest winners. That is not a surprising policy perhaps for the opposition, because it is clearly just a piece of political opportunism by both the opposition and the Democrats.

Unless both the opposition and the Democrats are unaware of what they are doing, I think we would have to say that it is very difficult to understand any consistency in their purpose or intent in opposing this clause. The proposed amendments will not adversely affect any rural farmers. The policy was applied to all farmers currently being assisted by the DSS. It is simply a lie to state that the provision will widen the assets test and exclude some rural farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reply to some of the comments that have been made by Senator Crowley. For instance, she said that farmers already are a privileged group because of the treatment they receive under the taxation act. The basic difference between farmers and other groups in the community—and this is a principle that the government is failing to appreciate time and again—is that at this point in history farmers' assets are providing them with no income whatsoever. Compared to other sectors, such as a person who owns a factory that could be described as an asset in the manufacturing sector, farmers' assets, their land, is providing them with no income. The government, apparently, fails to appreciate this. Therefore, I believe, as the coalition believes, there is a case to be made out for providing this exemption in the amendment outlined by Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, houses do not provide income when they are on a farm unless, as many farmers do at the moment, farmers' wives—and the farmers themselves—are reduced to providing bed and breakfast accommodation for tourists because that is the only income they can afford to make from their farms at the moment. Nothing else is providing an income. Therefore, I ask yet again that the government consider the special category that farmers are in; their assets are not providing them with an income.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for those comments. I always find it interesting when senators start by saying I do not understand something. I do not ever find that a persuasive line. I understand very well that in some situations and from time to time some assets are not producing income. In this case, for some farmers in some places under some circumstances, some of their land is not producing some income. I say to Senator Troeth that does not allow us to deal with a particular problem which is, quite clearly, for a large number of farmers in this country—if it is the case at the moment, and I accept that for some it is—a transitory position. But Senator Troeth wants to change the rules forever. Will Senator Troeth say to the Senate in the future, `Look, they now have a return on their land, so we will remove the amendment'? I do not hear her arguing that. That is the difficulty we face.

PARA.TAB: The government is being asked to have a debt against non-assessable assets taken against their assessable assets. That is a very interesting equation—and all of this from the heart-rending story of some farmers who are not getting a return on their land. We know it is tough for farmers. That is why the government introduced the hardship provisions. Those hardship provisions are much fairer because they actually cover real circumstances for many farmers, but not the big variability in return on assets for farmers.

I do not ever find it persuasive to be told I do not understand. I do understand very well. What I find hard to understand is that those opposite seem to want to amend in perpetuity a distinct advantage for one subset of this community, farmers, against all the others, by breaking a fundamental principle of the assets and incomes test.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause 28.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition opposes clause 28. It regards certain life interests created by wills as an assessable asset. In my speech in the second reading debate I indicated that we would be opposing this clause which seeks to include the value of certain life interests in the assets test. In this clause the government is seeking to ensure that people cannot gain an advantage by converting an absolute interest in property to a life interest.

PARA.TAB: This problem arose from a Social Security Appeals Tribunal case where a life interest was created under the will of a deceased person who immediately before his death was the partner of the life tenant. The coalition opposes this clause because we contend, as I said in the second reading debate, that it is not appropriate for the government to be considering such measures at the same time as it is conducting a review of the pension income and assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this clause. We believe the decision of the SSAT which brought the attention of the government to this particular provision was not in line with the original intention of the parliament—which I believe was understood and agreed to.

PARA.TAB: I note the opposition's intention to oppose both parts 8 and 9 on the grounds that the income and assets test review is to be conducted later in the year. We support delaying the provisions of part 9 until that review takes place, particularly as managed investments will no doubt be dealt with at some length by that review, but we believe the provisions of part 8 should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the opposition appears determined to change policy on this matter. It does not seem to have much idea of how to run an effective administration. The government is trying to ensure that people are not able to use wills to avoid the assets test. This possibility arose with an interpretation of the legislation by the SSAT. By refusing to allow even technical amendments to be made while the income and assets test review is under way the opposition seems to be prepared to condone avoidance of the assets test and to open up large holes in the existing provisions. The spirit of the act is quite clear in this matter, and the spirit of the opposition is to be obstructive and to allow the provisions to be rorted.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 29 to 34—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated, the Australian Democrats will be opposing these clauses on the grounds that the income and assets test review is to be undertaken later this year. This will look specifically at managed investments, and no doubt at other saved non-superannuation investments. I again point out that there are apparently so few people who will be affected by these provisions that there will be no financial implications from this measure, so the Democrats will be opposing these clauses.

—The Australian Democrats' attitude to these clauses is the same as that of the coalition. They also oppose clauses 29 to 34. We oppose part 9 which includes clauses 29 to 34 of the bill relating to the assessable period of a client that is to be taken into account when a client realises a saved non-superannuation investment. As Senator Woodley has mentioned, the government is seeking to have the assessable period of a non-client partner taken into account.

PARA.TAB: The department has indicated that it has administered these provisions, taking a non-client partner's assessable period into account, since March 1993 without the necessary legislative backing. The opposition will oppose this amendment to the income test as we contend that it is not appropriate, as I said before, for the government to be considering such changes at the same time as it is conducting its review of the pension income and assets test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here again the Australian Democrats and the opposition are united in mind, trying to change policy. The department has identified an omission made in a previous amendment and which benefited clients. The government is now seeking to fix the omission by ensuring that the assessable period is also defined for partners of investment owners, otherwise these partners would get an unintended and totally arbitrary advantage. The opposition is again obstructing the proper administration of this area.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats position is inconsistent. While they were not prepared to leave a hole in the assets test through the life interest provisions, they do seem to want to give a one-off windfall gain to a few individuals in this case. It seems the Democrats are preferring to overlook the fact that the entire income and assets testing regime is based on joint income. Perhaps the best way to describe it is to say that they must feel like being generous today. The government is not persuaded by that view.
Clauses negatived.
Clauses 35 to 40—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
