SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In our consideration of the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1993 we need to be aware that this is a budget bill to amend the Housing Assistance Act 1989 in accordance with the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Housing Assistance Act 1989 under which the states, with financial assistance from the Commonwealth, deliver housing assistance for rental housing and home purchase in accordance with the terms of the 1989 Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends section 7(3A) of the act, which section specifies appropriations made under the act, in particular those for 1993 to 1996. An amendment introduced in the other chamber belatedly by the government on 22 February this year has the effect of amending section 15 of the principal act. This amendment to the bill passed in the other chamber will have the effect of enabling the Commonwealth minister to authorise the full level of untied grants to a particular state in 1994-95, even if the minister cannot ensure that the state can meet the balance of its matching obligation for the value of home loans provided through its home purchase assistance programs. This is in accordance with paragraph 13(2)(b) of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

The financial impact of the amendments to section 7(3A) of the act appropriates from the consolidated revenue fund $1,080,890,000 in respect of the fifth grant year of the act—that is, 1993-94. It appropriates $1,010,641,000 in respect of the sixth year of the act—that is, 1994-95. It also appropriates $1,017,863,000 in respect of the seventh year of the act—that is, 1995-96. The bill amends these appropriations to $1,042,390,000, $1,028,141,000 and $1,035,363,000 respectively. The financial impact of the bill is thus to decrease the appropriation of 1993-94 by $38,500,000, to increase the appropriation for 1994-95 by $17,500,000, and to increase the appropriation for 1995-96 by $17,500,000. The financial impact to the Commonwealth of new section 15(2A) and new section 15A will not result in any additional Commonwealth outlays. The amendments to section 7(3A) of the principal act are routine and non-controversial, and implement budget proposals announced for the financial years 1993-94 to 1995-96.

The government announced a slippage of funding due to unexpected funds from 1992-93 rolling over to this financial year and the carry forward of other funds into subsequent years. These changes have been endorsed by state and territory housing ministers. The amendments to section 15(2A) and new section 15A have been requested by some state governments which, under their various home purchase assistance programs, have not been able to meet the matching grant level required under this legislation.

These amendments to the principal act have been alluded to in meetings with the housing departmental officials prior to Christmas 1993. On 22 February 1993, these amendments were introduced in the other chamber. My office contacted the offices of the various state and territory ministers to ensure that the state and territory government housing ministers were aware that the Commonwealth was going to proceed with amendments of this nature to this bill.

Whilst there has been a definite lack of consultation on the part of the federal government, the amendments as passed by the other chamber appear to have the endorsement of state and territory governments. My office was advised of these particular amendments that related just to the new amendments to the legislation only several hours prior to the legislation being debated in the chamber. I do not think the Australian Democrats were even given that particular courtesy with regard to this legislation. Therefore, the government must accept the criticism that it has attempted to bring in new amendments at the 11th hour. It is simply unreasonable and arrogant for the Labor government to expect same day delivery on those principled amendments.

Normally the coalition does not have a problem with the government introducing amendments to its own flawed legislation. However, we take exception to this rule when, first, the government had the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill sitting on its books in the other chamber for six months; secondly, there is an introduction of amendments to the bill which do not amend the content of the bill but are principled changes to the nature of the Commonwealth-state housing agreements; thirdly, courtesies are extended to the Labor caucus and cleared by caucus but the same courtesies are not extended to the Liberal and National parties, the shadow ministry, party room and back-bench committees, and, I am sure, to the Australian Democrats, the Greens and other independents in this parliament—I believe similar consideration for party debate was not extended in any way in this area—fourthly, the federal government does not even consult with the state minister and housing officials to advise that these amendments are to be implemented in the legislation, particularly when the amendments have major implications for the state budgetary processes.

Officers of state housing ministers alerted my office of their apprehensions prior to the debate in the other chamber, citing the fact that they had not seen copies of the amendments or explanatory memoranda accompanying the amendments. These officers were also of the opinion that this matter was to be on the agenda for the consideration of the Commonwealth-state housing ministers conference, which, as we all know, was held last Monday—a date some time after the amendments were foisted through the House of Representatives. I am highly critical of the federal government's handling of the housing portfolio. It has failed dismally in the provision of public housing, and this is after a decade—10 years—in government.

The Auditor-General's commentary on aspects of the Commonwealth-state housing agreements, which was tabled on 31 September 1993, contains damning comment on housing policy under the federal Labor government and the current Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services, Mr Howe. After a decade of Labor administration, the efficiency and accountability of the Commonwealth-state housing agreements should be beyond question. I would have thought that the emphasis for any minister for housing would be such that we would see less of the sort of trenchant criticism that is now being expressed by the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 6 of 1993-94, to which I have just referred, states:

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect that is frequently overlooked by departments and agencies is the need for clear identification, measurement and reporting of Commonwealth obligations of exposure under the agreement. In the case of housing, for example, data currently available to the department is insufficient to determine both the true levels of subsidies provided under the various housing assistance schemes and the overall exposure of the Commonwealth under its obligations to meet any shortfalls in the operation of those schemes.

These comments compounded criticisms made earlier in the National Audit Office report No. 1 of 1993-94. In that report the Auditor-General's comments in the area of housing and planning were very scary, and drew attention to a range of issues and agreements between the Commonwealth and state governments that needed addressing in the performance of the Commonwealth-state housing agreements. The issue that the Auditor-General has now acknowledged leads us to question where is housing in Australia. What rules, regulations and arrangements between Commonwealth and state housing ministers have been put in place? I cannot stress how alarmed I was when I questioned officers of the former Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services at the September-October 1993 Senate estimates committee hearings. The departmental officers admitted they had not responded to the recommendations with any degree of urgency.

PARA.TAB: The billions of dollars of Commonwealth money injected into public housing makes this an important issue to people with housing needs throughout Australia. If the federal government is going to walk away and not acknowledge any of the issues that are put under its nose by the Auditor-General on accountability, efficiency and effective performance indicators, we are in desperate and dire straits.

The Industry Commission report into public housing was established on 5 November 1993 by Treasurer John Dawkins. The draft Industry Commission report was released on 6 August 1993, and that also was a shocking report card on Labor's housing record. The final report, which was released on 13 January 1994, unfortunately, was not much better. The Industry Commission report is a critical indictment of existing public housing arrangements and highlights the urgent need for action. Its focus on people on low incomes or with disabilities, homeless youth, women escaping domestic violence and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people reveals the compounding relationship between unemployment and housing needs.

A joint statement by the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe), the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), and the Assistant Treasurer(Mr Gear), commenting on the Industry Commission's report, indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission concludes that more transparent funding and institutional arrangements and greater clarity in the objectives and responsibilities of Commonwealth and State/territory governments, will be necessary to enable the optimum mix of assistance measures to be identified.

PARA.TAB: The ministers said that the specific changes recommended by the Commission form a closely inter-related package which if adopted would see a significant change in the respective roles of the Commonwealth and State/ Territories and to present funding arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: However, despite the ministers' statements, I am concerned at the muzzling of the Industry Commission's recommendation on accountability. In the August draft report, recommendation 1 stated that governments should clarify their housing objectives to ensure that they are operational. Recommendation 2 was that housing assistance should be provided under arrangements which promote transparency and accountability.

PARA.TAB: In the final report, these recommendations appear to have slipped seriously in priority order—no doubt with subtle intervention by the ministers involved and perhaps some departmental officers—and have become mere suggestions. I fail to see why the federal government has not taken valid accountability criticisms on board and addressed these flaws. After all, if the government can snap its fingers and secure amendments relating to exemptions for state government home purchase assistance programs when they are unable to match grant level funding required by the Commonwealth under this act, then correct accountability, transparency and institutional arrangements should also be considered.

The sheer arrogance of the government in not taking valid criticism from both the Auditor-General and the Industry Commission and putting it into action shows how it has a total disregard for the public purse. The ministers have publicly acknowledged the federal Labor government will not respond to the Industry Commission's recommendations until June 1994. Ironically, that is a month after the May 1994 budget, given that they have had a draft report sitting on their desk since August of last year.

This government has absolutely no ability to address the problems raised by the Industry Commission. The areas that need to be addressed urgently by this government include: expenditure to promote and facilitate community housing; housing assistance for people in crisis; supported accommodation assistance program and crisis accommodation program; funding to modify community housing to meet special needs of people with disabilities; housing problems facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; and rent assistance measures for tenants in the private rental market so that it, firstly, declines as income increases, secondly, it is important that it is available to all low income tenants in the private rental markets and, thirdly, is brought closer to rent rebates in the public housing sector.

The Australian people have a right to know what this elected government is going to provide in the form of housing assistance. The recommendations will affect over one million low income households in Australia receiving housing assistance from the Commonwealth and state governments. Genuine battling families living in cities, suburbs, towns and villages across Australia are all affected. Many of these families have a father, mother, brother, sister, aunt, uncle or some other unemployed relative. There are nearly one million unemployed.

The Industry Commission's report is a critical indictment of existing housing arrangements and highlights the need for urgent action in some specific areas. Labor's recession has adversely affected large sectors of the Australian community. The Industry Commission acknowledged that many people have difficulty assessing appropriate and affordable housing including: people with disabilities; elderly people; young people; women and children escaping domestic violence and family breakdown; sole parents; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; and migrants. The fact that the Industry Commission reveals that many needy people have fallen outside the traditional safety nets and government spending priorities shows the compounding relationship between unemployment and housing needs—sadly, an issue which obviously the Labor government has walked away from.

This legislation is important for what it seeks to achieve in the financial arrangements and the certainty, but it is the challenge of policies and budgetary direction that the government must face in the forthcoming May budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill adjusts the amounts to be appropriated from consolidated revenue from 1993 to 1996 for the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The Democrats support this bill and also the amendments, but wish to comment further, as Senator Tambling has done, about the late arrival of those amendments. The Democrats also were not able to see them before the time originally set for this debate. They are readily available now, but we must remember that this bill was originally listed some time ago. It was very much at the last minute that we were able to see those amendments, which quite significantly alter the thrust of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Whilst supporting the legislation, I take this opportunity to stress that the Democrats do not support the general thrust of this government's housing policies and look particularly at the urgent need for government to address problems of housing for the mentally ill, housing for Australians with psychiatric disability, victims of domestic violence and in particular the growing number of young people, many of whom may not officially be on any homeless list but are squatting with friends, moving between relatives, and are effectively without a home that they can call their own.

There are some good pieces of news on the housing front, particularly the affordability index. It is at its highest level since the December quarter of 1984 for those people who are in a regular, secure, reasonably well-paid job. But that does nothing for those people—and there are huge numbers of them—on the public housing waiting lists. The housing lists in my state of South Australia are a disgrace. There are well over 42,000 people on the list, and that does not mean just individuals, but in many cases families are represented in that figure. In yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser the South Australian housing minister, Mr Oswald, said:
Three years ago there had been 3,000 public housing starts in SA. Last year it went down to about 600 and next year "we were looking at about 400".

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia cannot undo the mess it is in on its own as far as public housing is concerned. This legislation certainly has the potential to have an impact on that, but without some real will on the part of this government, very little can be done. We await with interest to see what will come out of the budget and what additional moneys will be made available to ensure that the number of housing starts goes up considerably.

PARA.TAB: The latest available data contained in Australia's Welfare 1993—Services and Assistance shows that one out of every 10 Australians was in housing need in the early 1990s and that, in particular, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families, young people and single parent families—and most of those single parent families are women—are in the greatest need.

Public and community housing is widely recognised as the most cost effective way of providing low cost housing. A recent cost benefit analysis by National Shelter demonstrates that there are measurable economic benefits which flow from public housing. They include: a reduction in poverty due to effective assistance to people on low incomes; the provision of basic human needs; lower inflation by lowering demand pressures at the lower end of the private rental market; stabilisation of cyclical activity in the building industry; higher employment; and security of tenure for tenants. In its budget submission, National Shelter argues that the government must provide additional resources for public and community housing so that commencements can go up from 10,000 to around 30,000 per year. As it is the peak umbrella organisation in Australia, I hope that the government is listening to its requests.

The Democrats are aware of the difficulties in defining the levels of homelessness, but the estimates of the number of young people who are homeless, at risk of becoming homeless, or in situations where they have no security of tenure and do not have a place to call their own, is at least 50,000. If we look at the implications of this for their physical wellbeing as well as the activities that these young people undertake—very few of them are able to continue with formal education—we see that it is not just a matter of providing housing that the government needs to look at in its economic analysis, but all the other costs that are going to have to be borne by government in later years if these young people are not adequately catered for.

The Burdekin report on human rights and mental illness highlights the need for increased access to supported accommodation for people with mental illness and for those with psychiatric disabilities. It stresses that these people should have priority of access under state housing authority agreements. This report also calls for better trained staff, increased resources for respite care and appropriate licensing and regulation of boarding houses and special accommodation facilities. In its response to the Burdekin report the government proposes to do a range of things. It will be looking at a national review of all Commonwealth, state and territory legislation, et cetera, but I ask the minister when we will see some action rather than a simple list of promises. Yes, the government will do it, but we need to know when the government is going to take action.

The Democrats consider the provision of affordable and appropriate housing a basic right, especially with regard to meeting the housing needs of disadvantaged groups. The recommendations raised in the Industry Commission report require action. The issues highlighted in the Burdekin report require action. It is not enough for government to say that housing is a key priority and yet do absolutely nothing about it in financial terms. We need action. It is unfortunate that, despite the fact that this bill has been around for six months, those amendments were so late. As I mentioned before, it is something that we hope does not happen again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to cover a couple of points that were raised by Senator Tambling and one matter raised by Senator Lees. I thank opposition members and Democrats who have spoken in this debate for their support for this legislation, although, as is usual, there was a fair amount of criticism on the way through, but I will attempt to deal with those criticisms now.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's reports were referred to by Senator Tambling. It has been suggested that there has been a lack of response to Audit Report No. 1 of 1993-94. That claim is not true; the Commonwealth has responded. Cash management arrangements introduced in October 1992 have identified some anomalies in information provided by states and these have been followed up with the states by the Department of Human Services and Health. Arrangements have been put in place to ensure more timely submissions of financial returns by the states. A set of performance measures and related data requirements are being developed in conjunction with the states. These will facilitate the evaluation of performance against national housing objectives.

Commonwealth and state officials are undertaking a review of home purchase assistance arrangements provisions of the CSHA. Joint policy development work with the states is also under way to address issues raised by the recent Industry Commission report, and this work includes measurement of the efficiency and effectiveness of housing service delivery. Reference was also made to Audit Report No. 6. Two matters on page 26 of that report were referred to. The questions of performance measurement and information requirements are being addressed as part of the joint policy work being undertaken with the states in responding to the Industry Commission report and in a review of the home purchase assistance provisions. Changes to be implemented in these areas will address issues raised by the Industry Commission as well as the ANAO concerning transparency in the costs of providing housing assistance.

However, the suggestion of Commonwealth exposure in respect of meeting any shortfalls in the operation of home purchase assistance schemes would seem to be based on a misunderstanding of the CSHA. The detailed design and operation of these schemes are a state responsibility, and the CSHA does not place any obligation on the Commonwealth to meet any shortfalls in their operation. Finally, on the audit report, the government agrees that the Auditor-General has provided sound advice on the introduction of prudent cash management. There need be no concern that an opportunity for improved cash management and savings has been ignored. In fact, it should be noted that the recommended practice was adopted under the CSHA in October 1992, well before this audit recommendation was made.

There was some criticism concerning consultation with states and territories about the amendments and about their introduction so late that apparently opposition and Democrat senators only saw them very late in the time frame for this legislation. In September last year the minister for housing met with housing ministers from New South Wales and Victoria. They asked him to address the difficulties they were experiencing in meeting their home purchase assistance matching obligations under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. The minister was also subsequently asked for similar consideration by the Tasmanian housing minister. As was explained to the parliament in the other place in the recent debate, the minister acted on these requests by seeking a legislative amendment to the Housing Assistance Act.

The standing committee of Commonwealth-state housing officials, which has representation from all state and territory housing departments and which considers housing policy and program issues, has discussed the matching issue on several occasions. At the most recent meeting on 1 February this year, the committee was advised that the Commonwealth would be pursuing a legislative amendment to address the difficulties of the states. The minister's office met with the shadow minister for housing on the same day that the approval to proceed with the legislation was given by caucus.

The coalition has claimed that state ministers expected to view the legislation at a ministerial council meeting last week. Minister Howe met with the state and territory housing ministers at the ministerial council on Monday and advised them that the Commonwealth was pursuing a legislative amendment. No concerns were expressed about this action. Some state ministers have purportedly indicated to the shadow minister's offices that they were quite happy with the legislation proceeding.

Senator Lees raised a matter in respect to the Burdekin report. The minister referred to that matter in a press release of 28 February. Senator Lees sought an indication from me on the provision of a time frame. I cannot give that to the honourable senator. I do not think she will be surprised that I cannot give her that assurance—we really have to be a little realistic. The minister's public statement on this matter was only two days ago, on 28 February. It is very difficult to give an ironclad time frame on this matter or many other matters in the government policy process. That is not any deliberate evasion; there are heavy schedules, workloads, et cetera. I have asked the advisers, as a matter of priority, to speak to the minister in an endeavour to ensure maximum consultation with Senator Lees on that time frame. I cannot give the honourable senator anything beyond that in this debate.
Other matters that were raised have been dealt with in the other place. I do not want to speak at length on the matter. I thank opposition and Democrat senators for their support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL WAR CRIMES TRIBUNAL BILL 1994INTERNATIONAL WAR CRIMES TRIBUNAL (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 February, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International War Crimes Tribunal Bill and the International War Crimes Tribunal (Consequential Amendments) Bill establish a legislative framework that enables Australia to comply with a resolution of the United Nations Security Council establishing an international war crimes tribunal for the prosecution of crimes arising from the ongoing conflict in the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

PARA.TAB: In the last parliamentary session, the government announced that it would try to issue a list of bills that would be introduced in this session for passage in the next or to highlight at the beginning the ones that were to be dealt with in this session. As I understand it, these bills were not on that list. I am not sure whether that was the case. I see one of the advisers looking a bit startled, so perhaps the bills were on that list. However, in any event, these bills appear to be rushed, and there may well be good reason for that.

The background to the bills is that in May 1993 the United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution establishing an international tribunal which had as its sole purpose prosecuting persons that were adjudged to be responsible for serious violations of international law committed in the former Yugoslavia. The resolution adopted the statute of the international tribunal which details the competence, jurisdiction, powers, composition and procedures of that tribunal.

The resolution was taken under chapter 7 of the charter of the United Nations which concerns actions with respect to threats to the peace, breaches of the peace and acts of aggression. Resolutions taken by the Security Council pursuant to that chapter are mandatory and binding on members of the United Nations. Pursuant to the terms of the resolution Australia, along with other member countries, has an obligation under international law to cooperate with the tribunal and take measures under domestic law to implement the provisions of the resolution and the statute.

In particular, article 29 of the statute provides: first, states shall cooperate with the international tribunal in the investigation and prosecution of persons accused of committing serious violations of international humanitarian law; and, second, states shall comply without undue delay with any request for assistance or an order issued by a trial at chamber including but not limited to the identification and location of persons, the taking of testimony and the production of evidence, the service of documents, the arrest or detention of persons, and the surrender or the transfer of the accused to the international tribunal.

What the bill is trying to do is allow us to fulfil those obligations and give us the capacity to do so. It is interesting to note that Sir Ninian Stephen, a former Governor-General and High Court judge of Australia, has been appointed as one of the 11 judges of the tribunal by the General Assembly of the United Nations, and that Mr Graham Blewitt, who formerly directed the Australian war crimes special investigation unit and the war crimes prosecution support unit has, as I understand it, been appointed a deputy prosecutor to the tribunal.

The second reading speech of the bill indicates that one of the intentions is that the bill should be kept as simple, minimalist and as clean and easy to understand as possible. Without wanting to be carping, I must say that it does not appear necessarily to have achieved that.

Part 2 of the bill allows the tribunal to make a request for assistance to the Attorney. Part 3 establishes a mechanism that allows for the surrender of persons to the tribunal. The provisions therein are modelled on the Extradition Act of 1988, but the discretion of the executive that exists in the Extradition Act of 1988 is somewhat curtailed in this bill—that is, the discretion of the executive to refuse a request by the tribunal is much more limited than in the Extradition Act. That is because of our international obligation to hand over someone to the tribunal, and that obligation is absolute.

The fact that the bill does provide a discretion for the Attorney-General to refuse to surrender a person to the tribunal does, therefore, have potential to cause us some embarrassment. Perhaps the minister, when he is responding, may care to make some remarks about that point. As we understand the situation, our obligations are absolute. So why does there need to be any discretion in the Attorney not to hand over? Does that not mean that we are not accepting an absolute obligation to hand over, and does that not allow for some potential embarrassment? There may be a simple explanation that has not occurred to us. In the event, we would be grateful if the minister could give some indication about that matter.
One of the commentators who contributed to the consultations on this bill with the shadow Attorney-General, Daryl Williams QC, put it this way:

SPEECH.PARA: One could imagine the pressures that might be exerted by different segments of the community for or against surrender of a particular person accused of war crimes. Rumour has it that the government had second thoughts about an Australian serving as a member of the tribunal because of the potentially divisive effects of the trials within the Australian community.
He went on to say:
A similar case could be made against the government retaining a discretion under the bill to refuse to surrender an accused.

There is a technical point in relation to sections 9 and 10 in part 3 of the bill, of which there may be some explanation. These provisions relate to the procedures applicable before an Australian magistrate can issue a warrant for a person's arrest to facilitate his or her surrender to the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: In a normal case the issue of a warrant by the magistrate must be conditioned by receipt by the Attorney-General of a warrant issued by the tribunal, together with a request from the tribunal that the person be surrendered. However a provision is also made that in cases of urgency the magistrate may issue the warrant where a warrant has been received from the tribunal, but no request for surrender has been received.

The reason for this procedure is not immediately obvious. It is not easy to envisage where the tribunal will have the time, capacity, reason et cetera to issue a warrant, but not to issue a request for surrender. Perhaps in the Minister's response there may be some explanation of that.

I looked in the explanatory memorandum, which regrettably I have not brought with me, and all it says is, `This clause deals with the issue of the warrant for surrender'. It does not actually explain why there are two limbs to clause 10. It is the second limb of clause 10, as I recall, that contains this provision for the matter to be dealt with differently in an emergency. All we ask is for some explanation of how there can be an urgency if a warrant can be issued by the tribunal but not a request for surrender. I look forward to hearing any comments the government might wish to make with respect to that.

Part 4 deals with other forms of assistance to the tribunal, including the taking of evidence and production of documents in Australia, search and seizure of evidentiary material in this country, evidence at hearings and so on. In relation to that and part 6, the provisions closely follow the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act, 1987. It might be worth remarking—which I had not thus done—that we will support the bill, and at this stage do not have any amendments to move. But, as I understand it, the bill is being referred to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee in the other place.

I had occasion last week to make reference to that committee. The chairman, Mr Daryl Melham, was proudly announcing that it was the premier committee of the parliament—not just of the House of Representatives, but of the parliament. I found that rather amusing, being on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the Senate, which does most of the work in the whole of this place. It has not done a bad job, works on a pretty bipartisan basis, and has been very effective for a number of years in addressing both the technical issues in bills and issues in the community. But nonetheless we are all entitled to our dreams, and Mr Melham is no exception in that respect.

Actually, Mr Melham has had a win. In fact, I was able to inform him of it, and he seemed a bit surprised. As I understand it, the government has agreed that this bill will be referred to the committee in the lower place. There is a temptation to say, `We will have it too'. Then we would have a good comparison of what the other place did and what we did. We all know who would be judged the better, but that might be judged to be a waste of taxpayers' money. So we will just wait and see what the House of Representatives committee has to say.

No doubt two of the matters that the committee will be addressing are those matters I have raised: the potential embarrassment by there being some opportunity for the Attorney-General to not pass someone over, and also the different procedure where there is an emergency, and some explanation for what that emergency might be.

Some people have said, with respect to this, that this process is just an empty vessel, a gesture at looking good to somehow pass off the world's guilt for the fact that the processes we have set up internationally are not being effective in stopping all the atrocities that have occurred and perhaps are still occurring in that part of the world and elsewhere. Although, as we are informed, the possibility of prosecutions might not be as remote as those people would think, and we are happy to support a commitment to pursuing people who engage in those sorts of completely unacceptable activities.

We understand that there is good evidence for prosecutions being launched against a number of people already. In fact, we understand that in Germany a high-ranking suspected war criminal is already in custody. So that is a good thing, if the tribunal finds that the person is guilty. It is perhaps not such a good thing if it finds that the person is not guilty.

On both sides of the dispute there are Croats who hold in custody Serbs who are accused of war crimes, and the other way around. Those detainees may potentially be surrendered to the tribunal. Our role is not expected to be very substantial. The bill is only likely to be utilised occasionally, and most likely in the context of simply surrendering suspects to the tribunal.

On that basis we are happy to support the bill, but we do believe that some of the technical matters need to be looked at. It is a very serious matter to agree to pass up our own citizens into someone else's jurisdiction and when we cannot rule out the prospect that it may in fact be our own citizens that we will be called upon to do that with.

Therefore, the bill deserves very close scrutiny to make sure that the procedures that are being put in place are the proper procedures, and that with all good intentions we are not somehow putting our citizens unfairly at risk—a risk that we would not put them at were we to have control of the matter. On that point I will conclude and look forward to hearing what Senator Spindler has to say and then the government's response to those two points that I raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the International War Crimes Tribunal Bill and related consequential legislation. The bill is a welcome attempt to give effect to the obligations that were imposed by the United Nations Security Council when it adopted resolution 827 on 25 May 1993. That resolution is based on chapter VII of the United Nations charter under which the security council is given mandatory powers to determine a threat or breach of the peace and to take measures to restore international security and peace. Article 25 of the United Nations charter obliges member states to cooperate and hence to override or amend provisions in national constitutions which may slow down the capture and surrender of their nationals.

PARA.TAB: In many respects, the action taken by the United Nations in resolution 827 is quite radical. It represents a move away from trying to get the agreement of the world community to the establishment of an international body to deal with all allegations of war crimes. That process has been going on since the Nuremberg trial.

Instead, the United Nations has acted to set up an ad hoc tribunal for the sole purpose of prosecuting those responsible for serious violations of humanitarian law in the former Yugoslavia since 1 January 1991. As Sir David Hannay, the British Ambassador to the United Nations, said at the time of the resolution it is `an exceptional step needed to deal with exceptional circumstances'.

At this point, I will comment briefly on the point made by Senator Vanstone. She said that these measures possibly are being taken to assuage our consciences because the world community at large has seen fit not to intervene in Bosnia and prevent the genocidal atrocious activities that have proceeded there and are still continuing. I wish to put on record my personal opinion that the failure of the world community, the European community, the United States, other countries and the United Nations as a whole to not intervene militarily in that particular situation is to be deplored.

I think it will affect detrimentally the future activities and status of the United Nations as a peacemaking as well as a peacekeeping body. As such, I think we, as a world community, have neglected to take an opportunity which would have established long-term credentials to bring about lasting world peace. It should be recognised by all and sundry—all countries—that the world community will not tolerate genocidal, murderous activities and that there is enough resolve and enough money to show that, although many of the nations that subscribe to the UN principles have failed and are failing to make their contributions.

I do not exclude our own government from the regret I am expressing. But I do realise that even if we said action should be taken and we in Australia were prepared to contribute our share, it is unlikely to overcome the obvious reluctance expressed by the European Community, by the United States and by other countries. I know the arguments against it. People are saying that to pacify the warring factions militarily in what used to be the state of Yugoslavia would take 500,000 personnel and we would have to commit them for 10 years or so. I know that that is the case. What I am saying is taking that into account. I think we are dealing with an exceptional situation. I think the world community as a whole is not meeting its obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you on that.

—I appreciate Senator O'Chee's support on that point. I return to the bill. The Australian Democrats welcome and support the main thrust of the legislation. The setting up of the tribunal sends a clear message to all in the former Yugoslavia that they must immediately stop violations of international humanitarian law or face the consequences.

PARA.TAB: Drawing upon the legislative framework suggested by the Extradition Act and the Mutual Assistance Act, the bill firstly gives legislative recognition to the international tribunal that has been set up to deal with the Yugoslavian war crimes. As Senator Vanstone said, Sir Ninian Stephen has been appointed to the panel of judges. I think, in view of Sir Ninian's distinguished record as a jurist and as a former Governor-General, it is pleasing to see that he has seen fit to accept that appointment.

Secondly, it provides mechanisms by which those people who may be resident in Australia and who are to be prosecuted by the tribunal can be arrested and surrendered to the tribunal. Thirdly, it also allows for the Attorney-General to make arrangements for witnesses to appear before the tribunal. Fourthly, it allows the tribunal to sit in Australia to take evidence. Fifthly, it allows for Australian authorities to assist in the gathering of evidence. And, sixthly, it enables forfeiture orders made by the tribunal to be enforced in Australia.

As I said, the Democrats support these provisions in the main. However, there are areas of the bill where amendments are needed to improve procedural fairness and to protect the rights of individuals. These areas of concern will be taken up in more detail later in the committee stage but I will flag some of them now.

There are two main areas of concern. One is in the surrender of persons to the tribunal. The surrender mechanisms set out in part 3 of the bill allow for the issuing of warrants and for the arrest of the person named in the warrant. This issuing of a warrant may occur either when a notice from the tribunal has been received by the Attorney-General or when the Attorney-General requests a magistrate to issue a warrant in the expectation that such a notice will be received.

Once a person is arrested that person may be either remanded in custody or granted bail. If a notice from the tribunal has been received, the Attorney-General must then make a determination as to whether or not the person is to be surrendered. Section 16 requires the Attorney-General to order the surrender of the person unless there are `exceptional circumstances'.

As the bill presently stands, there is no statutory right vested in the person who is to be delivered to make submissions to the Attorney-General on the matter of exceptional circumstances which might stop the Attorney-General from delivering that person. There is no right vested in the person to know the allegations made against him or her. I find that quite extraordinary.

In this bill there is no statutory definition of exceptional circumstances; there is only a statement that in exceptional circumstances the Attorney-General may decide not to surrender the person. Further, there is no court involvement in the determination of whether a person is to be surrendered; it is purely an executive decision. There are no rights of appeal. The Attorney-General's decision is not subject to review under the ADJR Act. There is no recognition of the time served by an Australian prisoner when he or she is surrendered to the tribunal.

I fully appreciate that these are exceptional provisions and that we do not wish to pass into law provisions which might lead to a person not being delivered to a war crimes tribunal and which might contribute to that person escaping. All honourable senators and the community at large would want war criminals punished and the prosecution of people charged to proceed as quickly and as effectively as possible.

In view of these considerations, all of which I support, I still feel that it behoves us not to ignore the normal safeguards that a civilised nation would expect to have in its judicial process. Clearly a balance has to be struck. Because of the extraordinary circumstances, it may be that in one or two areas we are prepared, and perhaps should be prepared, to relax a little the safeguards that we follow to ensure that they are available to accused persons in our adversarial legal system. Nevertheless, it is a weighty step to take to diminish these rights, even in these circumstances, and it should be carefully considered.

I understand from discussions that we have had with the government that it will agree to the amendments I will move that will require the person arrested to be given a written outline of the offence that he or she has allegedly committed and the conduct constituting that offence. I believe the government has also agreed to an amendment that I will move that will give recognition to the time spent in the tribunal's custody as time spent in serving an Australian sentence. The other concerns that I have outlined are still under consideration, in recognition of the fact that there is a balance is to be struck; however, I think that they will lead to some further Democrat amendments.

This bill has some connection to the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Bill, again in respect of which the Australian Democrats will be moving a large number of amendments with the intention of circumscribing police powers in the context of arrest, detention, search and seizure. Part 7 of the war crimes bill lifts provisions of the crimes bill into this bill. The Democrats acknowledge that as far as possible there should be legislative uniformity in this area; hence a final position on part 7 of this bill can be indicated by the Democrats only when the outcome of the debate on the Crimes Act amendments is known. I understand it is for that reason that the Senate will not be proceeding to the committee stage of this bill today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a particular interest in the former Yugoslavia as I competed in sport against a number of very fine gentlemen from Sarajevo—one of whom is now dead, killed by a mortar shell. The world is thoroughly repulsed by the inhuman, perverted and disgusting acts which have been committed in the former territory of Yugoslavia. I believe the world must take action to ensure that these things are not perpetuated.

PARA.TAB: I have been a supporter of the concept of a permanent court of international jurisdiction. However, I agree with many of the concerns outlined by my colleagues Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler that, just because we are repulsed by what we see, we should not necessarily rush into action which may be precipitous. I particularly agree with the concerns that Senator Vanstone has raised that some of the individuals who might be asked to be surrendered may be Australian citizens. That may seem strange to people who are not closely following the issue but, for one reason or another, many Australians have gone to the former territories of Yugoslavia and many of them are fighting in one force or another and, therefore, should they be suspected of committing an offence, they would be possible candidates for surrender.

There is always an obligation on a sovereign state to look to protect the interests of its nationals when they are sought for proceedings of this nature. That is one of the obligations of a sovereign state in international law. It has been said that the provisions of this bill are extraordinary measures. They are extraordinary measures because it is an ad hoc tribunal. The point is that we should be very careful in not opposing the second passage of this bill to ensure that in no way are we taken to be assenting to these particular provisions being subsumed into customary international law should another ad hoc tribunal be set up at another time to deal with possible international crimes in another area. Nor should we be seen to be assenting to similar provisions which would come into effect in the event that there is a permanent court of international jurisdiction on criminal matters. These provisions must be clearly understood to be extraordinary measures.

Having said that, I support the concerns that Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler have raised about matters that must be dealt with in the committee stage. However, I would be failing in my duty if I did not express my concerns at this point in time so that everybody understands the exact consequences of the passage of the bill. Some years ago I advocated that Australia claim jurisdiction in terrorist matters where Australians had been killed by terrorists overseas and to claim the power to try those terrorists in Australia—a power which the United States claims. The government responded by saying that it had jurisdictional concerns about that lest other states attempt to claim jurisdiction over Australians for acts which they have committed overseas or in Australia. I know that the two are not entirely analogous, but it must be recognised that there are similarities in terms of jurisdiction; that we have an obligation as a sovereign state to protect the rights of individuals; but, at the same time, that we do not wish to become a latter day Paraguay and be a haven for war criminals. That is why the second reading of this bill will not be opposed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions in the debate on the international war crimes bills. Senator Vanstone, on behalf of the opposition, touched on two matters to which I will respond. In outlining those two issues, she firstly expressed concern at what she perceived as the rush in getting this legislation into the Senate today. I do not know what Senator Vanstone's understanding was, however, the program has been proceeding very smoothly this week and that very smoothness is the only reason we are dealing with it earlier than she may have anticipated.

PARA.TAB: We are getting through our business reasonably quickly. I thank those opposite for their cooperative part in ensuring that we move our program along probably quicker than we anticipated. Probably the new arrangements for the hours of sitting have something to do with it as well. If that has inconvenienced Senator Vanstone, I apologise to her.

Secondly, Senator Vanstone made some comments about a colleague of mine in the other place, Mr Daryl Melham. He is a very intelligent, diligent and hardworking member; one of our finest on the back bench. He certainly projects that diligence, hard work and intelligence quite freely, as he should project it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make sure he doesn't gazump you on to the front bench.

—I accept what Senator O'Chee says; I am sure Mr Melham will be a future frontbencher in this very longstanding government, as it continues to win election after election. He is the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs where, as has been noted in this debate, this matter is to be referred.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone raised two matters. The first matter is: why retain a discretion to refuse? Apparently, the mere presence of a discretion does not of itself mean that Australia's obligations will not be adhered to. However, there may well be exceptional circumstances, such as humanitarian grounds, that would warrant refusing surrender—for example, a case where a defendant was suffering from a terminal illness with only a few months to live. It would clearly be unconscionable to surrender in such a case. But it must be stressed that it is only in such circumstance that the Attorney-General would exercise such a discretion. The bill seeks to find the appropriate balance between adhering to our international obligations and providing safeguards to Australian citizens.

The second matter relates to the issue of an arrest warrant without receipt of notice from the Attorney-General. The situation parallels the provisional arrest procedures under the Extradition Act. It may be necessary to seek to detain a person before he or she leaves the jurisdiction. It may be necessary to seek an arrest warrant as a matter of urgency in such circumstances. The urgency may be such as to prevent the issue of a notice by the Attorney-General under section 9 in sufficient time to reach the magistrate.

If there are additional concerns or points that Senator Vanstone requires clarification on, I will certainly speak to the Attorney-General and I am sure the matters will be taken up in the legal and constitutional affairs committee hearings.

Finally, both Senator Spindler and Senator O'Chee expressed their extreme concern at what has occurred in Yugoslavia. I agree with their sentiments very strongly. I am personally quite appalled at what has occurred in Yugoslavia over the last few years. I have had the opportunity to travel through that part of Yugoslavia that is now a war zone. With memories of a very enjoyable holiday in that part of Yugoslavia, to see it today turned into a war zone with the various atrocities that are occurring really does appal me. Certainly, I share Senator Spindler's concern at the failure of the United Nations to act in a more decisive manner to bring to an end the violence that is occurring in Yugoslavia.

I am also concerned that, in an area of the world which certainly prides and, at times, boasts of its relative civilisation—that is, Europe—these sorts of atrocities and this warfare can occur without, again, the active intervention of the various European countries in seeking to bring to an end that violence, together with the United Nations. I share very deeply those sentiments expressed by Senator O'Chee and Senator Spindler.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
