DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Health and Medical Research Council was founded 58 years ago and became a statutory authority last year. I do not think there is any body within the medical world that has had such a proud record of achievement in that 58 years. It has been an advisory group to government and has been responsible for the disbursement of research funds over that period. It has a very proud record throughout this period.

PARA.TAB: In its current report the major issues are as follows: inequalities in health status; improving the understanding of chronic conditions; ageing; environmental health; national health goals and targets; and research. Principally, I wish to comment on the inequalities in health status and this links with another document that comes later. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The first is the development of an Aboriginal health research program. Under this program the funds for health and medical research are paid to the Aboriginal community which is party to the research. This allows the community to negotiate on matters such as its aspirations from the research, ethical aspects of the research and the transfer of research skills to members of the community. Lengthy consultations were essential in the development of this program which has attracted research funding of $366,398 for 1994.

The Aboriginal community has enormous health problems. The number of Aboriginals in Australia is estimated to be 1.2 per cent of the population. The life expectancy for an Aboriginal male is 22 years less than the non-Aboriginal average and for an Aboriginal female, it is 15 years less than the non-Aboriginal average. The Aboriginal life expectancy rate is similar to that found in Third World countries.

PARA.TAB: That is not entirely due to neglect. Aboriginals have great problems with diabetes—the rate is 10 times the Australian average. Circulatory system disease, respiratory disease, ear diseases, eye disorders, cancer, urinary tract disease, tuberculosis and sexually transmitted diseases are much higher than the Australian average. In fact, tuberculosis is 20 times more common in the Australian Aborigine than it is in the non-Aboriginal population. So there is a significant need for this allocation of research. My concern in some respects is that this allocation gets through to the researchers and does not get diffused into the non-Aboriginal community or in the bureaucracy. Already Australia devotes over $1,000,000,000 to the Aboriginal community and it would be a tragedy if these funds were not used in the appropriate manner.

The other aspect of research I want to allude to is that the National Health and Medical Research Council says it has recognised the need to strengthen the discipline of health economics in Australia. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that one great growth area in employment in Australia is in health economists. I have never seen the degree to which they have achieved as in recent years. It really has been brought about by the government's desire to ration health care in Australia. This has meant the need for more health economists and their analyses in trying to restrict the amount of health care funding. I find that an interesting characteristic.

The report contains information on maternal morbidity for 1988-90. It found an increasing and unacceptably high rate of maternal deaths among Aboriginal women, with a high proportion of avoidable deaths. I will be interested to see what the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) is going to do about that. He has grandstanded all over the place regarding what he is going to do about Aboriginal health. Labor has been in government for 10 years. As I say, it is interesting that the report says there is an increasing and unacceptably high rate of maternal deaths among Aboriginal women. I will be interested to see in 12 months time what the report states in relation to this matter and how much the minister has achieved in that period. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Senate print media inquiry, I have had the opportunity to examine the modus operandi of the Foreign Investment Review Board in connection with one major foreign investment transaction—that is, the 1991 and 1993 applications by Conrad Black's Tourang consortium for the purchase and subsequent increase in ownership of John Fairfax Ltd.It is inappropriate to canvass the future report to the Senate on FIRB's controversial performance on this occasion. However, I do wish to comment on the annual report.

PARA.TAB: FIRB is a non-statutory advisory body comprising three paid advisers and an executive officer who is a Treasury official. It is the agency which provides the Treasurer with advice on what is in `the national interest' required under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act which covers the acquisition of shares by overseas interests.Under this act there can be no purchase of shares if the result would be contrary to the national interest. The previous requirement was for a foreign investment to be of net economic benefit to Australia.

The main functions of the board are to examine proposals by foreign interests for investment in Australia and to make recommendations to the Treasurer on the requirements of the legislation. In particular, it is to advise the government on foreign investment generally; to foster awareness both at home and overseas of the government's policy on foreign investment; and to provide guidance to potential foreign investors in the case of proposals which might not be in conformity with government policy.

From the examination of FIRB's two executive officers, this statutory body appears to lack direction and is completely over-worked. I see from the report that it had 3,825 proposals for investment in Australia. Of those, 3,602 were approved, with 2,268 conditions. With about 20 employees and, I understand, burdened with over 40,000 phone calls a year, one can see this very important body is completely over-worked. Clearly, FIRB's powers of investigation are limited and its power to enforce the conditions it sets on a foreign buyer are really unsatisfactory.

FIRB's biggest problem is its total lack of public accountability. I am afraid to say the public face of FIRB that we have seen is straight out of the text of Yes, Minister. The print media inquiry has shown that FIRB clearly stepped outside its operational charter. No-one knows to what extent it was inappropriate or inept because its officers refused to answer straightforward questions. However, it is clear from the public evidence before the Senate committee that the operations of FIRB have not been subject to an internal review by officers of the Treasury for many years, nor have they been subject to a review by the Auditor-General. This is entirely unsatisfactory when government policy clearly states and requires a regular review of major programs such as FIRB at least every three years.

The biggest aspect that has enmeshed FIRB having regard to the current Senate inquiry is the Senate's power to be given evidence that it requires. This is bound up with the government's claim in FIRB's defence of public interest privilege, which is clearly preventing FIRB's and the government's accountability in this very important area and case. There will be another exciting instalment of this matter, I can assure the Senate, because legal advice presently being sought and obtained by the committee may change forever the lack of transparency and public accountability of FIRB's performance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the comments of the previous speaker, Senator Sandy Macdonald, and continue our remarks on the Foreign Investment Review Board. I note that another member of the Senate select committee, Senator Minchin, is ready to speak as well. I am delighted. For years, I have been one of the few people in the Senate to talk about Foreign Investment Review Board annual reports. I am very pleased to be joined by others.

PARA.TAB: This report tells us exactly the same as all the other reports have told us in recent years: very, very little about the real processes of FIRB. I think this report highlights the shambles that is the government's foreign investment policy. In 1992-93, FIRB considered 3,825 proposals and approved 98.4 per cent of them. The largest single category of proposals was again in real estate, which represented one-quarter of the $24 billion of total approved projects. Major increases in investment and mining helped to push the total investment close to the peak achieved back in 1989.

There is a cost to foreign investment in this country and it is one that this government continues to overlook. It was highlighted in the FitzGerald savings report. The savings report warned that dividends paid to foreign investors cost more than the cost of the equivalent foreign debt in the long term. This situation is made worse by current policy which has allowed 63 per cent of foreign investment to flow into the finance, property and business services. I believe these produce little or no foreign revenue capable of helping to service foreign debt. This proportion has almost doubled in the last 10 years.

This brings us back to FIRB. Not only is it forced to implement a fundamentally flawed foreign investment policy, in my view, but it does so in a fundamentally flawed way. Superficiality and secrecy shroud its every movement. The number of proposals considered by each of the 18 FIRB employees in 1992-93 was 192, which was up from the 160 in the year before, which was up considerably from the 35 that the officers had to look into in the mid-1980s. Most approvals were granted with conditions. These were not followed up. There is no mention in this annual report of the follow-up of the 1,933 conditional approvals left over from 1991 to 1992.Then there is the aspect of secrecy. The report has little to say on its processes other than—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The board seeks to ensure that proposals are dealt with quickly and efficiently and every effort is made to avoid unnecessary interference in normal commercial practice.

What does `unnecessary interference' mean? Does it mean minor, irritating things like the national interest, like whether the proposal will add to Australia's economic well-being? How do the people who work in FIRB make these important decisions? We are not exactly sure. We have asked; the Senate select committee has asked; and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) will not allow his employees to tell us.

PARA.TAB: The Senate has not been the only body having trouble getting material out of the secretive FIRB and Treasury. The Auditor-General was forced last year to resort to taking precept action against Treasury to obtain information for a performance audit. It was the first time in 70 years that a Public Service department refused information to the Auditor-General on expenditure—although, I suppose, if its performance is similar to the rest of Treasury, particularly the Foreign Investment Review Board, we can understand their reticence to be exposed. It is still totally unjustifiable.

I intend to continue to push to ensure that Australia develops a proper foreign investment policy that protects our national interest; that protects our economic sovereignty; that is long term, not short term; and that such a policy is defended and enforced by an independent, open, rigorous statutory body. Our national watchdog should be a terrier, not a little poodle baulking at unnecessary interference with would-be trespassers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am a member of the print media inquiry. I do not want to canvass all the issues, but there are some areas of great concern. I do not share Senator Kernot's antipathy towards foreign investment, but I do share her considerable concerns about the operation of government policy and of FIRB in particular.

PARA.TAB: There are three areas that I want to deal with in the few minutes I have available to me in this debate this evening. I refer first to the inconsistency in the existing limits on foreign ownership of Australian media; secondly, the secrecy of FIRB operations; and thirdly, the need for an independent regulatory body in this area. The policy in relation to foreign ownership in the media is a complete and utter incoherent mess. The annual report we are considering states that:

SPEECH.PARA: All proposals to invest in the media sector are subject to prior approval under the Government's foreign investment policy.
It then lists that policy in various areas. In broadcasting:
Foreign interests in commercial television broadcasting services continue to be limited to a 15 per cent company interest for individuals and a 20 per cent company interest in aggregate.
That is TV. But then we find:
Foreign ownership and control limits have been removed for commercial radio.
So suddenly with radio we have no controls at all. When we get to subscription television broadcasting service licences, which Senator Collins knows about, we see:
. . . foreign interests are limited to a 20 per cent company interest for an individual and a 35 per cent company interest in aggregate.
Then we find the following:
There are no other foreign ownership and control restrictions on other broadcasting services.
Turning to newspapers, we find:

Foreign investment in mass circulation newspapers is restricted. . . . The maximum permitted foreign interest involvement in mass circulation newspapers by a single shareholder is 25 per cent and unrelated foreign interests are allowed to have . . . shareholdings of up to 5 per cent.

Completely different limits are set for all the different media. There is no logic whatsoever to it. There is no description as to why one particular area of the media should have one level or another area of the media have none, different, higher or lower levels of foreign ownership allowed. It is utterly incoherent and without any logic whatsoever. As this report sets out, it is a major flaw in the government's policy on foreign investment.

PARA.TAB: I turn briefly to the second issue that concerns me greatly about FIRB, that is, the secrecy with which it operates. I can put it no better than the Communications Law Centre did in its submission to us:FIRB gives no notification of its activities, nor seeks submissions, nor explains its criteria and methods. Its recommendations to the Treasurer are not disclosed. Requests for details of FIRB recommendations, criteria and reasoning have been consistently rejected under the Freedom of Information Act. . . . Once decisions are taken, they are invariably announced in brief formal statements without the giving of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an unbelievable and intolerable way for FIRB to operate. We even had FIRB officers telling us, for example, that they never reply to correspondence from tenderers or bidders. The way in which the AIN consortium was dealt with by FIRB was quite unacceptable for a government agency. I share Senator Kernot's considerable concern about that matter.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, as I mentioned, Australia needs an independent regulatory body. It is quite clear to me that FIRB as an advisory body is nothing more than a couple of people paid a retainer to appear as though they sit on a board. All the action goes on in the Treasury; FIRB is really under the Treasury's thumb. The extent to which there is any independence is utterly illusory. Far too much discretion is given to the Treasurer of the day which, particularly in the media area, creates considerable problems with the suggestion of political influence. It is about time that we had a system that operated on the basis of clear rules set down by the parliament and policed by an independent regulatory body. I certainly share with the Democrats the view that we must move to that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on many of the issues that I am concerned about in this Foreign Investment Review Board Annual Report 1992-93 that have been mentioned, and there are some points I would like to add. I am interested in the comment made by the opposition about the fact that FIRB is under-resourced. I wonder whether that means the opposition would be in favour of extra government revenue. Normally it is in favour of cutting government revenue, so perhaps this is one area where it would be in favour of additional government revenue, provided that the board improved its practices. I guess that answering correspondence is very difficult for the board if it has not the people to do so.

PARA.TAB: The number of applications that were being dealt with and the consequent number of acceptances mean that nearly everybody gets a guernsey in some way or another in terms of investment acceptance. It greatly concerns me that it is almost impossible to follow up whether conditions are satisfied.

I draw attention to the fact that on page v it is mentioned that there were 3,825 proposals for investment in Australia of which 3,602 were approved. However, turning to page 14 under `Urban real estate', we find that 3,236 of those proposals by foreign investors were to acquire urban real estate in Australia. That figure is increasing by 27 per cent. I am not surprised that in recent times the government has been saying that there is a buoyant market in real estate and that this is good for the economy when these figures come from this particular area. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: There appears to be increasing investor interest in the acquisition of residential real estate for development, particularly the acquisition of real estate `off the plan'.

This means that these are the applications that have gone through to the Foreign Investment Review Board. Many applications slip the cordon altogether and, as we know, there is no means of following up. There is an increasing amount of speculative investment, not just in real estate but in almost every other sector.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the figures. As to minerals investment, 0.98 per cent was expected, but $4.13 billion was acquisitions and $1.12 billion new business. That means that taking over companies accounted for much greater investment than speculative investment in companies that exist.

With manufacturing, we find $4.38 billion compared to $0.34 billion of new business. With services we find it is $2.52 billion compared with $1.20 billion of new business. This gives an indication that our pattern of investment consists largely of takeovers and speculation, and perhaps involves a fair degree of asset stripping. It has already been mentioned that a large loss of foreign exchange goes through profit repatriation and other means. This is something we need to look at.

I wonder whether there is a firm policy on national interest, and whether the Foreign Investment Review Board has the least ability at this stage to look after our national interest. One can only wonder whether the desire to get runs on the board in terms of investment figures sometimes pushes government policy makers and the Treasury to require organisations such as the Foreign Investment Review Board to be more generous than they might otherwise be. Not providing the resources for more careful scrutiny of public interest from the Foreign Investment Review Board is one way of making sure that the runs get on the board; that is, nearly every post is a winner. It is a very short-sighted approach. People find it difficult to own their own house when a great deal of speculative trade in real estate in Australia, whether domestic or otherwise, is going unnoticed or passing with a nod and a wink through the system. It will affect welfare, rent, mortgages and acquisitions, and will encourage asset stripping of other resources in Australia. This is something that we have never quite come to grips with, and not many people know what the situation is—neither does the government perhaps in real terms. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In the document produced by the Australian Taxation Office entitled Taxation statistics 1991-92, I was interested to read the figures for sales tax in the latest returns. When I got a copy of the document earlier today, I set out to compare the statistics contained in it with those for the last three or four years. One of the most important contributions I can make here today is to say that one of the problems with the statistics—I have only looked into the sales tax figures—is that we cannot compare the sales tax statistics in this year's report with the statistics from last year, the year before or the year before that. If we were to try to make a comparison between the Commonwealth's revenue from, for example, sales tax on items such as household appliances, household hardware or any other business category, it is impossible to do so because the method for gathering such statistics changed this year. This year's method is different from that used for the last two years. The method for gathering statistics in 1989-90 was different again. It is therefore impossible to make a comparison.

PARA.TAB: I will ask the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook, to provide to the Senate a version of the statistics for sales tax for the financial year to 30 June 1992 which is comparable with the last two or three years. We will then be able to see what has happened to sales tax revenue as a result of the recession and as a result of the upturn in the economy in the past few months. One of the downfalls of the Australian sales tax system with its many different rates is the fact that it puts on low and middle income earners a far greater burden than a progressive tax system would.

As we go through the figures for sales tax for various items, we note that low and middle income families are required to pay an enormous amount of tax on everyday items that they do not even know about. From the debates during the last election campaign and debates in this place over a number of years while we were discussing tax reform—it has gone off the agenda somewhat since—we know that Australia does have a number of different sales tax rates: 10 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent, 0 per cent and other rates applicable as exemptions.

I picked a basket of goods for the current year from table 6.3. It showed that some of the absolute necessities of life—some of the things that every family would buy at some time during the year, if not every week—would add up to something like $2.7 billion. That is a tax on families that applies whether somebody is a multimillionaire or living in the back blocks of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Southern Cross.

—Yes, Southern Cross. Things like household appliances collect exactly $716 million; crockery, brooms, cutlery, mops collect $117 million; confectionary, $99 million; soft drinks and cordial, $284 million; spirits, wines and beer, just under $1 billion; soaps and detergents, just over a quarter of $1 billion; toys, $172 million; and even pet food, $69 million. So an enormous amount of money is coming out of the pockets of Australian families. The sad thing is that many of those families cannot afford it.

PARA.TAB: For those items alone, if we divide the amount spent on them by the number of households in Australia, we find that every household in Australia would pay $500. If we look at sales tax as a proportion of the number of households, we find that the figure is up around $2,000 for every household. But it is a totally hidden tax; it is indeed Keating's hidden consumption tax.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! I ask Senator Campbell to use the proper title of Prime Minister or use `Mr Keating'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, Mr Keating—a fine man. The other item which will be of interest, particularly to Senator Margetts, is furs. Twenty-one people remitted sales tax details for the sale of furs this year—Brigitte Bardot would be interested in this as well—and not $1 of sales tax was collected. That might indicate that no furs were sold in Australia during this year, which is a good thing for the little seals and furry animals.
—What about kangaroo skins?
—No sales tax was collected on that either.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the report relating to the implementation of the Commonwealth government's responses to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It is an important document and a number of facts should be brought home to people when they consider Aboriginal deaths in custody. The report states that, in the last year to June 1993, 72 people died in custody. Of them, six were Aboriginal and 66 were non-Aboriginal. In fact, the rate of non-Aboriginal deaths in custody is increasing. The significant thing that I wish to refer to is the inequality that has occurred over the years in this regard.

PARA.TAB: An enormous amount of money was spent on the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I refer particularly to an article in the Medical Journal of Australia dated 1 November 1993. The article was written by Neil J. Thompson, former Head of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Unit of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, and David McDonald, Deputy Head of Research from the Criminology Research Unit of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. They set out to assess the risks of death in police or prison custody in Australia for Aborigines and non-Aborigines. The important and interesting thing that came out of that assessment was their conclusion, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Although some deaths in custody are inevitable, the very much higher risks of death in police custody for both Aborigines and non-Aborigines has implications for custodial authorities in terms of preventative and remedial action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said all this three years ago. It is in the Hansard.
—I appreciate what Senator Collins is saying, but not everybody reads everything he says—and it was three years ago. This article was written in 1993. The conclusion of the assessment continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Reduction of the excess of Aboriginal over non-Aboriginal deaths in police and prison custody relative to general population figures requires action to reduce the over-representation of Aboriginal people in custody and to improve the general well-being and health status of Aboriginal people in the community.

I refer to this document today because I have already spoken on the National Health and Medical Research Council report, in which it was interesting to note that $398,000 is being devoted for research funding. Almost a similar amount was spent last year in the alcohol and other substance abuse prevention program under the implementation of the same Commonwealth government response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. All of us know that something must be done about the problems that beset the Aboriginals because the combination of a 40 to 50 per cent Aboriginal adult unemployment rate with alcohol consumption in a community that has 10 times the Australian average of diabetes is a lethal one.

PARA.TAB: The witch hunt that occurred in relation to prison officers and police officers in this community was really not warranted. Although there are problems in relation to the custodial measures that ensued in this community—as Senator Collins pointed out three years ago—there seems to be a perception that the police were killing Aboriginals in custody. The police officers I know felt that they had to share this burden—a burden which did not exist in fact—with others throughout Australia. This lethal combination of the factors I have mentioned will not improve until those factors have been overcome in the Aboriginal community. If anybody wishes to read about this issue in more

SPEECH.PARA: detail, it is available, as I said, in the Medical Journal of Australia dated 1 November, 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 22 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Mr Doug Aiton, a broadcaster for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), who has recently been promoting his books, tapes and launches on air:
(1) Are Mr Aiton's books and tapes etcetera, ABC enterprise products; if not, what costs, if any, does Mr Aiton pay to the ABC for the privilege of advertising on its station.

(2) Please advise the nature and extent of any, and what, arrangements exist between: (a) Mr Aiton; (b) any other ABC on air presenter or personalities; and (c) the ABC in relation to: (i) copyright, (ii) royalties, and (iii) publishing rights.

(3) Section 31 of the ABC Editorial Policies permits the ABC to broadcast announcements of any of its activities comprising ABC and concerts and the range of ABC Enterprises product approved under the relevant guidelines, could a copy of the guidelines be provided; if not, why not.

(4) Given that ABC Enterprises receives no appropriation from the ABC budget as profits are returned to the other output divisions for programming and production activities: (a) which areas of the ABC provided funding for ABC Enterprises in 1992-93 and how much was supplied by each and every area; (b) how much profit was made by ABC Enterprises in 1992-93; and (c) how many and what magazines did the ABC publish in 1992-93.

(5) What, if any, Editorial Policies and guidelines does the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) have in relation to promotion of its activities, commercial or enterprise products and announcers endorsement of their own products, for instance, a book of interviews.
(6) How many enterprise products did SBS have in 1992-93 and what profit did they make for SBS.
(7) What, if any, tax in the 1991-92 and 1992-93 financial years did the: (a) ABC; and (b) SBS pay on their profits made by enterprise products.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the ABC and SBS:

PARA.TAB: (1) Doug Aiton's three books, Conversations with Doug Aiton, More Conversations with Doug Aiton and Doug Aiton's Proof of the Pudding, and his two audio cassettes/CDs, Your Favourites and More Favourites are all Enterprises product.
Doug Aiton's Favourite Classical Pieces is not an ABC Enterprises product but is sold in the ABC shop in Melbourne.
According to the ABC Act the ABC is able to promote ABC Enterprises product. The ABC Act prohibits advertising on domestic services and Radio Australia.
(2) (a) & (c) Mr Aiton has standard commercial contracts based on local industry practice for the books and audio tapes produced by ABC Enterprises.

Mr Aiton receives Enterprises' standard royalty rate consisting of a percentage of recommended retail price on sales through the ABC Shops and a percentage of net receipts to the ABC on sales through other sources.

Mr Aiton has retained copyright in the articles included in these works which were previously published in "The Age" newspaper. The ABC retains copyright in the published edition of the books and in the sound recordings of the audio tapes. Further, the ABC is the exclusive licensee for the duration of copyright of subsidiary and ancillary rights in relation to the works.

(b) Similar arrangements exist with other ABC on-air presenters and personalities involved in the creation of product through ABC Enterprises. A standard commercial contract is negotiated for work to be done in their own time. Such contracts are separate from other contractual arrangements with the ABC in relation to the terms of their employment.
(3) This question has been taken to refer to section 31 of the ABC Act.
Sections 14-15 of the ABC Editorial Policies give guidelines regarding promotion of ABC activities, particularly sections 14.1.2 and 14.2.1. The Editorial Policies document is freely available.
(4)(a) No areas of the ABC provided funding for ABC Enterprises in 1992-93.
(b) ABC Enterprises made a profit of $2.8M in 1992-93.
(c) ABC Enterprises published the following magazines in 1992-93
A Summer of Golf (one-off publication, published in October 1992)
West Indies in Australia 1992-93 (published November 1992)
Australian Tour of England 1993 (published May 1993).
(5) Whilst the SBS does not yet have written guidelines it has a commercial activities policy of following the SBS Charter and SBS Codes of Practice as a framework for its activities.

(6) In 1992-93 the SBS had two enterprise products—"The SBS World Guide" and "The SBS Guide to Ethnic Eating". The revenue from these two products was $18,000 and $5,700 respectively with a net profit margin of 10%.
(7) (a) Under section 71(1) of the ABC Act 1983, the corporation is not subject to taxation, however ABC Enterprises does pay sales tax for participation in commercial activities.
(b) Under section 68 of the SBS Act 1991, the SBS does not attract tax on such profits.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 January 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since the proclamation of the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992, on how many occasions has the National Health and Medical Research Council consulted publicly, under section 12-15 of the Act, on: (a) a regulatory recommendation; (b) a guideline; and (c) a prescribed activity.

(2) For each instance specified in (1): (a) what was the recommendation, guideline or prescribed activity on which public consultation took place or is still taking place; (b) who was consulted and who was invited to make submissions; (c) through what forum or medium were invitations to consult issued; (d) by what process did the council decide on the scope of consultation and on the advertising of it; and (e) what funds were available to the council for public consultation in each of the instances in which public consultation has taken place to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) six occasions
(b) nine occasions
(c) no occasions.
(2) (a) Consultations have taken place or are still taking place on the following:

(ii) Air Quality Goals for Ozone: Environmental, Economic and Social Impact Assessment;
(iii) Options for Australian Air Quality Goals for Oxides of Sulphur;

(v) development of Dietary Guidelines for Children;
(vi) Use of Antibiotics in Agronomy and Horticulture;
(vii) Termiticides (Safe Use) Code of Practice;
(viii) draft Report on Boxing Injuries;
(ix) development of a report on Head and Neck Injuries in Football;
(x) regulatory recommendations on Effective Care in Childbirth;
(xi) guidelines for Donation of Organs and Tissues for Transplantation;
(xii) a re-examination of guidelines on In Vitro Fertilisation and Embryo Transfer;
(xiii) a review of guidelines on the Protection of Privacy in the Conduct of Medical Research;
(xiv) proposed guidelines on the Use of Patient Tissue Samples in Research; and
(xv) proposed guidelines on Legal Liability, Insurance and Indemnity Arrangements for Institutional Ethics Committees.
(2) (b) Submissions were invited from the public at large.
In addition, submissions relating to the consultations, as numbered above, were invited from the following:
(i) interested parties including health professional associations, industry groups and overseas health agencies;

(ii) all local government authorities in Australia; peak industry bodies; individual industries and businesses; State and Territory health, environment, energy and transport departments; consumer and environment organisations which had previously expressed interest; academic institutions in Australia and overseas with an interest in environment, health transport and urban issues.

(iii) industry and business organisations; State and Territory health and environment departments; Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency and the Commonwealth Department of Environment, Sport and Territories; consumer and environment organisations which had previously expressed interest; academic institutions in Australia and overseas with an interest in environment, health, transport and urban issues;
(iv) and (v) organisations and individuals with a known and interest in the topic, including those who made submissions in an earlier consultation;
(vi) Commonwealth, State/Territory and Local Governments, and interest groups;
(viii) boxing and kickboxing associations; medical associations and medical experts;
(ix) football organisations; medical associations; academic institutions; football/medical experts; international football and medical experts; international football organisations;

(x) interested individuals and organisations including: State and Territory health departments; medical colleges; nursing bodies; child health organisations; major maternity hospitals; community health services; health and social welfare councils; women's health services; consumer bodies; health advisory groups;

(xi) medical colleges and peak nursing bodies; State and Territory health departments; bereavement care associations; organ registries; transplantation units; welfare organisations and consumer bodies;

(xiii) all institutional ethics committees registered with NHMRC; Public Health Association; Australian Epidemiological Association; members of the Privacy Advisory Committee; State privacy bodies; individuals and organisations who made submissions on the guidelines when the guidelines were first developed;

(xiv) all institutional ethics committees registered with the NHMRC; the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia; research institutes; people who had provided comment during an earlier consultation on this issue; and
(xv) all institutional ethics committees registered with the NHMRC; hospitals and universities; the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association; the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

Consultation (xii) re-examining guidelines on in vitro fertilisation and embryo transfer was also notified in the newsletter of the Australian Health Ethics Committee which has a distribution of more than 1500.
(2) (d) Decisions are made on a case by case basis by or on behalf of the Council committee that has carriage of the particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Do Acceptable Daily Intakes (ADIs) only measure the level of one particular chemical in isolation.
(2) To establish an ADI is only one particular chemical considered at a time.
(3) Are these ADIs based upon data gathered from experiments on laboratory mice and rats.
(4) Do mice and rats produce their own anti-oxidants which detoxify chemical pollutants.
(5) Does the human body produce its own vitamin C or anti-oxidants.
(6) Do humans and rodents respond differently to a particular pesticide.
(7) Is the data on which ADIs are formulated applicable to humans if there is a fundamental bio-chemical difference in responses between laboratory mice and rats, and humans; if so, how.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) is an estimate of the daily intake of a particular chemical which, if consumed by a human over an entire lifetime, should not cause any appreciable risk to health. It is expressed in milligrams of the chemical per kilogram of body weight per day (mg/kg/day). By definition it relates to a particular chemical.

(3) The ADI is derived from the No Observable Effect level (NOEL) for the most sensitive toxic effect in the most sensitive species tested. This need not necessarily be the rat or mouse. Relevant human data, where available, are also used in developing an ADI.

(4) The anti-oxidant properties of every substance present in the diets or synthesised in vivo in animals and man are not known. The biochemistry and physiology of processes for the metabolism and excretion of natural and synthetic toxic chemicals involves many factors other than chemicals with anti-oxidant properties.
(5) See (4). With specific reference to vitamin C, humans are not able to synthesise this chemical and this must be sourced from the diet.

(6) The response of different species to a particular pesticide is dependent on many factors including the route, dose and duration of exposure. In some cases responses are essentially the same while in others they may differ, in various degrees of significance, either quantitatively or qualitatively.

(7) For the reasons given in reply to part (6) the appropriateness of particular animal models in the assessment of a given chemical is considered as part of the toxicological evaluation. The calculation of an ADI, where based on animal data, includes factors to allow for interspecies variation.
